story:
Math and Science of Superheroes

  • I am Timothy Hinchman and have been teaching math and science for middle school students for ten years.  My Bachelor's and Master's are in Criminology and I worked in the Criminal Justice field for ten years prior to my tenure as a teacher.  As a student, I enjoyed these classes when they were geared towards my personal interests or my instructor's interests. 
  • I often had trouble focusing in class except in those classes where the teacher was engaged in discussions and activities with their students.  I had several teachers that would just ask a questions and it was up to the students to find a solution to this question.  I found myself gravitated towards the absurd and often used examples I read about in comics or Saturday morning cartoons to get the answers.  My answered always seemed to have a pattern, which made my teacher smile (whether intentionally or not.)  I want to offer the same creativity in my classroom and allow other students to sawn their inner cape while enjoying the complexities and simplicities of math and science.
  • I have been teaching my classes thematically for years on no budget and paying for all expenses out of pocket.  I usually spend between $1500 and $2000 a year on raw materials for my students to create various instruments used by Batman, Captain America, Spiderman, Green Lantern, etc.  The school where I teach is rural and is economically deprived and it is becoming more and more difficult to get financial assistance.  I am asking you to be a Hinchman's Henchman/Henchwoman and help me make a difference in a student's life.

What I Need & What You Get

  • Seeking:

    • $2000 for simple construction equipment (including 5 Oscillating Multitools and attachments to cut wood and metal;  5 wood saws, 10 hammers, 15 exacto knifes  buffing machine and 5 electric screwdrivers)

    • $1000 for raw materials (including sheet metal, rubber edge, plywood, 4 X 4 or various lengths, graph paper and poster board.)

    • Any contribution will help in purchasing equipment for the 2012-2013 school year.
  • What you get:
    • #1  A Better Tomorrow-  a future of educated and enthused students that grow up to be engineers, scientists, cartoonist, film directors, doctors, etc
    • #2 For $25 contribution you will receive a personalized e-lesson on the math and science behind one of my favorite superheroes.  The E-Lesson wil be in E-Pub format to be viewed on mobile device/tablet.
    • #3 For $50 contribution you will receive the personalized e-lesson and a Hinchman's Henchmen T-shirt.. 
    • #4 For $100 contribution you will receive a personalized  e-lesson, T-shirt and hat.
    • #5 for $250  contribution you will receive all the previous perks plus personalized  Hinchman's Henchmen/women personalized batarang (will be completed by the students during the school year when we cover the Nature of Science)
    • #5 for $500 contribution you will receive all the previous perks plus a personalized  Hinchman's Henchmen/women personalized shield (will be completed by the students during the school year when we cover Netwon's Three Laws of Motion.)

The Impact

  • Making students love math and science.   The United States is at a crossroads and we need an intervention.  Making this difficult classes fun and enjoyable will encourage our stduents to further their education in these fields. 
  • Help me make a difference in a student's life.  It is difficult for some students to understand why they are in school and what benefits an education has to offer; it is our duty and responsibility as human beings to help those less fortunate. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Volunteer at your local school
  • Share this campaign with others via twitter and facebook.  follow me @MrHinchman.
story_txt:
Math and Science of Superheroes

I am Timothy Hinchman and have been teaching math and science for middle school students for ten years.  My Bachelor's and Master's are in Criminology and I worked in the Criminal Justice field for ten years prior to my tenure as a teacher.  As a student, I enjoyed these classes when they were geared towards my personal interests or my instructor's interests. 
I often had trouble focusing in class except in those classes where the teacher was engaged in discussions and activities with their students.  I had several teachers that would just ask a questions and it was up to the students to find a solution to this question.  I found myself gravitated towards the absurd and often used examples I read about in comics or Saturday morning cartoons to get the answers.  My answered always seemed to have a pattern, which made my teacher smile (whether intentionally or not.)  I want to offer the same creativity in my classroom and allow other students to sawn their inner cape while enjoying the complexities and simplicities of math and science.
I have been teaching my classes thematically for years on no budget and paying for all expenses out of pocket.  I usually spend between $1500 and $2000 a year on raw materials for my students to create various instruments used by Batman, Captain America, Spiderman, Green Lantern, etc.  The school where I teach is rural and is economically deprived and it is becoming more and more difficult to get financial assistance.  I am asking you to be a Hinchman's Henchman/Henchwoman and help me make a difference in a student's life.



What I Need & What You Get

Seeking:


$2000 for simple construction equipment (including 5 Oscillating Multitools and attachments to cut wood and metal;  5 wood saws, 10 hammers, 15 exacto knifes  buffing machine and 5 electric screwdrivers)


$1000 for raw materials (including sheet metal, rubber edge, plywood, 4 X 4 or various lengths, graph paper and poster board.)

Any contribution will help in purchasing equipment for the 2012-2013 school year.


What you get:

#1  A Better Tomorrow-  a future of educated and enthused students that grow up to be engineers, scientists, cartoonist, film directors, doctors, etc
#2 For $25 contribution you will receive a personalized e-lesson on the math and science behind one of my favorite superheroes.  The E-Lesson wil be in E-Pub format to be viewed on mobile device/tablet.
#3 For $50 contribution you will receive the personalized e-lesson and a Hinchman's Henchmen T-shirt.. 
#4 For $100 contribution you will receive a personalized  e-lesson, T-shirt and hat.
#5 for $250  contribution you will receive all the previous perks plus personalized  Hinchman's Henchmen/women personalized batarang (will be completed by the students during the school year when we cover the Nature of Science)
#5 for $500 contribution you will receive all the previous perks plus a personalized  Hinchman's Henchmen/women personalized shield (will be completed by the students during the school year when we cover Netwon's Three Laws of Motion.)







The Impact

Making students love math and science.   The United States is at a crossroads and we need an intervention.  Making this difficult classes fun and enjoyable will encourage our stduents to further their education in these fields. 
Help me make a difference in a student's life.  It is difficult for some students to understand why they are in school and what benefits an education has to offer; it is our duty and responsibility as human beings to help those less fortunate. 





Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer at your local school
Share this campaign with others via twitter and facebook.  follow me @MrHinchman.

story:
Short Summary

Giving Liberian youth a voice for their own issues and ownership of their art.  Working at 5 program sites across Monrovia and Mt. Barclay, with approximately 300 children, we will build on our 3 year legacy of writing an original play with music and dance that focuses on community issues and change from the youth perspective.  Many of our participants are orphans or high-risk in other ways due to 14 years of civil war.  Inconsistent education and no access to arts training has left these children with a void and a need to express their greatest concerns.  

Program Director, Jasmine Blanks, Harford County, Maryland, USA music teacher, MPP University of Minnesota, BS Music Education Florida A&M University, has run this program through small contributions and grants for two years.  This year's expanded partnership with Liberian government entities including the Ministry of Education, Ministry of Youth and Sports, and University of Liberia, aims to train 20 Liberian young adults to lead 5 program sites in this tested program model that teaches literacy and math through the artistic process of play-writing using the Public Achievement model of community organizing.  

B4 (Burning Barriers, Building Bridges) Youth Theatre has received commendation from US-based organizations including Samaritan's Purse,  and the President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf for its impact for youth in Liberian communities.

Contributions make it possible to:

1- Train 20 young adults during a 2 week seminar

2- Run an 8 week program for 300 youth across 5 program sites

3- Write an original play on issues of importance to Liberian youth

4- Hold 5 community performances and a cumulative performance at Monrovia City Hall, the largest performance venue in Liberia

5- Produce a high-quality DVD of the performance with documentary segments

6- Hold round table discussions between program sites for youth development and community empowerment on these issues

7- Enable youth to share their concerns with Liberian government officials 

8-Become officially established as a 501c3 so that we can reach a variety of contributors

 

What We Need & What You Get

Program Budget (in US dollars)

Director and Staff provisions:
Flight                                      $2000/person
Housing                                  $1740/person [$25/day for 10 weeks]
Food                                       $1400/person [$20/day for 10 weeks]
Stipend                                   $1,000/person
Teaching Tools                         $1,000/Discipline [music, dance, theatre]
Individual Total                        $7,140/person X 5 people
Director and Staff Total              $35,700

Trainees:
Stipend                                   $100/person X 22 people
Trainee Total                                 $2200

Venues:
Fendell Campus auditorium and dormitory space
5 Local Venues for rehearsals and performances (churches, town hall buildings, etc)
Monrovia City Hall

Transportation:
5 buses for each of the following events (30 participants at 5 locations):
- Field trip
- Final performance
1 SUV daily (7 rotating team members between locations)
Fuel for SUV                                   ($600)

**Performance Budget (in US dollars)
Advertising                                $300
Program Printing                        $300
Costumes                                 $1000- higher than 2010 due to more                                                                                                                                   `                                                 participants

Sound Equipment                       $400
Fuel for Generators                     $500
Stage Set and Props                   $500
*Transportation for Audience Guests $100
PERFORMANCE TOTAL                      $3,100

       
Venue (Cost not included): Monrovia City Hall
*In 2010, more than 50 young children ages 5-10 were safely picked up for the show and escorted home.
**Budget can be decreased by in-kind donations.
PROGRAM TOTAL                        $41,000

 

Establishment as 501c3 and US advertising costs/information for sponsors

ADMINISTRATIVE TOTAL              $2000

 

OVERALL TOTAL                          $43000 (minus indiegogo fees of nearly  $2000)

 

What you get:

Sponsors $5000+

- Listed on website as a Program Sponsor (http://burningbarriersliberia.wordpress.com/)

- Listed on program and Souvenir booklet

- Mentioned during our Special Thanks at the end of the performance (included on the DVD)

- Receive a copy of the DVD including the performance and documentary segments

- Receive a copy of the 2012 original play with student actor signatures

- Receive copies of the 2011 and 2010 original plays

- Signed copy of cast photo poster

- Reserved seating and an invitation for two persons to attend the VIP reception immediately following the performance. (*if you decide to attend the cumulative performance in Liberia- not funded by our organization- we wish we could!)

Sponsors $1000+  

- Mentioned in Special Thanks article on website (http://burningbarriersliberia.wordpress.com/)

- Listed on Souvenir booklet

- Mentioned during our Special Thanks at the end of the performance (included on the DVD)

- Receive a copy of the DVD including the performance and documentary segments

- Receive a copy of the 2012 original play with student actor signatures

- Receive copies of the 2011 and 2010 original plays

- Signed copy of cast photo poster

- Reserved seating (*if you decide to attend the cumulative performance in Liberia- not funded by our organization- we wish we could!)

Sponsors $500+

- Mentioned in Special Thanks article on website (http://burningbarriersliberia.wordpress.com/)

- Mentioned during our Special Thanks at the end of the performance (included on the DVD)

- Receive a copy of the DVD including the performance and documentary segments

- Signed copy of cast photo poster

Sponsors $100+

- Mentioned in Special Thanks article on website (http://burningbarriersliberia.wordpress.com/)

- Receive a copy of the DVD including the performance

Sponsors under $100

- Mentioned in Special Thanks article on website (http://burningbarriersliberia.wordpress.com/)

- 20% off cost of DVD of performance

 

*If we do not raise the entire amount, priority goes to program implementation.  We may run fewer program sites if necessary.  Admin costs would be reduced in advertising and reaching new markets.  We may not be able to create the documentary.  We really want to raise all of the money to make all of this happen for these children!

 

The Impact 

"Ms. Jasmine has shown us how to use our talents to make a difference in our communities" Sam (2010 participant and 2011 Junior Arts Instructor, age 16)

Need
As Liberia forges ahead with its development agenda, there are many new buildings and roads. However, there is a lack of quality programs to meet the needs of high risk youth. This is particularly evident during the months of vacation from school. If we are to combat growing rates of teen pregnancy and violence and increase rates of school completion and youth civic participation, young people need an avenue for expressing themselves where they feel valued and encouraged while learning new skills. This kind of program also needs to be sustainable by the people of Liberia in order to grow and provide rich artistic and educational experiences for youth seeking guidance at a time when they normally would have limited supervision.

Secondly, the arts are absent from educational settings in Liberia, and there are few, if any opportunities for the study of music, dance and theatre. Without these opportunities for young people, any Liberian desiring to achieve a professional level of performance will have to seek training outside of Liberia.


Finally, young adults who are currently jobless due to lack of skills after years of destructive war are seeking opportunities for growth and service to their communities. Training programs designed to serve high-risk children provide a direct opportunity for service while participants are learning basic skills in youth development, recreational programming, and education provision.

Burning Barriers, Building Bridges (B4)

Program History 2009-2011

In 2009, Director Jasmine Blanks heard President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf speak about the "Education Drive for Liberian Youth" and immediately felt connected to the need of Liberia's youth.  A student at the Humphrey Institute for Public Affairs, Ms. Blanks met with then Inspector General for Liberia, Marc Amblard, and Director of Liberian NGO Touching Humanity in Need of Kindness (THINK) Inc., Rosana Schaack, to create a plan for a pilot of an arts intergration program for Liberian youth.

In 2010, 40 children from the Children’s Rescue Outreach Center Orphanage Mission in Mt. Barclay, Liberia participated in the 2010 program of Burning Barriers, Building Bridges. 24 of these children wrote and performed an original play with music and dance. This process lasted seven weeks, and the final performance was held at City Hall in Monrovia during the eighth week. Among approximately 300 audience members, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and other government officials were in attendance.


This performance resulted in approximately $1500 in donations that were used to pay program costs, as well as, school fees for some of the children. Additionally, the children were invited to attend a special lunch with the President.


Since the summer 2010 program, there have been continued cross-cultural literacy efforts between the children at the Children’s Rescue Outreach Center Orphanage Mission and children in school in Covington, GA, USA and their first original play has been analyzed for its literary content by students in Harford County, Maryland. Liberian and American newspapers have covered aspects of this program. The play has been broadcast on Liberian television with advertisements on radio stations.


In 2011, we partnered with Calvary Empowerment Team’s Vacation Camp to provide arts education for an additional 60 children. Between the two program sites (Sinkor and Mt. Barclay), 120 children were served. The original site from Mt. Barclay retained and improved upon the information they learned in math, literacy and the arts from the previous year as evidenced in written pre-test scores and performance assessments during the first week. Children from both sites were excited to voice their concerns through theatre as they felt that the concerns of young people are often overlooked. Two performances were held; one at Tubman High School in Sinkor and the other in Mt. Barclay at the orphanage. Participants had combined rehearsals in the final week and performed at both locations together thus bridging these two communities and exposing the children to the collaborative spirit of performing arts.

Additionally, three previous participants from Mt. Barclay are trained as Junior Arts Instructors. Here they learned elements of program design, curriculum and instruction, and a variety of pedagogical methods in the arts.

Skills gained by youth: Increase in ability to do basic math with fractions and some algebra, improved writing skills and grammar, better command of theatrical performance, ability to compose 2 and 3 part musical selections, ability to choreograph short dance numbers with transitions for large and small groups.  

"We are becoming better people for tomorrow" Deborah (2010 and 2011 participant, age 11)

Other related projects:

Click4Life Minnesota http://www.click4life.org/page/2/ (Ms. Blanks served as the community organizing/legislative advisor)

Small Donations Make BIG CHANGE!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean YOU can’t help:

  • Get the word out: @B4YouthTheatre on Twitter, http://burningbarriersliberia.wordpress.com/
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Ship supplies: notebooks, pens, pencils, small toys (balls, jump ropes), instruments

story:
Angry, Young & Poor:  
building community since 2001

Angry, Young & Poor (AYP) is a free summer festival that was created in 2001 to fight apathy & promote the local scene of Fairbanks, Alaska. The Disorganizers of AYP have volunteered thousands of hours to promote positive, alternative lifestyles while to supporting local musicians & artists. THEN, in their spare time, The Disorganizers volunteer heavily within the community... because we love our town & want to see it become everything it has the potential to be.

To keep AYP as a free event The Disorganizers fundraise by hosting original events that spotlight local talent: David Bowie, Twin Peaks, apocalypse & Fear & Loathing themed Proms, all-ages raves & arcade nights, burlesques, theatre, singer/songwriter showcases, a Dr. Who Informal: these events cover the costs for insurance, equipment, merchandise & the other sundry costs associated with an all-day festival.  Any remaining funds are donated to area non-profits: local community associations, homeless youth programs, educational non-profits & health centers.

AYP is an iconoclast and by any other name would smell as sweet. We work hard to encourage individuality, leadership & community action while promoting the people who make Fairbanks such a artistic oasis.

We could not maintain what we do without the help of people with similar ideals & loves… it really does take a village.

What We Need & What You Get

It costs a lot of money to make a festival:

  • Original art & locally printed, eco-friendly festival t-shirts: $1,000+
  • Event insurance: $300
  • Sound equipment rental: $500+
  • Stage material: $200

Any amount of money we can raise towards these goals will deeply impact the awesomeness of AYP 2013 & the amount we can give back in to the community.

However, we’ve got some fabulous perks for your donations: AYP bumper stickers, handwritten thank-you cards, personally crafted pins, 2013 t-shirts & more!


Plus, there's the reward of ceaseless badassery: GLORY!

Other Ways You Can Help

Money’s tight all over & we can dig that fact, but there are plenty of ways to lend a hand so AYP can meet its goals: help us make some racket about our cause! Word of mouth is The Best tool we have… spread the word far & wide.

            ROCK OVER FAIRBANKS!

Any amount of money we can raise towards these goals will deeply impact the awesomeness of AYP 2013 & the amount we can give back in to the community.However, we’ve got some fabulous perks for your donations: AYP bumper stickers, handwritten thank-you cards, personally crafted pins, 2013 t-shirts & more!
Plus, there's the reward of ceaseless badassery: GLORY!
Other Ways You Can Help
Money’s tight all over & we can dig that fact, but there are plenty of ways to lend a hand so AYP can meet its goals: help us make some racket about our cause! Word of mouth is The Best tool we have… spread the word far & wide.
            ROCK OVER FAIRBANKS!

story:
Artists for Charity

The AFC Children’s Home was created to provide comprehensive (medical, educational, nutritional, and emotional) care for HIV-positive double orphans in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.  

Semira was one of the founding children of the home in 2005, when she was 8 years old. As an HIV+ orphan, she was entirely dependent on an older sibling who could not care for her.  She came to the house malnourished, without medical care, and very much in need of a family and support.  

Like many of the children, Semira blossomed at the house.  She excelled in her education.  She spoke to groups on the challenges of being an HIV+ child in Ethiopia. 

She also took care of the younger children, including a deaf child who she learned sign language to communicate with.  When that child was coming to the United States for a surgery to enable her to hear, Semira accompanied her to help her. 

Upon her graduation from school in Ethiopia, Semira was admitted to St. Francis Xavier University in Nova Scotia, with scholarship but she cannot secure loans because she's not a Canadian citizen.  

Semira aspires to be a doctor to help children like she was not so long ago.  But she needs your help.  

In order to attend school in the fall, we need to raise $4,400 as soon as possible to cover her expenses.  Can you donate today?  

Semira has a bright future ahead of her.  Your contribution will make this dream a possibility.

story:
A Year in Muscat, Oman

Hey, there! I'm Shanaya Stephenson, a high school student from Atlanta, Georgia. Recently however, I became much more than your average high schoool student when I won a U.S. Department of State sponsored scholarship to go on a program known as Kennedy-Lugar Youth Exchange & Study Abroad (K-L YES Abroad). Through this program, I will receive the opportunity to act as a youth ambassador for the next 10 months to Oman, a beautiful Middle Eastern country on the edge of the Arabian Peninsula.

This Isn't Common:

According to this graphic by Connect All Schools, only 1 in 10, 800 US high school students study abroad on a year or semester program, and of those, less than 25% are minority students. In a rapidly globalizing world and economy, a universal mindset is becoming increasingly valuable. The abilities to speak a foreign language, understand another culture, and adapt well in a new environment are quickly becoming standard skills, and without them, many students will lose their ability to compete with foreigners who are doing just that in our future job market.

As a result of noticing this gap in our education, I've decided to start an exchange student resource website geared towards getting U.S. high school students, especially minorities, interested and involved in study abroad exchange programs. It's called The Curly Muscateer, named for where I'll be staying, Muscat, Oman, and my naturally curly hair that makes me stand out! I will be doing videos, writing inspirational articles, giving helpful tips, and uncovering opportunities for my peers!

YES Abroad Visit to Omani Embassy in Washington, D.C.

Impact of The Curly Muscateer

One has to wonder, could the lack of participation in exchange programs come from just not knowing that these opportunities exist? What would happen if someone were to get the message out that there about the wealth of opportunities for their taking? This is where I believe my project comes in.

Study abroad gives students the opportunity to acquire these skills at a young age, and allows them to put their knowledge to use in their daily lives post-exchange. The Curly Muscateer will be a total exchange student resource blog website that will chronicle my experiences as an exchange student in Muscat.

I will use this site as a means to share the benefits of international education with the missed 99%, my own peers. I hope to, in turn, inspire prospective exchange students through this resource, which will help improve these numbers. Using the power of social media and my own skills as writer, photographer, and video blogger, I will make international education COOL.

Where will your donation go?

By donating you will be, in a sense, directly supporting U.S. international education by investing in one of it's products -- me! Your funding will go directly into turning the site into a proper resource & supporting me and my brand while abroad. Here are the ways you'll see your donation be put to use:

  • Research: I hope to fully expand the blog site, and turn it into a big landing pad for exchangers. For example, I currently have a page on The Curly Muscateer blog that lists a few of the popular exchange scholarships. I will add many more opportunities and fellowships that would work for even young adults in college, among other things! In addition, I hope to add helpful articles and tips for the students. Getting this done will take time, energy, and dollars.
  • Advertising campaigns: I want to use this ambitious method as a way of getting the message out there to high school and college age kids who have an interest in furthering their education for the better!
  • Video blogs and Photos: My work on The Curly Muscateer will be highly concentrated on the video blogs and media. I've done some small vlogs already and have had a positive reaction! From experience, it makes the interaction with the viewer highly personal & more relateable. Therefore, it will bring in more prospective students. I will need to get some equipment to use while abroad, including a good quality camera, a tripod, editing software, etc. This is where the bulk of the fundraising money will go.

Can't donate right now?

If you believe in what I'm doing with The Curly Muscateer, but cannot donate at the moment, you can help by sharing this campaign and passing the word on to your friends, or someone that you know CAN donate!

Thanks for taking the time to consider my campaign! Please share and tweet your support on the hashtag #FundTheCurlyMuscateer!

story:
The Yellow Finch Autism Project is a workshop dedicated to serving the autistic community in the metro NY/CT area.

Autism has touched all of our lives in different ways.  One of the huge challenges faced by parents and educators, is giving children with autism the tools they need to express themselves, and communicate with the rest of the world.  Within the education system, there are curriculums, tests, and applied knowledge.  Often times, children on the autistic spectrum are not given many opportunities to participate in spontaneity, interaction, and emotion as enjoyable experiences.  That's where the Yellow Finch Autism Project comes in.

In 2006, Jacqui Russell of the Chicago Children’s Theater and London’s Oily Cart Company developed a multi-sensory installation performance for children with autism. "The Red Kite Project" continues to create new theatrical experiences in the Chicago area. Red Kite also created a framework that incorporates theater games with educational-based learning called "Dramatime". Red Kite Dramatime is a pilot project that places theater professionals and children on the autistic spectrum in a unique performance and discovery production.  

Our primary goal with this project is to bring Red Kite Dramatime to our community and give this experience to children whose development has been affected by autistic spectrum disorders.

To see how these children become involved is something very unique and rewarding.  Parents who are wary of bringing their kids to any kind of social gathering are amazed to see their kids interacting with each other and with the actors onstage.  Children are celebrated in Red Kite shows, and the autism becomes just one of the many things that make them special.  

We are going to continue that vision in our community.

With this money, we are going to bring Jacqui and members of her Red Kite team to New York for an intensive four-day teacher/performer training workshop, culminating with members of our community bringing Dramatime into a classroom of special needs children. Everyone on our staff is volunteering, and the money will be used for travel expenses, training materials and educational fees.  

That final day in the classroom is something that we have been looking forward to, and have been talking about since we first learned of the Red Kite Project over a year ago.

story:
Doula in Training

Aloha my name is Asheeliyah, many of you know me as Shelly. I was born and raised in Moab Utah, my beautiful desert homeland. I am currently setting roots in Maui Hawaii actively participating in and organizing various conscious community gatherings, festivals, and events.  As I align with my highest calling as a healer, I find myself in a very rested, heart resonate space eager to share my natural gifts through bodywork, inspiring song, dance, play and education.  

I'm feeling called to dive deeply into learning and gaining first hand experiences with these sacred birthing practices in honour of the Divine Feminine and the rebalancing of the masculine and feminine energies. A doula works along side with physicians, midwives, nurses and with whomever is chosen to be part of a womans birthing team. Doulas can also help by providing information and support in the pre-natal and postpartum periods. There is growing evidence that labor support is the missing component in maternal and child health care. I'm choosing to maintain these ancient practices of holding ceremony for childbirth, providing our children with a proper welcoming into the world.

The training I am raising money for is through Barabara Essman's Sacred Birthing School. June 10th-July15th 2013.  

http://www.sacredbirthing.com/vision-and-mission/

"Sacred Birthing realigns birth with the Intelligence of Natural Law. By birthing softly, babies remain conscious, and remember that they are beings of love, never losing their conscious connection to their higher nature. Each newborn radiating this coherence transforms its family, community, nation and world.

The program consists of completing a 13 week course of study under an experienced doula and receiving supervision while completing the requirements for certification. Once certified as a doula, I will have opportunities to make home visits and assist with gathering a community of support around a sister and her partner preparing to give birth birth.

I've also been holding the vision and supporting other sisters with the vision of educating not only our youth but eachother of the importance of tracking our cycles with the moon & holding womens cirlces to rekindle the firey feminine. While this awareness is spreading, I will continue to empower my brothers to come together in councel as well.

Holding visions of educating, Inspiriing, and Empowering my community. I am confident that the growth and evolution we experience in our personal lives, ripples out into the collective affecting individuals around the globe. We are one! 

Funding Love Offering

The funding needed to take the course is $1,550. These funds cover the course itself of which is $750, Roundtrip flight Maui-Kauai $300, and final $500 will support basic living expenses for food and living for the month.

Your financial and energetic love offering is so deeply appreciated. Simply to know that we can support eachother when choosing to take a leap of faith. We serve as a safety net for one another, creating a space to hold and nurture with encouragement. Extending my Blessings and Gratitude :) Mahalo

Other Ways You Can Help

Feel free to get the word out to friends or family members you feel may be interesting in contributing.

I would also love to receive your prayers and positive intentions for me on this path of awakening via facebook messages or email shelly.welch88@gmail.com 

To make your offering click on the Indiegogo Share tab!

story:
Who am I?

I am a regular guy in his mid 30’s living in New York City and loving life.  I have a BS in Finance from Northeastern University and I’m on my 12th year in the world of financial services.  I live in New York City; undeniably my soul's home.  I hail from the metropolitan Boston area and I’m the eldest of four.  I’m also fortunate enough to be able to travel frequently, having already visited 38 countries!  As of late I’ve been trying to mix tourism with volunteering; voluntourism if you will.  After my first volunteer trip I knew a sleeping giant was awakened.  Never did I imagine it would impact me as deeply as it has.  Apparently life can take you places you never imagined.  For example, Naserian School and Orphanage in Arusha, Tanzania.

 

What do I want to do?

 After spending only one week living and working at Naserian, I was overwhelmed with amazing, joyous, discoursing and conflicting emotions.  Reconciling all of them was an exhausting exercise.  In short, I was so impacted by the beauty, and need, of all these lovely and amazing children who were so desperate to learn and be heard.  I knew I couldn’t live with myself if I didn’t help.  So, I am.  I want to raise money for the students and orphans at Naserian School and Orphanage.  I want to make a difference, and I personally feel there is no better way than to give directly to an organization like this; providing basic services to orphans and education, the key to all success, to Tanzania’s most needy children.  

 

What will your money provide?

 Everything! 

 Well, not EVERYTHING!  Here are some examples:

  • ·         Materials for building dormitories and more classrooms
  • ·         Beds for children
  • ·         Clothing
  • ·         Books
  • ·         School supplies
  • ·         Salaries for hard-working teachers
  • ·         Food
  • ·         Mosquito nets to prevent malaria
  • ·         Medicine

 

How much do items cost?

  • Beds - $150 each.  Currently, this is the biggest need
  • Labor - $15 pays one worker for a 12 hour day!
  • Electricity for the year - Approximately $400
  • Teacher salary for one month - Approximately $100
  • Food for all orphans for one month - Approximately $100

EVERY LITTLE BIT HELPS!  A donation of $10 goes a long way!!!! 100% of your money will go DIRECTLY to the above items and more.  The only overhead is the fees for this site and Western Union; the way in which money will be transferred.

 

Why am I doing this?

 Because I know it’s possible that a little sacrifice on my (our) end will have an exponential impact on the other end.  But most importantly because the children at Naserian School and Orphanage, and its founder Mary Sinantei, are some of the most beautiful and caring people I’ve ever encountered.  Children that have nothing, including family, couldn’t be more loving and engaged.   Mary left a well-paying job to start this project with her own funds.  She has dedicated her life to educating high-need children and providing shelter to the ones who need it.  Naserian’s survival is dependent on donations from the community and nothing more.

 

How do I know YOUR money is being used properly?

When I was there, my friend Jerry and I donated some money to help complete one of the dorms so the children who lived there no longer slept on the classroom floor.  Within one day of putting our money in their hands, a foreman came, ordered supplies, and supplies started arriving that day.  By the time we’d left all of the necessary supplies were purchased, all of our money was used, and workers came to work 12 hour days to complete their job.  Within weeks, some of the children were able to sleep in a proper dorm.  They’re still on the floor – so part of this initiative is to build them beds.  

 

What will I do for you?

 As the lead of this initiative, I promise to send updates to all that have donated on exactly what your money was used for.  I’ll provide pictures when possible and share E-mails of the joy your kindness has brought to both Mary and the children.  Fortunately, Mary has access to E-mail on days she goes into town and regularly communicates with me.

I thank you for your time and consideration.  Please feel free to reach out to me with any questions at any point.  

 

Now, let’s raise some money and change some lives!!!!!

story:
http://beingsocial.co/waaree/ קישור לתרגום האתר לעברית



  

>>>>WHERE IS IT ? 

See School site on google maps: http://goo.gl/maps/oUKko 

Waaree village, Midegha district, OROMIA STATE.

                          EWB AND WAAREE COMMUNITY
                  ARE UPGRADING THE PRIMERY SCHOOL!

What do we need the money for?

  • Materials that need to be purchased: cement, gravel, sand, plaster and paint... Even water needs to be purchased and transported to the remote village. 

  • We plan on installing windows and doors, and to buy tables and chairs, because sitting on stones is a pain in the ass ;)

  • We intend to install an additional rain water harvesting system, and a solar lightning system. Its all elementary.

  • The community requested MORE CLASSROOMS and an additional school building. Will we get enough funds to build an additional
    building?

  • Tell us about your dreams or ideas for a sustainable project somewhere in africa... Maybe we can make it happen together!

We believe that any child who arrives to school should enjoy the proper learning conditions.

What kind of difference can we make?

  • We can improve the learning conditions of hundreds of students.

  • We can build the 5th-8th grade classrooms to improve the level of education.

  • We can make their school a source of pride

  • We can help the community establish their 
    - Community center 
    - Library
    - Woman evening clases
    - Agricultural center 
    - Engineering and science studies at the school... 

  • Imagine children going to a school that provides them with tools to invent, to create, to reserve their enviroment and to enlage the capacity of their land and sociaty. We can see it happening. Can you?

     

 THE GENERAL IDEA:

>>>Education is a key factor in community and individual development<<<

>>> Empower the rural population of Waaree Village by empowering the local school.<<<

         

 

                                                   A little about us:

EWB is an international organization, active in 50 countries around the globe. We promote empowering of developed communities through an holistic approach, and sustainable low-tech engineering solutions.

The organization is based on autonomist chapters, and each chapter is in charge of its own projects, and needs to find a funding source for its activities.

Our chapter, at Rehovot, Israel, is composed of students, engineers, and other volunteers.

 

New era has arrived:
      students full of passion, engineers and      
            volunteers from different fields gathered 
                  together to form an EWB team in order to
                            to finish the construction the school.

 

FOR TRUE SOUL FARMERS 

AND MORE.... OROMO CULTURE ITEMS:

 


                                     


       

 

 

And that’s all there's to it.  

;)

 

OUR PARTNERS :

 

We Received EXTERNAL Funding OF 
                                $3000 !!! 


                             Thank you
Bronfman Youth Fellowships in Israel !



                             Yey for us!

See School site on google maps: http://goo.gl/maps/oUKko 

Waaree village, Midegha district, OROMIA STATE.

                          EWB AND WAAREE COMMUNITY                   ARE UPGRADING THE PRIMERY SCHOOL!

What do we need the money for?


Materials that need to be purchased: cement, gravel, sand, plaster and paint... Even water needs to be purchased and transported to the remote village. 

We plan on installing windows and doors, and to buy tables and chairs, because sitting on stones is a pain in the ass ;)

We intend to install an additional rain water harvesting system, and a solar lightning system. Its all elementary.

The community requested MORE CLASSROOMS and an additional school building. Will we get enough funds to build an additional building?

All costs are significantly reduced because we don't pay for labor - We are all volunteers!

story:
Most of you know me as the "Green Guy", someone who will tell you to recycle or turn off the lights. But my interest in sustainability lies way beyond educating my peers about sustainability habits. My passion for community service, leadership and sustainability got me involved for various organizations that empower students to become environmental stewards. And, sustainability came very early to my life because I was educated an elite boarding school (Daly College, Indore) and was privileged to learn at attend the University of Illinois, Urbana - Champaign. I realize how lucky I am for getting the best education and thus always tried to use my resources to make a difference in people's life. 

I envision a future where children are educated of the choices they can make; and empower themselves to contribute to an environmentally sustainable future. I want to see all the sustainability orientated visions come together to help make this vision a reality.

As I turn 21, I want to raise $500 to support a non-profit that helps students in one of the most densely populated and economically challenged areas of the US become productive farmers and environmental stewards. 

I shared a stage with Stephen Ritz, teacher at Green Bronx Machine at the Greenbuild International Conference and Expo in Philadelphia last year and listening to his story inspired me to do something about my vision. Stephen believes that students shouldn’t have to leave their community to live, learn and earn in a better one. Moving generations of students into spheres of personal and academic successes they have never imagined while reclaiming and rebuilding the Bronx, his extended student and community family have grown over 25,000 pounds of vegetables in the Bronx while generating extraordinary academic performance. His Bronx classroom features the first indoor edible wall in the New York City Department of Education which routinely generates enough produce to feed 450 students healthy meals and trains the youngest nationally certified workforce in America. His students, traveling from Boston to Rockefeller Center to the Hamptons, earn a living wage en route to graduation. 

This campaign is important for me because I want to help Stephen and his team continue the great work of inspiring students to become a part of the environmental movement. These students learning to grow local foods that helps them become self-sufficient responsible adults and build edible walls and green roofs around the NY region. They are a volunteer based non profit and your money will help in training students, workforce development, infrastructure support (building gardens) and feeding people. 

Donate as low as $10 and help them continue amazing work. I understand if you cannot donate any money but like their facebook page anyway! 

Celebrate my 21st Birthday by donating to a great cause.

story:
Introduction


The statistics show that there are about 86,500 students who graduate from high schools in Gaza and west bank yearly (49,700 students from West Bank and 39,800 students from Gaza Strip). Most of the students only make decisions about their majors in the university based on what they think they know, unfortunately in so many cases their knowledge and experience is not enough to take the right decision. In so many other cases the student depend on other people’s preferences (parent, friend), the more likely it is to be a good choice for them, but not for students. Pre-mature decisions lead to loss of time if the student goes through too many major choices. Pre-mature major decisions can also lead to loss of money due to the extra cost of extra time in college as well as the loss of income while still in college for the extra time. 


Problem statement:

The student’s perspective. Most of them only make decisions based on what they think they know, unfortunately in so many cases their knowledge and experience is not enough to take the right decision. In so many other cases the student depend on other people’s preferences (parent, friend), the more likely it is to be a good choice for them, but not for him. The student should go to other people for ideas and impressions then make up his own mind.

The results of that are the following: 


·  So many students change their major during college.

Between 20% to 40% of all students change their major at least once during college. Students often realize that they want to change their mind because of academic courses, their personality, and/or an internship that helps them understand their real interests.

Changing the major will cost the students a lot of money, time and effort.


·  Complete their study and graduate.

After two or three years in college some students discover that their major won’t led them to the career or life they really want, even though they choose to complete their study because they almost finish their study.

So they may graduate and have a career, but they will do it badly without interest and motivation and that would kill the creativity at work.


Solution:

Our website will provide high school students with some strategies and tools for looking at how they fit best in majors and careers. The project will help them to look at their interests, skill areas, and values. Then compare those to the characteristics of majors and careers in order to find similarities and differences. We’ll try to make them choose their majors by discovering their own interests and talents. This will help them to focus on choosing a specific career area.


Objectives:


Overall Objective

To improve the quality of life of the youth in Gaza Strip and reduce the unemployment, also to make them more comfortable with their work environments.


Specific Objectives

·  To help high school and university students choose a major wisely and not spend unnecessary extra time and money in college,

·  Increase the opportunities of employments for the graduated students by helping them to choose the majors which fit with their interests, talents and abilities,

·  To help students to know what a particular majors mean,

·  Provide students with information about how majors interact with careers,

·  Provide the students with information about what skills they will need after graduation,

·  Improve productivity at work, and

·  Encourage the employees to do their work with more fun and creativity.


Target group

This proposal is for school students in twelfth grade in Gaza Strip (about 86,500 students).


Links

Our website



http://site.iugaza.edu.ps/rshaban/ge/

story:
Chi sono? 

Ciao! Mi chiamo Marco,
tra pochi giorni inizierò un viaggio in bicicletta da Londra a Mariano Comense, ben 1.200 km.

Mi sono laureato in Antropologia a Londra nel 2013 e sto organizzando un rientro a casa in grande stile per promuovere e raccogliere fondi per il progetto Kilifi Social Enterprise con cui ho collaborato in Kenya nell'agosto 2012 e Gennaio 2013.
Social Enterprise è un tipo di impresa che opera con una precisa "missione sociale", in questo caso l'educazione:
L'educazione nei paesi in via di sviluppo è spesso l'unica via d'uscita dalla povertà estrema e un potentissimo motore di sviluppo personale. Nelle parole di Mandela:

"È grazie all'educazione che la figlia di un contadino può diventare medico, il figlio di un minatore il capo miniera o un bambino nato in una famiglia povera il presidente di una grande nazione."

Contribuendo al progetto potrai rendere il sogno di tanti bambini una concreta realtà. 

Tu puoi scegliere dove destinare la tua donazione!

-L'avvio di una piccola impresa di olio di cocco extravergine dove il 40% dei profitti andranno a sostenere l'educazione nella provincia di Kilifi, Kenya. [Modello Sostenibile di Social Enterprise, Impatto a lungo termine]

-L'acquisto di materiale scolastico per le scuole elementari e medie della provincia di Kilifi. [Impatto diretto]


Cosa serve e come puoi aiutare:

Risolvere i problemi del mondo è complicato, bisogna pensare in grande ma agire nel piccolo.  Il mio obiettivo è di raggiungere 1.200Euro, simbolicamente un Euro per ogni Chilometro percorso.
A lato potrai scegliere TU quanto donare e come i tuoi soldi verranno usati. Puoi scegliere se acquistare direttamente un libro per uno studente o se sponsorizzare il progetto a lungo termine di 'social enterprise'.


L'impatto

Donare a un organizzazione di beneficenza può cambiare molte vite, ma a volte non si ha pieno controllo sulla donazione e i soldi vengono usati per pagare costose campagne pubblicitarie o si perdono nella burocrazia. 

Sponsorizzare un piccolo progetto come questo ha diversi vantaggi.

-La tua donazione verrà usata direttamente da me per l'acquisto di libri in Kenya o per sostenere le iniziative di economia sostenibile di Kilifi Social Enterprise.

-Il progetto è mirato verso i figli del ceto sociale più povero: contadini e braccianti che producono e raccolgono cocco e derivati.

-Volete sapere se la vostra donazione è andata a buon fine? Sapete a chi chiedere!

-Durante la ricerca per la mia tesi, a Gennaio 2013, abbiamo creato rapporti di fiducia reciproca con 50 famiglie la cui unica fonte di guadagno deriva dalle piantagioni di cocco. Queste persone, il cui reddito giornaliero è inferiore a 1 Euro, saranno i primi beneficiari dei nostri servizi e delle vostre donazioni. 



Successi passati


Con l'aiuto dei lettori del mio blog abbiamo ristrutturato la casa di una famiglia che mi ha ospitato, donato libri alla Mkombe Accademy e messo le fondamenta per una nuova abitazione in mattoni. 


PRIMA

Dopo



30 Libri per la scuola di Mkombe
Fondamenta



Rischi, Difficoltà e come affrontarli:

Fare Business in Africa può risultare complicato per via dell'economia a stampo informale e lunghe pratiche burocratiche. Per queste ragioni il continente non è mai riuscito ad attrarre investimenti esteri sufficienti a creare un economia stabile. 

Kilifi Social Enterprise vuole trasformare questi ostacoli in opportunità e testare un modello economico più flessibile e adatto al contesto. 

La mia esperienza di ricerca antropologica in Kenya si è rivelata indispensabile per concepire il progetto così come il rapporto di fiducia con il mio collaboratore Keniota, Thomas, e la sua conoscenza della legislatura locale.



Se non puoi fare una donazione puoi comunque aiutare!


Condividi la campagna con i tuoi amici, e chiedi a loro di fare lo stesso!

Grazie!

story:
The Earth Experience Vision

Our vision is nothing less than building a museum which is both beautiful  architecturally, with towering glass and steel, and transformational. The minute you arrive, we want you to be taken back in time to the age when mysterious creatures of massive size walked the earth. Once you walk inside, you will go on an exciting journey through time using nature’s creativity and man’s creativity to guide you.

But the museum will be more than just dinosaur skeletons. The museum will showcase the interaction of humans and nature, as well as educating about the fundamental elements, the building blocks of the earth. The collection of stone and gemstones come from around the world, as well as the rich soil right here in Middle Tennessee.

Another dream is to host a working paleo-lab inside the museum, where experts can clean and study gems and bones, and where we can teach the community about the importance of studying the history of the earth.

While our vision is massive, our feet are grounded. We know that such an endeavor takes time and money. As we seek funding to reach our ambitious monetary goal, we continue to build an enviable collection of exhibits sure to be coveted by the world’s most astute aficionados.

Building a Museum - a Mammoth Task

A lot of people want to know what it takes to create a museum. Well, of course the budget of any major museum is deep and complex. A building alone runs in the hundreds of millions of dollars.  But a great building isn’t what people come to see. We thought you’d like to see the prices of some of our dream collections:

Casts list (all are full skeletons except the mastodon)

  • Mastodon skull $3,000
  • 13ft “pterodactyl” $5,000
  • Sabertooth cat $8,000
  • Dimetrodon $10,000
  • Velociraptor & Protoceratops fighting $10,000
  • Struthiomimus $10,000
  • Nodosaur 11′ $20,000
  • Tanji(stegosaurus) $30,000
  • Ankylosaurus 15′ $40,000
  • Appalachiosaurus $60,000
  • Triceratops $70,000
  • T-rex $80,000
story_txt:
The Earth Experience Vision
Our vision is nothing less than building a museum which is both 
beautiful  architecturally, with towering glass and steel, and 
transformational. The minute you arrive, we want you to be taken back in
 time to the age when mysterious creatures of massive size walked the 
earth. Once you walk inside, you will go on an exciting journey through 
time using nature’s creativity and man’s creativity to guide you.
 But the museum will be more than just dinosaur skeletons. The museum
 will showcase the interaction of humans and nature, as well as 
educating about the fundamental elements, the building blocks of the 
earth. The collection of stone and gemstones come from around the world,
 as well as the rich soil right here in Middle Tennessee.
Another dream is to host a working paleo-lab inside the museum, where
 experts can clean and study gems and bones, and where we can teach the 
community about the importance of studying the history of the earth.
While our vision is massive, our feet are grounded. We know that such
 an endeavor takes time and money. As we seek funding to reach our 
ambitious monetary goal, we continue to build an enviable collection of 
exhibits sure to be coveted by the world’s most astute aficionados.
Building a Museum - a Mammoth Task 

A lot of people want to know what it takes to create a museum. 
Well, of course the budget of any major museum is deep and complex. A 
building alone runs in the hundreds of millions of dollars.  But a great
 building isn’t what people come to see. We thought you’d like to see 
the prices of some of our dream collections:
Casts list (all are full skeletons except the mastodon)

Mastodon skull $3,000
13ft “pterodactyl” $5,000
Sabertooth cat $8,000
Dimetrodon $10,000
Velociraptor & Protoceratops fighting $10,000
Struthiomimus $10,000
Nodosaur 11′ $20,000
Tanji(stegosaurus) $30,000
Ankylosaurus 15′ $40,000
Appalachiosaurus $60,000
Triceratops $70,000
T-rex $80,000

story:
Nous sommes deux jeunes étudiantes en soins infirmiers, nous avons pour projet de partir effectuer l'un de nos stage à Madagascar, stage qui se déroulera du 1er février au 4 mars 2016  :
  • Sur cette photo, il y a à droite Anaïs (20 ans) et à gauche Margaux (20 ans), étant toutes les deux en école d'infirmière à Lyon en 2ème année.
  • Ce projet nous tient à cœur car nous souhaitons confronter les valeurs de notre métier dans un pays étranger, et les mettre à profit pour apporter du soutien, de la joie et une aide à la population Malgache. Nous partons dans un dispensaire situé au cœur de la capitale (Antananarivo) qui permet à la fois la scolarisation des enfants dans le besoin, et l'accès aux soins pour toutes les personnes du quartier.
  • Ce stage fait partie de notre cursus scolaire, il nous permettra alors de valider les compétences nécessaires à l'obtention du diplôme d'état, mais également de nous enrichir personnellement et professionnellement.  Ce sont l'amour de l'humanité et l'altruisme qui nous poussent à conduire ce projet, pour être auprès de la population Malgache.



VOS DONS ET NOS REMERCIEMENTS

  • Ce beau projet ne se réalisera malheureusement pas sans votre aide, car malgré tout, les billets d'avions, le logement sur place, les vaccins et les préventions médicales ont un coût non négligeables. C'est ainsi que l'argent que nous récolterons grâce à vos dons nous permettra de financer notre hébergement au sein d'un centre social (environ 600 euros pour 2) mais également les vaccins, c'est à dire Hépatite A, Fièvre Typhoïde et contre la rage, ainsi qu'un traitement pour lutter contre le paludisme, pathologie  très présente à Madagascar. Il est également nécessaire de prendre des précautions pour traiter l'eau, car la bas plus de 50 % de la population n'a pas accès à l'eau potable.
  • Pour vous remercier de vos dons, nous nous engageons en contrepartie à vous faire profiter de tout un tas de souvenirs, comme par exemple cartes postales, objets de souvenirs, partage de nos photos etc...
  • Petit guide sur Madagascar :  Madagascar est une île (5ème plus grande au monde) de 22 millions d'habitants, qui n'ont pas de couverture sociale, dont le salaire moyen est de 30 euros par mois. Cela ne leur permet donc pas l'accès aux soins, et c'est ainsi que l'on retrouve à Madagascar un nombre important de pathologies et de problèmes sanitaires. Le taux de mortalité infantile est de 44 décès pour 1000 naissances, le paludisme, les infections sexuellement transmissibles, le choléra sont des maladies extrêmement répandues.


Si vous ne pouvez pas nous aider ...

Nous comprenons si vous ne pouvez pas nous aider à financer ce projet, cependant nous vous serions reconnaissantes si vous pensiez à le partager avec le plus de personnes possible afin d'atteindre notre objectif.

Nous sommes deux jeunes étudiantes en soins infirmiers, nous avons pour projet de partir effectuer l'un de nos stage à Madagascar, stage qui se déroulera du 1er février au 4 mars 2016  :

Sur cette photo, il y a à droite Anaïs (20 ans) et à gauche Margaux (20 ans), étant toutes les deux en école d'infirmière à Lyon en 2ème année.

Ce projet nous tient à cœur car nous souhaitons confronter les valeurs de notre métier dans un pays étranger, et les mettre à profit pour apporter du soutien, de la joie et une aide à la population Malgache. Nous partons dans un dispensaire situé au cœur de la capitale (Antananarivo) qui permet à la fois la scolarisation des enfants dans le besoin, et l'accès aux soins pour toutes les personnes du quartier. 

Ce stage fait partie de notre cursus scolaire, il nous permettra alors de valider les compétences nécessaires à l'obtention du diplôme d'état, mais également de nous enrichir personnellement et professionnellement.  Ce sont l'amour de l'humanité et l'altruisme qui nous poussent à conduire ce projet, pour être auprès de la population Malgache.





VOS DONS ET NOS REMERCIEMENTS


Ce beau projet ne se réalisera malheureusement pas sans votre aide, car malgré tout, les billets d'avions, le logement sur place, les vaccins et les préventions médicales ont un coût non négligeables. C'est ainsi que l'argent que nous récolterons grâce à vos dons nous permettra de financer notre hébergement au sein d'un centre social (environ 600 euros pour 2) mais également les vaccins, c'est à dire Hépatite A, Fièvre Typhoïde et contre la rage, ainsi qu'un traitement pour lutter contre le paludisme, pathologie  très présente à Madagascar. Il est également nécessaire de prendre des précautions pour traiter l'eau, car la bas plus de 50 % de la population n'a pas accès à l'eau potable.

Pour vous remercier de vos dons, nous nous engageons en contrepartie à vous faire profiter de tout un tas de souvenirs, comme par exemple cartes postales, objets de souvenirs, partage de nos photos etc...

Petit guide sur Madagascar :  Madagascar est une île (5ème plus grande au monde) de 22 millions d'habitants, qui n'ont pas de couverture sociale, dont le salaire moyen est de 30 euros par mois. Cela ne leur permet donc pas l'accès aux soins, et c'est ainsi que l'on retrouve à Madagascar un nombre important de pathologies et de problèmes sanitaires. Le taux de mortalité infantile est de 44 décès pour 1000 naissances, le paludisme, les infections sexuellement transmissibles, le choléra sont des maladies extrêmement répandues. 




Si vous ne pouvez pas nous aider ... 
Nous comprenons si vous ne pouvez pas nous aider à financer ce projet, cependant nous vous serions reconnaissantes si vous pensiez à le partager avec le plus de personnes possible afin d'atteindre notre objectif.

story:
Uplift is a 501(c)3 nonprofit dedicated to combatting online sexual violence through education and advocacy. We work to ensure that these flourishing communities are safe for the millions of people who connect through them. We believe that the internet can be an incredible tool for good; that everyone has the right to feel free from sexual harassment; and that everyone should have the freedom to use the Internet safely.

Since we started as a task force, Uplift has worked tirelessly to support the communities that are so dear to us.

  • We created the Safer Community Pledge, designed to give people simple and concrete actions to support survivors and respect the boundaries of others. Since September 2014, this pledge was shared over 9,000 times, was discussed in videos gaining over 97,000 views, and was signed in-person at conventions by over 1,000 people.

  • We created an educational Youtube series called Engage by Uplift, which has been viewed almost 70,000 times. The series has over twenty videos covering everything from consent to trolling.

  • We had strong presences at Geekycon and Vidcon this past summer, distributing resources, leading panels and workshops, and hosting a roundtable to get direct feedback from the community on how we should address sexual violence online.

The internet is a huge part of our culture, and the size, number, and importance of online networks only continues to grow. It is crucial that these spaces are given proper attention within the sexual violence prevention field. Uplift is creating a framework for addressing online sexual violence that empowers both online communities and sexual violence organizations.

Uplift’s ultimate goal is to educate on- and off-line communities about online sexual violence, advocate for survivors, and foster safer online spaces for all. We've come a long way from the tiny task force we were back in March 2014, and with your help we will go so much further.

  • We will establish a chapters program to take our mission to a local level. While in-person chapters may seem odd given the topic of our work, they serve the purpose of allowing young people who make connections online to translate their support systems into physical spaces. Chapters will also be able to advocate in their local, physical communities -- increasing visibility for the issue, supporting survivors, and encouraging bystander intervention.

  • We will increase our presence at conventions by providing more resources for con-goers. Since conventions are spaces in which online acquaintances and friends physically meet, a presence in these spaces is essential. Our past experiences at fan Vidcon and Geekycon have made it clear that having a booth -- a physical, safe space to go when encountering a coercive or uncomfortable situation -- is vital for attendees to feel safe. Many reports of harassment and abuse at conventions have been made directly to us. This year, we hope to be able to attend more conventions, provide more written resources, and lead more programming. These programs will include everything from how to create a safe space to safe online leadership and how to translate online communities to IRL spaces. It’s only through education that we can ensure long-term, grassroots, sustainable change.

  • We will train convention staff and volunteers in bystander intervention strategies to prevent, recognize, and defuse coercive situations. Since the staff members leading these conventions are usually community members as well, staff training not only ensures that convention staff are able to intervene and prevent situations at their events; it also increases awareness of the issue among community members who can take those skills and implement them in their day-to-day lives.

  • We will partner with platforms to institute change from a structural level. We hope to work directly with platforms like YouTube, Vine, Twitter, and Tumblr to ensure that their structure is elevating a community, rather than giving unlimited power to a few individuals.

Our plans are ambitious; we’re the first to recognize that. In order to give each of these projects the attention it deserves, Uplift needs to begin paying its senior staffers.

A portion of the funds would be allocated for travel, stipends for senior staff, and stipends for key volunteers to give us the presence at conventions and organizations we need to accomplish our goals. The funds would also give us the ability to have dedicated graphic artists, coordinators, and web developers to create high quality products that can be updated over time - giving us the foundation we need to grow as a nonprofit and continue to achieve our goals. These three steps would come together to create a coordinated prevention strategy that would enable us to bolster our mission and ensure that online communities are safe for all.

10% of the budget will go towards printing and supplies

26% of the budget will go towards travel for conventions

32% of the budget will go to direct programming and outreach

33% of the budget will go to funding staff members

 


SENIOR STAFF: Grace Miller (Operations Director), Jennifer Dorsey (Communications Director), Sahitya Raja (Co-Executive Director), Katie Twyman (Co-Executive Director)

Each of our staff members and volunteers has a strong background in the online communities that we serve. Online communities are our homes, and we’re intensely dedicated to them. Many of our staff also have a background in sexual violence prevention. Our intimate understanding of both online communities and sexual violence prevention makes us uniquely capable of creating resources and programs serving our mission.

Q: I live outside of the United States? Can I still buy a perk?

A: Yes! We’re able to ship internationally, though we do have a couple details particular to international donors. First, we ask that you add $10-15 to your donation to cover the cost of international shipping. Also, you'll need to use a credit card, not a bank card or debit card. Having trouble donating or have additional questions? Feel free to email us at indiegogo@uplifttogether.org to get things sorted out.

Q: When will I receive my perk?

A: All perks, even the digital ones, will not be shipped until after the campaign has ended. We’ve added an estimated delivery date for each perk type to give you a better idea of what to expect. You can see the estimated date underneath the perk description on the right. If there are any delays or complications in perk shipment, we’ll send out an update to let you know.

Q: How do I get you my name, phone number, or any other info specific to the perk I purchased?

A: You’ll get an email from us after the campaign has closed to collect any additional info we need from you. Please add indiegogo@uplifttogether.org to your address book to make sure that this email doesn’t end up in your spam!

Q: What percentage of my donation will go to Uplift?

A: Part of your donation will go towards perk shipping, Indiegogo fees, and merchant (credit card) fees. The rest goes directly to Uplift! For more information on how your donation will be used, check our our financial breakdown.

Got more questions? Email indiegogo@uplifttogether.org and we'll help you out!

story:
CoVort will be the newest coworking space in Bangor focused on serving entrepreneurs, professional service providers, and digital nomads, OPENING IN NOVEMBER!   We chose to locate CoVort at 49 Main St., in downtown Bangor because of its proximity to restaurants, pubs and shopping and energetic.   We will leverage our open concept space to create a fun, friendly community where "CoVorters" work, learn and socialize. We will plan events to foster community, contribute to the life of the space, and attract new members, such as lunch and learn sessions (monthly),happy hours (quarterly).   CoVort will be run by Lisa Liberatore and Jason Harkins.   Lisa Liberatore will work full time in the space as the Community Coordinator.  Jason Harkins will work as the Executive in Residence, providing business mentoring to members including goal setting, business development, customer discovery and growth strategies.

Features within the space will include: a large conference room that will hold 8-10 people, phone booths and a small collaboration room.  The rest of the space will be open and have tables, 4 dedicated desks and a living room style seating areas to encourage random collisions. Our "CoVorters" will be motivated as they work in a variety of flexible environments ranging from living room style seating to traditional desks to small collaboration centers.

Additional amenities that will be featured in our space include:

24/7 keyless access

Wicked fast internet (20/20)

Black and white printing, scanner, fax

Lots and lots of power plugs

Cell phone charging towers

Mailboxes

Video and Teleconferencing equipment

Kitchenette

Free GOOD coffee and tea

We offer a wide range of options to our "CoVorters" including: day, week and month commitments. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5,000 to support our marketing and community outreach.  We are fortunate to have the generous support of local corporate sponsors to help make our dream a reality including Bangor Savings Bank.

Perks include awesome laptop stickers, sweet t-shirts, recognition on our "Wall of Founding CoVorters" to be displayed in the space, day passes, invite to member- only happy hours, our super fun VIP launch party and a chance to grab a local microbrew downtown Bangor and talk business with Lisa and Jason!

Be Part of the Awesomeness!

Please help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
