story:
Thanks to People Like You, We Reached Our Goal!!! Now what?

We have enough now to fund at least 7 baskets (we had another $100 contribution outside of IndieGoGo). That is fantastic! We are so appreciative of the support.
So, the question is what we're going to do now. We are increasing our goal to an even $1,000--which will guarantee that AT LEAST 10 families will receive the basket during their time of need.
If you're still reading this, we want you to know that every penny will go towards our goal, and we'll make sure it gets to the right people.
We will be doing another push on Facebook shortly--but we encourage you to help out if you're able to do so.
Thank you so much for your support!

What is Project: Welcome Wagon?

We're excited to tell you about something that we just started this week—and although we’re biased…it is very, very cool.

We’re giving, “Welcome Baskets,” to parents and family that have had the blessing (although they might not know it yet) of having a child—or receiving a diagnosis before birth—of Down Syndrome. We’ll also be ready to give the family help, guidance, and encouragement during this extremely difficult time. We’ll do that if the family wishes—but if they don’t, we’ll honor their wishes, too. They’ll just get the basket.

Many of you know that Laura and I have a beautiful, perfect, soon to be 4 YEARS OLD boy, that just happens to have Down Syndrome. Well, maybe you do know this—or maybe you don’t—but the days after he was born, the uncertainty, the grief, and sadness over his diagnosis were some of the darkest moments of our life. Honestly, if you know Alec and our life now, you know that they needn’t have been…but they were. It was so tough to handle and cope with those emotions. Just thinking about them now, several years and thousands of happy memories removed from them—I still get choked up and very emotional. I’m thinking it’s a feeling that only people that have been in a similar situation understand.

…And that’s who we’re trying to help. Project Welcome Wagon is the brainchild of Ashley Gradel Bailey, who has a perfect little man named Anthony--who also has an extra chromosome. She approached me about making this a reality, and we’re going to do it!

We’re still prototyping and brainstorming the basket, but we’re going to have some baby clothes—to include a Down Syndrome “Am I Rocking This Extra Chromosome or What?!” onesie, diapers, the book “Babies With Down Syndrome: A New Parents’ Guide,” a list of resources and things we wish we would’ve known, and maybe most importantly…letters from us (and eventually our kiddos with DS) welcoming them to the “club,” and offering our support. 

The idea is that doctors at our local hospitals will put out the “Bat Signal,” for us when they have a precious baby with DS that arrives on the scene. We’ll be ready to visit, if allowed, and give the basket, and even let them see our little guys, and how freaking sweet and cute they are! You see, the doctors don’t always give a real accurate idea of how wonderful life can be with these Angels on Earth. It’s a time of sorrow when it CAN be a more joyous occasion. Wow, we just wish we knew THEN what we know NOW!

That’s what we we’re doing with this. 

What We Need & What You Get

IF you feel so inclined, give a little bit to make this a reality. Even a cool $10 will help. We’re aiming for a budget of about $100 per basket, and EVERY CENT of that will go to these new families. Our $500 request will see to it that at least five families get a visit from the Welcome Wagon and a basket.

If you don’t do that, we’ll still love you—but we certainly appreciate and are humbled by the help we do receive.

As far as what's in it for you...well, honestly, it's a good feeling of helping these families through a difficult time if the baby is born without them knowing about the diagnosis.

BUT--here's one of the biggest things we're trying to do: We're going to talk to families that get a prenatal diagnosis of Down Syndrome, and let them know how wonderful life can be with these beautiful children. Right now, upwards of 90% of these precious souls are killed in the womb after a DS diagnosis. We think a lot of this is due to bad and outdated information they get from otherwise well-meaning doctors. We're going to counter that and let them know how life REALLY is with these blessings.

We think that the $100 (or so) basket and visit from us can go a long way towards saving lives.

Another Way You Can Help

We appreciate and are humbled that you're reading this far into our little campaign. Even if you're not able to contribute with a donation--or even if you do--can we ask a favor? 
Use the "Share" tools for our campaign, to let more folks know about what we're doing.
It is appreciated more than you know!
Thank you for your time.
Ashley Bailey Gradel and Chip Franks
(and Awesome Anthony and The Amazing Alec)
story_txt:
Thanks to People Like You, We Reached Our Goal!!! Now what?
We have enough now to fund at least 7 baskets (we had another $100 contribution outside of IndieGoGo). That is fantastic! We are so appreciative of the support.
So, the question is what we're going to do now. We are increasing our goal to an even $1,000--which will guarantee that AT LEAST 10 families will receive the basket during their time of need.
If you're still reading this, we want you to know that every penny will go towards our goal, and we'll make sure it gets to the right people.
We will be doing another push on Facebook shortly--but we encourage you to help out if you're able to do so.
Thank you so much for your support!
What is Project: Welcome Wagon?

We're excited to tell you about something that we just started this week—and although we’re biased…it is very, very cool.

We’re giving, “Welcome Baskets,” to parents and family that have had the blessing (although they might not know it yet) of having a child—or receiving a diagnosis before birth—of Down Syndrome. We’ll also be ready to give the family help, guidance, and encouragement during this extremely difficult time. We’ll do that if the family wishes—but if they don’t, we’ll honor their wishes, too. They’ll just get the basket.
Many of you know that Laura and I have a beautiful, perfect, soon to be 4 YEARS OLD boy, that just happens to have Down Syndrome. Well, maybe you do know this—or maybe you don’t—but the days after he was born, the uncertainty, the grief, and sadness over his diagnosis were some of the darkest moments of our life. Honestly, if you know Alec and our life now, you know that they needn’t have been…but they were. It was so tough to handle and cope with those emotions. Just thinking about them now, several years and thousands of happy memories removed from them—I still get choked up and very emotional. I’m thinking it’s a feeling that only people that have been in a similar situation understand.

…And that’s who we’re trying to help. Project Welcome Wagon is the brainchild of Ashley Gradel Bailey, who has a perfect little man named Anthony--who also has an extra chromosome. She approached me about making this a reality, and we’re going to do it!
We’re still prototyping and brainstorming the basket, but we’re going to have some baby clothes—to include a Down Syndrome “Am I Rocking This Extra Chromosome or What?!” onesie, diapers, the book “Babies With Down Syndrome: A New Parents’ Guide,” a list of resources and things we wish we would’ve known, and maybe most importantly…letters from us (and eventually our kiddos with DS) welcoming them to the “club,” and offering our support. 
The idea is that doctors at our local hospitals will put out the “Bat Signal,” for us when they have a precious baby with DS that arrives on the scene. We’ll be ready to visit, if allowed, and give the basket, and even let them see our little guys, and how freaking sweet and cute they are! You see, the doctors don’t always give a real accurate idea of how wonderful life can be with these Angels on Earth. It’s a time of sorrow when it CAN be a more joyous occasion. Wow, we just wish we knew THEN what we know NOW!
That’s what we we’re doing with this. 


What We Need & What You Get

IF you feel so inclined, give a little bit to make this a reality. Even a cool $10 will help. We’re aiming for a budget of about $100 per basket, and EVERY CENT of that will go to these new families. Our $500 request will see to it that at least five families get a visit from the Welcome Wagon and a basket.
If you don’t do that, we’ll still love you—but we certainly appreciate and are humbled by the help we do receive.
As far as what's in it for you...well, honestly, it's a good feeling of helping these families through a difficult time if the baby is born without them knowing about the diagnosis.
BUT--here's one of the biggest things we're trying to do: We're going to talk to families that get a prenatal diagnosis of Down Syndrome, and let them know how wonderful life can be with these beautiful children. Right now, upwards of 90% of these precious souls are killed in the womb after a DS diagnosis. We think a lot of this is due to bad and outdated information they get from otherwise well-meaning doctors. We're going to counter that and let them know how life REALLY is with these blessings.
We think that the $100 (or so) basket and visit from us can go a long way towards saving lives.

  Another Way You Can Help
We appreciate and are humbled that you're reading this far into our little campaign. Even if you're not able to contribute with a donation--or even if you do--can we ask a favor? 
Use the "Share" tools for our campaign, to let more folks know about what we're doing.
It is appreciated more than you know!
Thank you for your time.
Ashley Bailey Gradel and Chip Franks
(and Awesome Anthony and The Amazing Alec)

story:
HISTORY

The summer camps have taken place every year since 1995. They were
initially organised by the University of Edinburgh Faculty of Music in
collaboration with the charity War Child, the Apeiron d'Arte young
people's collective in Mostar and NGOs such as the Edinburgh-based
Firefly. More recently collaborators have included Opera Circus UK,
World Child, Prishtina, Kosovo and Ulysses Theatre, Croatia. For this
year's camp the principal collaborators will be Los Rosales Centre for
Children with Special Needs, Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), the
Youth Theatre Srebrenica, BiH, the Municipality of Srebrenica, BiH,
the Centre for Children with Special Needs Pula, Croatia, Ulysses
Theatre, the M.A.R.E Centre Rovinj, Croatia, the University of
Edinburgh, Scotland UK and the University of Rijeka.

OBJECTIVES

The camps were originally designed to complement year-round
therapeutic work with children who were victims of the conflicts in
the Balkan region during the 1990s. Although the camps still involve
young people who have suffered from trauma, in particular among our
guests from Mostar, the principal focus of the work has shifted to
more general issues of special education and social and cultural
development in the region of former Yugoslavia.

During the camps we hold daily creative workshops, usually working in
groups - where the children compose, script, produce and perform an
original piece of music theatre - and there are social gatherings,
sing-songs, sports and swimming, all organised in a "light touch"
timetable. The objectives of the work are to help the children enhance
their personal creativity, self-confidence, social awareness,
communication skills, expressivity, emotional intelligence, cognitive
skills, physical mobility, fine and gross motor skills, trust and joy.

For the volunteers there is the opportunity to learn and to share
experiences. This year there will be representatives of projects in
Palestine, Syria-Jordan, West Africa, India and initiatives throughout
the Balkan region and South East Europe.

For volunteers with little or no experience, the camps are a "soft
landing" in this area of work. At every camp there is a majority of
experienced volunteers who are able to carry responsibilities for
others if necessary, and a very favourable volunteer to guest ratio.

Costs:
£150 per guest from Mostar 'Los Rosales' special school (x30)
£100 per volunteer/participant from Srebrenica (x8)
£300 props for performances
£200 bus driver accommodation and fee

Already raised by donations:
£1000 anonymous donor
£1000 Ashfield Trust

story:
E-Cubed Academy E-Cubed Academy, a public high school located in Providence has launched the first high school chapter of the NAACP in the entire state of Rhode Island. E-Cubed Academy students are passionate about the NAACP’s mission of social justice for all. Living as young black and brown people in Providence, RI they are faced with a multitude of issues plaguing their communities, school, and family. As youth, they believe that they have the potential to be the change that we wish to see in their communities. The majority of students at E-Cubed are Black and Latino students receiving free or federally reduced lunch. Particularly in the days following the events in Ferguson and the Grand Jury’s decision it is pertinent that youth are taking action to implement change within their communities. Through the NAACP E-Cubed students have taken it upon themselves to to help educate their peers as well as create change in the systems that continually allow racism to operate. Our mission as an NAACP chapter is to raise consciousness and awareness in our communities in order to make them a safer and more just place to reside.

On April 15th at 3pm we will be holding a panel of community members and students to discuss the current state of racial injustice following the events in Ferguson and what that means for the E-Cubed and Providence Community. Through these events students hope to raise awareness as well as consciousness for their peers to see how these events are relevant for them and to take action to be the type of change they wish to see. Following the community panel we are looking for food and raffle donations and the community will come together over food to break bread and share their own stories. We need money to make this pertinent community conversation happen! Please support us in being the future change makers of Rhode Island!

story:
Ebola has killed over 10,000 people in Africa according to the World Health Organization. 

We will create a list of treatments for the Ebola virus infection in Africa. We will help you to discover the science of medicine behind those treatments, using the medical literature, and other sources, with our new health information technology tools.

We DO NOT CLAIM to cure, treat, or prevent Ebola or any other disease. We are an educational system to teach you how figure out the science of medicine behind treatments, which should be the starting point for shared decision-making for all diseases.

We think we may have already found something very important in the medical literature about treating Ebola in Africa. It SHOULD be explored further because so many people have died from Ebola.

We will help you understand how new technology can help rate the science behind treatments using evidence-based medicine guidelines. Imagine that you have Ebola and that you could have 20 different treatments when you consider all of Western Medicine, Eastern Medicine, herbal therapies, and all alternative medical practices. All patients desperately need to know the "science of medicine" behind treatments. So, why hasn't this been done before?

The answer is because until now, no one has figured out how to do it. The math is complex. On average, one diagnosis may have 10 treatments. Each of those treatments may have 10 vital statistics. Each of those statistics may come from 10 different references. Each of those references may have 10 variables. That's 10×10×10×10 or 10,000 pieces of information that must be processed.

Remember the early days of the computer when only those who could do machine language programming could use a computer? We have solved this problem for the science of medicine by placing a Graphical User Interface over the clinical decision-making process, and by making it so visual that not only doctors and nurses, but patients, and everyone else around the world can do it. We have already done this on a desktop computer but are working to move these tools to the web and to mobile devices.

We want to make our tools available to everyone on the web and on mobile, because being able to study the science behind treatments, not only for Ebola, but all diseases, is potentially of life and death importance to some of your friends, family, and acquaintances. The science is the starting point to figuring out treatments via shared decision-making with your healthcare professional.

The Patient-Centered Outcomes Research (PCORI) team says, “Every day, patients and their caregivers are faced with crucial health care decisions while lacking key information that they need.” PCORI also says that we need to translate “…existing scientific research into accessible and useable formats…”

We have solved these problems. We are creating tangible educational products: a diagnosis search tool, a treatment list tool, an organizer tool, and a tool to help you rate the science of medicine. Eventually, when the website and mobile are done, we will allow you to use the tools so that you can study the literature and adjust the diagnoses and ratings of the science to your own educational needs. This is the only way we can ever have "personalized medicine" and "shared decision-making."

We are building transformative technology. Patients are the players in healthcare with the greatest needs. We want to help them with "treatment transparency." The first step is understanding the science in the background, which is mostly hidden from view now. We want to do this for Ebola, and then once successful for Ebola, for other diseases as well.

As we move forward, we will need money for better videos (sorry, we don't have the budget for CUTE ANIMATED VIDEOS yet), for website development, and for other expenses. We have spent a lot of money, time, and effort using our own resources and are hoping for a bit of help from other people. We can start looking at one disease at a time, build treatment lists, and perfect the tools to rate the science behind those treatments. As we improve the tools, we can move on to breast cancer, prostate cancer, colon cancer, the common cold, the flu, and other diseases.

DISCLAIMER: We we help you to review the medical literature and quantify the science of medicine behind treatments. You cannot use this information to treat yourself or others. We make no claims about accuracy; we claim ZERO ACCURACY. We are an educational exercise only. You must see your own licensed medical professional for treatment. We are an educational exercise, not medical guidelines. We are looking at the past medical literature; we cannot predict how treatments will work for you or anyone else going forward into the future. Choosing a treatment also involves clinical experience, making the right diagnosis, and knowing all about someone after a medical history, physical examination, and testing. We never know any of these things. SO YOU MUST SEE your own physician or other qualified medical practitioner to help you choose a treatment or treatments.

story:
March 4, 2016 Update: We’re increasing our goal to $7,500 to provide even more books!

We hit our campaign goal more quickly than we imagined possible—but we’re not stopping here. We’ve set a stretch goal of $7,500 so that we can provide more books for the students of Cuzco.

We need you to help us reach our stretch goal. Here’s how you can help:

  • Consider donating to this campaign ($10 = 1 book)
  • Share this campaign with your networks using the share links on the left side of the campaign page. 

We send our deepest thanks to all who have stepped up to support our efforts, and we hope many more will join with us.

Together, we can bring the world to our students.


Books for the Students of Cuzco

Libros para Estudiantes de Cuzco

A book can change a child. A library of books can change a whole community. We aim to fill the bookshelves of village schools in the Cuzco region of Peru's Sacred Valley of the Incas.

We are the NEA Foundation, a public charity with a unique strength drawn from the American educators who we support. Our mission is to ensure that educators are equipped with the knowledge and skills they need to help students succeed in a global society. The year-long Global Learning Fellowship is part of that mission. It provides outstanding educators the opportunity to experience the world beyond their home communities so that they are better equipped to help their students grow into the leaders who will guide us in the future.

Why We Need Books!

In the summer of 2015, our Global Learning Fellows visited the Peruvian village of Pumamarca, Peru in the Sacred Valley of the Incas 60 km northwest of the city of Cuzco. Before visiting the village, we learned the school library lacked an important ingredient: Full Shelves of Books.  

A library with few books is an unfinished promise. The NEA Foundation’s Global Learning Fellows took action, bringing more than 150 books in boxes, carry-ons, and suitcases. We carried them up to Pumamarca, 9,100 feet above sea level. It was a breathtaking labor of love. Literally. 

This year, the 2016 Fellows want to fill the shelves of Pumamarca’s library and expand the gift to neighboring schools and villages. 

Getting these books up to the Sacred Valley of the Incas will require some heavy lifting. We are prepared for that. But we need some help from supporters of the NEA Foundation and public education everywhere. We aim to raise $4,500 for the purchase and transport of the books from Washington, DC to Pumamarca and surrounding villages and schools.

Global Learning Fellows: Enrichment & Hope

Enriching Educators

Since it began in 2011, the Global Learning Fellowship program has brought more than 150 educators from across the United States to study, experience, and engage the citizens of far-away lands and diverse cultures. 

Enriching American Public School Students

The program provides educators a vital opportunity to explore and enrich themselves personally and professionally so that they may return home to share that wonder and excitement with their students. For many, this annual study abroad trip is their first visit outside the United States. It can be a life-changing experience for both visiting educators, their students back home, and the people of the regions we visit.

A Gift of Books is a Gift of Hope

The more support we raise, the more books we can bring with us to village schools we visit in the Sacred Valley of the Incas. This is not only a benefit to the students in this remote region by expanding access to literacy, but also a benefit to the future of their families and communities.  And, for us, it is an expression of our gratitude for all they bring to us, the educators, and the students we serve back home.

Risks, Challenges & Determination

A book can change a child. A library filled with books can change an entire community. If our campaign does not meet its goal, we will still bring books to Cuzco — just fewer of them. If we raise more then our goal, we will be able to support additional schools and students.

How You Can Help

Make a small financial contribution. Share this campaign with your social network. Post campaign updates to your Facebook page.

Anything you can do to support this effort financially or through sharing will be greatly appreciated by the NEA Foundation, the Global Learning Fellows, and friends of public education everywhere.

story:
Janine Macbeth has wanted to make children's books since she was in the second grade. As a kid, when she realized people who looked like her were invisible in books, she gave up her bookmaking dreams. Over time, that invisibility fueled her passion for publishing, and her commitment to making sure every child sees themself in books.

In 2013, after studying, training, and working in publishing, Janine started Blood Orange Press and released their first book, Oh, Oh, Baby Boy. 

Blood Orange Press has 3 new books lined up, all in different stages of development, and with plenty more stories waiting in the wings. Your support will help us pay off our second book, One of A Kind, Like Me, and reprint our first book. 

Blood Orange Press is committed to making beautiful books with high production value. We want children and families to fall in love with our books, and keep them in the family collection for generations to come.

Bottom line: Bare bones, each new book costs $25,000, from development to production to marketing and distribution. 

$100,000 would empower us to go full steam ahead on our three new titles, and reprint our first book, Oh, Oh, Baby Boy, which has sold out.

And... $100,000 is a huge challenge, so for now we’re setting our sights on a more modest goal  to keep us moving. $15,000 will allow us to pay the bills on One of A Kind, Like Me (which was just released late September 2016), get our awards applications out, and reprint our first book, Oh, Oh, Baby Boy, which has sold out. With more funding we can finish developing The Blue Flute and Best Day Ever, and with even more, send the books to print!

Janine has never been paid for the Blood Orange Press work she’s done. Every dollar we receive through book purchases and fundraising goes towards making more books that are missing. 

Every bit helps, and will allow us to move forward that much further! 

Blood Orange Press is an independent children’s publishing company committed to correcting the invisibility of people of color in children’s literature. We are one of a very small cohort of independent publishers devoted to making sure that people of color and Native communities can tell their own stories in children's books, and that diverse kids of all backgrounds can see themselves and each other in the books they read. We publish stories that embrace intersectionality, build confidence in underrepresented readers, and compassion across lines of difference.

One of A Kind, Like Me / Único como yo 
By Laurin Mayeno, Illustrated by Robert Trujillo 
Release date: Oct 2016 / Bilingual in English & Spanish 
Synopsis: Tomorrow is the school parade, and Danny (a multiracial Latinx preschooler) knows exactly what he will be: a princess. Mommy supports him 100%, and they race to the thrift store to find his costume. This unique book lifts up children who express their gender in non-conforming ways, and reflects the power of a loving and supportive community. 

The Blue Flute 
Written by Indira Allegra 
Release: Spring 2018 
Synopsis: What happens when an instrument plays its player? In The Blue Flute, a young African American girl begins a relationship with a magical flute. As she prepares for the winter recital, the flute reveals the music of her city in dribbling basketballs, dripping faucets and the booming laughter of men on the corner.

Best Day Ever [working title] 
Written by Lora Collier Chan
Release: Fall/Winter 2017 
Synopsis: Textile patterns unlock the imaginations of 12 diverse children as they take different journeys to the local park. This book shares the value of community with even the youngest readers.

Oh, Oh, Baby Boy! 
Written & illustrated by Janine Macbeth
Released: June 2013 (We've sold out and are fundraising to print more copies!)
Synopsis: Readers welcome a baby boy who’s nurtured and cared for by his loving father. We watch as he grows up to become a father himself. This book celebrates dads of color and non-traditional masculinity, and promotes gender equity within families.

(Above) Beautiful Stories Giclée Print, Book Bag, & Greeting Card Art

If met, our IGG goal will help us close the books on One of A Kind, Like Me, and reprint Oh, Oh, Baby Boy. With $30K-$50K more, we can finish developing our next two books, The Blue Flute and Best Day Ever, get them designed, translated, and printed.

When readers hold a book in their hands, they don’t often think about the many people and processes that went into making it. In general, publishers schedule out books in 2 year timeframes. In other words, once a publisher decides to move forward on a book, we typically aim for a release date two years out. This allows for continued manuscript development, vetting, planning, illustration, review phases, design, printing, shipping of the book, etc. - You get the idea!

This is why our upcoming books have different release dates - each is in a different stage of development.

And, with all these steps in the process, a hiccup or delay here or there can affect release dates.

Help us spread the word! 

  • Email your friends and listservs, invite them to support. 
  • Mention this campaign in newsletters that reach parents, families, educators, and others who care about visibility and diversity.
  • Let us know if you know any blogs or bloggers who might be interested in our work.
story_txt:
Janine Macbeth has wanted to make children's books since she was in the second grade. As a kid, when she realized people who looked like her were invisible in books, she gave up her bookmaking dreams. Over time, that invisibility fueled her passion for publishing, and her commitment to making sure every child sees themself in books.
In 2013, after studying, training, and working in publishing, Janine started Blood Orange Press and released their first book, Oh, Oh, Baby Boy. 
Blood Orange Press has 3 new books lined up, all in different stages of development, and with plenty more stories waiting in the wings. Your support will help us pay off our second book, One of A Kind, Like Me, and reprint our first book. 



Blood Orange Press is committed to making beautiful books with high production value. We want children and families to fall in love with our books, and keep them in the family collection for generations to come.
Bottom line: Bare bones, each new book costs $25,000, from development to production to marketing and distribution. 

$100,000 would empower us to go full steam ahead on our three new titles, and reprint our first book, Oh, Oh, Baby Boy, which has sold out.
And... $100,000 is a huge challenge, so for now we’re setting our sights on a more modest goal  to keep us moving. $15,000 will allow us to pay the bills on One of A Kind, Like Me (which was just released late September 2016), get our awards applications out, and reprint our first book, Oh, Oh, Baby Boy, which has sold out. With more funding we can finish developing The Blue Flute and Best Day Ever, and with even more, send the books to print!
Janine has never been paid for the Blood Orange Press work she’s done. Every dollar we receive through book purchases and fundraising goes towards making more books that are missing. 
Every bit helps, and will allow us to move forward that much further! 


Blood Orange Press is an independent children’s publishing company committed to correcting the invisibility of people of color in children’s literature. We are one of a very small cohort of independent publishers devoted to making sure that people of color and Native communities can tell their own stories in children's books, and that diverse kids of all backgrounds can see themselves and each other in the books they read. We publish stories that embrace intersectionality, build confidence in underrepresented readers, and compassion across lines of difference.

One of A Kind, Like Me / Único como yo By Laurin Mayeno, Illustrated by Robert Trujillo Release date: Oct 2016 / Bilingual in English & Spanish Synopsis: Tomorrow is the school parade, and Danny (a multiracial Latinx preschooler) knows exactly what he will be: a princess. Mommy supports him 100%, and they race to the thrift store to find his costume. This unique book lifts up children who express their gender in non-conforming ways, and reflects the power of a loving and supportive community. 
The Blue Flute Written by Indira Allegra Release: Spring 2018 Synopsis: What happens when an instrument plays its player? In The Blue Flute, a young African American girl begins a relationship with a magical flute. As she prepares for the winter recital, the flute reveals the music of her city in dribbling basketballs, dripping faucets and the booming laughter of men on the corner.
Best Day Ever [working title] Written by Lora Collier ChanRelease: Fall/Winter 2017 Synopsis: Textile patterns unlock the imaginations of 12 diverse children as they take different journeys to the local park. This book shares the value of community with even the youngest readers.

We watch as he grows up to become a father himself. This book celebrates dads of color and non-traditional masculinity, and promotes gender equity within families.






(Above) Beautiful Stories Giclée Print, Book Bag, & Greeting Card Art

If met, our IGG goal will help us close the books on One of A Kind, Like Me, and reprint Oh, Oh, Baby Boy. With $30K-$50K more, we can finish developing our next two books, The Blue Flute and Best Day Ever, get them designed, translated, and printed.

In other words, once a publisher decides to move forward on a book, we typically aim for a release date two years out. This allows for continued manuscript development, vetting, planning, illustration, review phases, design, printing, shipping of the book, etc. - You get the idea!
This is why our upcoming books have different release dates - each is in a different stage of development.
And, with all these steps in the process, a hiccup or delay here or there can affect release dates.

Email your friends and listservs, invite them to support.

story:
Chi siamo?

L’Orchestra Fuoritempo è un'associazione di promozione sociale interamente gestita da volontari, nata nel 2009 allo scopo di raggruppare i ragazzi della comunità trentina presso l’oratorio di Martignano per organizzare per loro un’attività durante l’estate. Oggi raggruppa circa 70 giovani musicisti tra i 12 e i 20 anni intorno a un progetto di formazione musicale, di crescita artistico-culturale e di promozione della loro partecipazione attiva alla vita della comunità.

Ogni anno l’Orchestra Fuoritempo è protagonista di molti progetti musicali, che si traducono in concerti musicali in Trentino, in Italia e all’estero, tutti caratterizzati da una forte valenza culturale-formativa sia per i ragazzi coinvolti, sia per la comunità destinataria dei concerti realizzati.​ Al Presidente dell'Associazione ed al Direttore dell'orchestra, che dal 2009 si occupano della realizzazione delle attività dei ragazzi, negli ultimi anni si sono affiancati altri volontari, principalmente di alcune famiglie dei musicisti. Alcuni di loro si occupano delle attività più divulgative delle attività dell'Orchestra (dal progetto grafico di alcuni materiali, alla pubblicità dei concerti). Altri offrono supporto logistico e affiancano i ragazzi durante lo svolgimento vero e proprio dei concerti.

L'Associazione “Tribù nel mondo” è un’associazione nata per sostenere i bimbi orfani ospiti dell'orfanotrofio Casa Marisa di Kinshasa (Congo). Tribù del mondo nasce dal desiderio di quattro famiglie adottive di mantenere e coltivare un rapporto con il Paese che ha dato i natali ai loro figli. L'Associazione Tribù del Mondo è costituita dalle famiglie dei ragazzi adottati, che quindi sono in grado di raccontare in prima persona le storie dei ragazzi che sono stati adottati.

 

Che progetto proponiamo?

Il progetto Tribù nel mondo” nasce da una semplice chiacchierata tra i membri delle due diverse associazioni.

Tribù del Mondo ha bisogno di raccogliere circa 7.000,00 € al mese da inviare in Congo, per “far vivere” o meglio “far sopravvivere” più di 100 bambini ospitati in tale struttura. L’idea che abbiamo avuto è di organizzare un Tour per le città d’Italia dove vivono gli “ex angeli di Kinshasa” cioè i bambini prima ospitati nell’orfanotrofio ed adesso adottati dalle famiglie italiane.

Il progetto si propone di creare uno spettacolo musicale accompagnato da narrazioni e interventi multimediali sul tema del progetto. L’orchestra FuoriTempo realizzerà lo spettacolo musicale con pezzi di diverse nazionalità mentre Tribù del Mondo penserà ai brani da leggere tutti tratti dal libro Furaha (una storia di adozione di una bambina congolese), alle immagini dei bambini ospitati a Casa Marisa, alle riflessioni sul tema dell’adozione, dell’accoglienza e della solidarietà.

 

Perché chiediamo dei soldi per il crowdfunding?

Per la prima parte del progetto, quella di organizzazione e creazione dei contenuti dello spettacolo, siamo riusciti ad avere qualche aiuto economico, ma per la seconda parte in cui vogliamo diffondere il nostro messaggio fuori dal  Trentino abbiamo bisogno anche del vostro aiuto … del vostro supporto economico … perché far viaggiare e sfamare una carovana di circa 50 ragazzi + gli organizzatori, pagare le varie autorizzazioni per i permessi ad esibirsi in pubblico, diritti d’autore per i pezzi suonati, ecc… non è cosa da poco!!! Ogni partecipante al tour pagherà una quota d’iscrizione simbolica, anche se servirà a coprire ben poco delle spese da sostenere.

Vi chiediamo quindi un’offerta per poter coprire le spese collegate al viaggio dei ragazzi nelle varie città; la nostra filosofia è “più siamo meglio è”, tante piccole offerte per coprire la grande spesa e per poi riuscire a donare il più possibile ai bambini di Casa Marisa.

 

Qual è il nostro obiettivo?

Il nostro obiettivo è raggiungere 13.000 euro in 60 giorni (2 mesi). Questi fondi ci serviranno per coprire le spese vive del viaggio dei musicisti nelle città, in modo che possano suonare e diffondere il nostro messaggio, ma serviranno anche per ristampare il libro Fuhara, che racconta un’esperienza di adozione.

 

Perché parlate di “progetto”? Non è soltanto musica?

No, non è soltanto musica. Il nostro scopo è unire la passione per la musica con la passione per la solidarietà. Inventare uno spettacolo dove le note musicali si mescolano con le parole, dove i suoni si alternano alle immagini, dove le emozioni che irrompono nei cuori scuotano i pensieri che riempiono le menti.

L'intero progetto è basato sulla condivisione di un obiettivo comune, sul racconto delle diverse esperienze vissute, sul racconto e la divulgazione di un tema importante come quello dell'accoglienza e dell'accettazione della diversità utilizzando diversi linguaggi allo stesso tempo (quello musicale, quello visivo e quello letterario).

Pensiamo che il valore aggiunto di questa condivisione e contaminazione dei diversi linguaggi che caratterizzano le diverse età degli attori principali sia rappresentato dall'essere un messaggio che, venendo dai ragazzi, sarà diretto e facilmente accessibile a un pubblico di tutte le età, perché sarà filtrato attraverso il punto di vista dei pari.

story:
The Oxford Radical Forum 2017 is a completely free and open annual festival of radical ideas and culture, organised by students and activists in Oxford. Each year leading critics, authors and activists of the left are invited to spark critical thought and debate about how we understand the world and struggles to change it. Celebrating its 10th anniversary, the Forum will focus on question such as, which way forward for Labour? What is the current situation of left nationalist and revolutionary movements across the world, from Colombia to Northern Ireland, Morocco and Indonesia? How can we think critically about the role of the UK in the world after the events of the past year? Closer to home, how do cuts and privatisation affect the NHS and can be combated effectively? What is the role of public institutions in perpetuating racism and rape culture? And what lies ahead for student activism and free education?This year’s Forum will host informed and engaged debates on all these questions and more.

All are welcome. At the heart of ORF is a hope that the conversations that take place at the event continue and excite activity, as well as discussion. The money you contribute to the Oxford Radical Forum will ensure that we are able to put on a high quality program, inviting speakers from around the world, as well as guaranteeing that all events remain free for all participants.

story:
TopLab: the first community biolab in Berlin

We are building TopLab: a community bio laboratory for curiosity, creativity, education and interdisciplinary research. TopLab serves as a platform for science, technology and art, where people have access to biotech classes and develop their own projects. Help us acquire the equipment needed to initiate our community and become an important part of our journey!

 

What is Top-Lab?

TopLab is supported by TOP e.V., an association for the promotion of cultural practice and social innovation which is situated at >top Schillerpalais, a project space in the heart of Berlin. Using borrowed, recycled and home-built equipment, we recreate a typical do-it-yourself biology (DIYbio) lab and bring biology to the public.

TopLab reframes the laboratory as a shared space, informal and inviting rather than sterile and exclusive. Through audience participation, the intention is to demystify biology and radically lower the barrier to participation in modern bioscience, allowing anyone to innovate and explore. This environment also encourages thoughtful examination and discussion of the implications and ethical questions surrounding cutting-edge bio-based technologies.

 

Our Story

We are launching this campaign to provide TopLab with the basic equipment used in a biology laboratory. This campaign is an important development for TopLab’s long journey ahead, which is to become an open space with the interest for sharing resources and overcoming those barriers given by the lack of professional facilities, equipment and access to public knowledge and practice. The community of the future depends on people like us who are initiating new era of science and providing new solutions and opportunities for the planet we live on.

 

Who is behind Top-Lab?

TopLab will be inhabited by various highly qualified and DIYbio practitioners who will work on their own projects and also provide opportunities for public participation through workshops and discussions.

Mirela Alistar

She is a biohacker actively involved in biotech research.

Flavia Barragan

She is a scientist interested in the intersection of art, science and technology. After more than 8 years working as a researcher in the field of Medicinal Chemistry, she is currently focusing her practice into the development of new Biomaterials, mostly grown from living organisms.

Tuce Erel

She is a curator, art writer and art professional, based in Berlin. Her curatorial interests are archiving practices, ecology, anthropocene, post-human and post-digital theories.

Mindaugas Gapševičius (miga)

He is an artist, interested in intersection between arts, technologies and sciences. Since four years he is interested in the emergence of life and interaction between organic and inorganic matter. Mindaugas Gapševičius (miga) is a PhD candidate and an artistic associate at the Bauhaus University, Weimar. Interested in DIYbio and beyond.

Christiane Hütter

She is an artist who analyses and (re)imagines systems with the means of play and storytelling. she has been working in many projects that aimed to science communication.. also she is working a lot on social fictions (e.g. With Society for Cultural Optimism/cultural optimism.org) or brueten.tumblr.de/a speculative design prototype of breeding an egg instead of being pregnant. A Biolab is a great opportunity for her to actually collaborate new projects in the social fiction field. And she thinks being informed of the real possibilities (and dangers) is crucial for taking decisions for the future. As individuals, groups and societies.

Alice Morey

She is a painter interested in the bridge between art and science. She has a strong interest in becoming self sustainable with the materials she use and she has started experimenting with growing her own. She is interested in decay and working with microorganisms that she can later use within her artistic practice.

Fara Peluso

Fara is an artist designer interested in the relationship between the human and its environment.

Liam Power

Liam is a graduate of fashion designer from Cape Town, South Africa now living in Berlin, Germany. He has an extreme interest in new and innovative materials that inspire a new direction for the role of clothing in our society. He wants to be apart of TopLab to explore how to develop bio-materials and to research how we can use materials that work with our environment and our lifestyle of today.

Alessandro Volpato

He is a biologist working on lab automation and designing systems for open and accessible science. He is interested in bridging communities and promote interdisciplinary collaboration to valorize each other's work.

Selection from our Perks

We provide three different toolkits, which are limited editions and signed by Mindaugas Gapševičius. 

Toolkit 1: Bacterial cellulose

The toolkit has been designed in order to discuss symbiotic relations between organisms and to develop an awareness of interspecies dependency with participants. The Toolkit includes jars with chemical elements and ingredients, along with a sample of SCOBY in kombucha tea. It also has a set of necessary tools for trying to make bacterial cellulose in a practical way, including scales and a microscope.


Toolkit 2: Sun collaborations

The toolkit introduces the cyanotype, which is a photographic printing process producing a cyan-blue print and can be performed on a variety of papers and textiles. While the photo chemicals are painted onto the print surface in a dark room, the print itself is made outside, under direct sunlight. The process uses two chemicals: ammonium iron (III) citrate and potassium ferricyanide, which are both safe to handle and easy to obtain.

Toolkit 3: Plant conversations

The toolkit introduces an electronic circuit for capturing electrical signals in plants. All together, the proposed toolkit introduces interaction between interconnected elements of different natures. The user is invited to build an electronic interface and bridge it with the mycorrhizal fungi and the computer in order to hack the interaction between the cultivated heads of lettuce.

Workshops:

We will host workshops at TopLab and we offer 4 different of our workshops in our campaign. 

Workshop 1

Let it glow! (by Mirela Alistar)

Living in a voluntary relationship with the sea animals, Photobacterium has developed a social sense directly connected to its bioluminescence. In this open workshop, everyone will influence the social life of Photobacterium in an attempt to make it glow. Practically, you will learn to culture the bacteria on agar plates and then grow it at home until it glows beautifully. Everyone is welcome to the workshop, that means also children and young adults. No prior knowledge is needed and all the materials are provided by us.

Workshop 2

Mycorrhizal networks or how do I hack plant conversations (by Mindaugas Gapševičius)

Fungi are able to biodegrade organic and inorganic elements, including slowly degradable elements such as cellulose, toxins, and heavy metals. Fungi are also known for being able to transport chemical elements within their networks and their ability to exchange chemical elements with plants. During the workshop, you will learn how to cultivate Oyster mushrooms and its mycelium. We will also think about possible uses for home and industry.

Workshop 3

Algature (by Fara Peluso)

Diatoms are photosynthetic microalgae that produce 20% of the oxygen on Earth. They are the most important little organisms that most people never heard of! Although tiny, diatoms play an immense role in keeping the planet’s ecosystem working. They’re important mediators of carbon and oxygen cycles, an integral component of marine food webs and the principal cycles of silica, which constitutes 25% of the Earth’s crust.

The workshop will show the general diatoms’ features (photosynthesis, aspects, colors…) and how you can cultivate them at home. 

Workshop 4

Sustainable pigments (by Alessandro Volpato & Flavia Barragan)

Pigments are molecules that can be found in great abundance and diversity in plants. In this workshop you will learn to extract the from the plants and understand how to see them into a DIY spectrometer.

What is our budget?

The funds are raised to support new ideas and open projects that need equipment and reagents to enable scientific precision. The open space will increase the interest for sharing resources and overcoming those barriers given by the lack of professional equipment.

Through audience participation, the intention is to demystify biology and radically lower the barrier to participation in modern bioscience, allowing anyone to innovate and explore. This environment also encourages thoughtful examination and discussion of the implications and ethical questions surrounding cutting-edge bio-based technologies. Our StoryWe are launching this campaign to provide TopLab with the basic equipment used in a biology laboratory. This campaign is an important development for TopLab’s long journey ahead, which is to become an open space with the interest for sharing resources and overcoming those barriers given by the lack of professional facilities, equipment and access to public knowledge and practice. The community of the future depends on people like us who are initiating new era of science and providing new solutions and opportunities for the planet we live on. Who is behind Top-Lab?TopLab will be inhabited by various highly qualified and DIYbio practitioners who will work on their own projects and also provide opportunities for public participation through workshops and discussions.Mirela AlistarShe is a biohacker actively involved in biotech research.Flavia BarraganShe is a scientist interested in the intersection of art, science and technology. After more than 8 years working as a researcher in the field of Medicinal Chemistry, she is currently focusing her practice into the development of new Biomaterials, mostly grown from living organisms.Tuce ErelShe is a curator, art writer and art professional, based in Berlin. Her curatorial interests are archiving practices, ecology, anthropocene, post-human and post-digital theories.Mindaugas Gapševičius (miga)He is an artist, interested in intersection between arts, technologies and sciences. Since four years he is interested in the emergence of life and interaction between organic and inorganic matter. Mindaugas Gapševičius (miga) is a PhD candidate and an artistic associate at the Bauhaus University, Weimar. Interested in DIYbio and beyond.Christiane HütterShe is an artist who analyses and (re)imagines systems with the means of play and storytelling. she has been working in many projects that aimed to science communication.. also she is working a lot on social fictions (e.g. With Society for Cultural Optimism/cultural optimism.org) or brueten.tumblr.de/a speculative design prototype of breeding an egg instead of being pregnant. A Biolab is a great opportunity for her to actually collaborate new projects in the social fiction field. And she thinks being informed of the real possibilities (and dangers) is crucial for taking decisions for the future. As individuals, groups and societies.Alice MoreyShe is a painter interested in the bridge between art and science. She has a strong interest in becoming self sustainable with the materials she use and she has started experimenting with growing her own. She is interested in decay and working with microorganisms that she can later use within her artistic practice.Fara PelusoFara is an artist designer interested in the relationship between the human and its environment.Liam PowerLiam is a graduate of fashion designer from Cape Town, South Africa now living in Berlin, Germany. He has an extreme interest in new and innovative materials that inspire a new direction for the role of clothing in our society. He wants to be apart of TopLab to explore how to develop bio-materials and to research how we can use materials that work with our environment and our lifestyle of today.Alessandro VolpatoHe is a biologist working on lab automation and designing systems for open and accessible science. He is interested in bridging communities and promote interdisciplinary collaboration to valorize each other's work.Selection from our PerksWe provide three different toolkits, which are limited editions and signed by Mindaugas Gapševičius. Toolkit 1: Bacterial celluloseThe toolkit has been designed in order to discuss symbiotic relations between organisms and to develop an awareness of interspecies dependency with participants. The Toolkit includes jars with chemical elements and ingredients, along with a sample of SCOBY in kombucha tea. It also has a set of necessary tools for trying to make bacterial cellulose in a practical way, including scales and a microscope.Toolkit 2: Sun collaborationsThe toolkit introduces the cyanotype, which is a photographic printing process producing a cyan-blue print and can be performed on a variety of papers and textiles. While the photo chemicals are painted onto the print surface in a dark room, the print itself is made outside, under direct sunlight. The process uses two chemicals: ammonium iron (III) citrate and potassium ferricyanide, which are both safe to handle and easy to obtain.Toolkit 3: Plant conversationsThe toolkit introduces an electronic circuit for capturing electrical signals in plants. All together, the proposed toolkit introduces interaction between interconnected elements of different natures. The user is invited to build an electronic interface and bridge it with the mycorrhizal fungi and the computer in order to hack the interaction between the cultivated heads of lettuce.Workshops:We will host workshops at TopLab and we offer 4 different of our workshops in our campaign. Workshop 1Let it glow! (by Mirela Alistar)Living in a voluntary relationship with the sea animals, Photobacterium has developed a social sense directly connected to its bioluminescence. In this open workshop, everyone will influence the social life of Photobacterium in an attempt to make it glow. Practically, you will learn to culture the bacteria on agar plates and then grow it at home until it glows beautifully. Everyone is welcome to the workshop, that means also children and young adults. No prior knowledge is needed and all the materials are provided by us.Workshop 2Mycorrhizal networks or how do I hack plant conversations (by Mindaugas Gapševičius)Fungi are able to biodegrade organic and inorganic elements, including slowly degradable elements such as cellulose, toxins, and heavy metals. Fungi are also known for being able to transport chemical elements within their networks and their ability to exchange chemical elements with plants. During the workshop, you will learn how to cultivate Oyster mushrooms and its mycelium. We will also think about possible uses for home and industry.Workshop 3Algature (by Fara Peluso)Diatoms are photosynthetic microalgae that produce 20% of the oxygen on Earth. They are the most important little organisms that most people never heard of! Although tiny, diatoms play an immense role in keeping the planet’s ecosystem working. They’re important mediators of carbon and oxygen cycles, an integral component of marine food webs and the principal cycles of silica, which constitutes 25% of the Earth’s crust.The workshop will show the general diatoms’ features (photosynthesis, aspects, colors…) and how you can cultivate them at home. Workshop 4Sustainable pigments (by Alessandro Volpato & Flavia Barragan)Pigments are molecules that can be found in great abundance and diversity in plants. In this workshop you will learn to extract the from the plants and understand how to see them into a DIY spectrometer.What is our budget?The funds are raised to support new ideas and open projects that need equipment and reagents to enable scientific precision. The open space will increase the interest for sharing resources and overcoming those barriers given by the lack of professional equipment.

story:
The Video shown above is a video about VCD Nepal, the local organization we are working with. 

Short Summary

I am sure you all have heard of the devastating earthquake in Nepal, the death toll has risen to more than 8,500 people. More than 16,000 people are injured and more than 60,000 houses are destroyed. Many trekkers are stuck in avalanches and historical buildings are gone. A lot of children have become orphans overnight. The most prominent industry in Nepal, tourism will be suffering for a long time. After three weeks, they are still suffering from multiple aftershocks everyday and more buildings collapsing.  

Before the earthquake, they served as an NGO hosting volunteers, and sending them to different projects around Nepal. Some of their projects are providing education in local communities, opening up libraries and women empowerment center, sponsoring orphanages, sending help to local hospitals and educating the locals about environmental issue. 

Now they are looking to start a building program to help local people to get back on their feet. 

What We Need & What You Get

What they need now is immediate support to buy supplies to build houses and to provide support groups to traumatized citizens as well as people who have lost their loved ones. I have been working with VCD Nepal (Volunteer Community Development Nepal) for over a year now. It is founded by Bikram Paudel, one of the most genuine and driven people I know. 

Here is a link to their website: http://www.vcdnepal.org/

He is trying to start a building project for local Nepali people. He is aiming to rebuild 10 houses in different communities. Each house costs around $1000USD, which is not expensive at all in the western world. If we can raise more than that, we can easily build more houses. 

The Impact

The monsoon season in Nepal, which means raining 24/7 is right around the corner yet people are still sleeping on the streets because they have lost their homes or because they are simply too afraid to sleep indoors as aftershocks continue to struck the nation. 
They are still sleeping under open skies, which can cause other hygienic problems as the roads are so damaged that they will only become muddy once the rain start to hit. They said to me that "the nation is traumatized", and that they are always on the edge of their seat, anticipating the next earthquake. 
The money will also go to provide food and medicine to local communities. I was talking to Bikram after they have started some relief work. He told me that the people called him God for transporting food to them. They thought that no one will care for them. Some of the villagers walked for 8 hours back and forth only to pick up some rice from VCD Nepal.
He very much stresses the importance of hope for these victims. He solemnly said, "the dead are dead, we can only help those who survived." 

Risks & Challenges

One of the most risky thing is to build the houses when it is raining. The process will be slow but we want to at least make a big house for a village so they can temporarily stay in there until after the monsoon ends. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you absolutely cannot contribute to this event, please help us share it!

story:
Short Summary

This non-profit project aims to connect students to the real business world during their stay at school. We seek to bridge the college-to-career gap by helping students find out what they are capable of. We believe the definition of "education" is Not just delivering or receiving systematic instructions at school because that's more like "training". Instead, we believe the true meaning of education should be the development of one's ability of mind and learning to know.

That's why we call it "The Inspiration Project", because we want to inspire students to explore his passion towards the future and his career potentials. This project is important to us because we feel strong responsibility to assist the next generation in their early age. We want to help them find who they can be in the future.

So we need your support. In the following, I will explain more details as to how we achieve our goal.


Who We Are

We are a group of young professionals based in London who want to share our past experiences to the young generation and help them explore their interest and develop the skills they need.


    What Challenge We have Found

    The major challenge we have found is that a lot of students have no idea what they really want to do until they grow up. So they might encounter a long period of confusion towards career and future. And after graduation, they might end up with a job that is irrelevant to what they learn in school. 


      What We Believe

      We believe everyone is a born talent in some way and we don't want to waste that talent. We want to serve as the window of this world and present to the youth the many possibilities. We are here to help the students discover their true passion and be wild & fearless, ambitious & confident, innovative & insightful.

      How We do

      Yes, dare to fly high. Instead of taking aptitude tests to peek your future, we want to adopt some more practical approaches: Simply talk to the professionals who is already in the industry and see it yourself.

      The below is how we are going to do.

      • Conduct interviews to a professionals or colleague students to share their past experiences on our dedicated website.
      • Encourage the students to contact our interviewees as mentors,and guid them in the way with inspiring ideas.
      • Host lecture among universities, and build a real-time bridge between the students and the experienced professionals.
      • Introduce the 5-days-5-corporate experience to students. It's a one week experience that gives you the opportunity to get insight into different industry across finance, design, engineering, art, and technology. This will help students explore the world and where  their inner passion can go to.


      What we have done so far

      We are serious about this project so we have already made the progress and we want to do it faster. Here's the achievement so far.

      • Over 14 professionals based in London have been interviewed since the last few months and shared their amazing experiences.
      • We have established the structure of our website and it will be ready to launch in Spring 2015. 
      • We have obtained huge and positive feedback from company directors, indicating that they are willing to provide apprenticeship to students.Through the apprenticeship, students will obtain more insights into a specific industry and what the skills they need at work. This also help them think twice when making the career decision after graduating.

      Thank you for making it happen

      This is a non-profit project, and all your support will directly impose a positive impact on students. Also, anyone who contributes to this project will become my partner as you will keep receiving the updates of progress. Again, we are passionate and serious about this project, and it's time to start the journey. Let's make it happen.

Host lecture among universities, and build a real-time bridge between the students and the experienced professionals.
Introduce the 5-days-5-corporate experience to students. It's a one week experience that gives you the opportunity to get insight into different industry across finance, design, engineering, art, and technology. This will help students explore the world and where  their inner passion can go to.

This also help them think twice when making the career decision after graduating.

This is a non-profit project, and all your support will directly impose a positive impact on students. Also, anyone who contributes to this project will become my partner as you will keep receiving the updates of progress. Again, we are passionate and serious about this project, and it's time to start the journey. Let's make it happen.

story:
We are The 2015 BattleBorn Slam Team.  Since 2010, we have a been providing a premier Performance Poetry opportunity for folks throughout the lifespan.  Currently Headquartered out of Downtown Las Vegas next to the Downtown Container Park, we offer a competitive poetry slam experience the first Saturday of the Month in addition to a monthly workshop designed to generate new material and help workshop older material.  In April, the winners of our monthly slams get together to battle it out one final time to see who will comprise the team that represents Las Vegas at the National Poetry Slam.  

The National Poetry Slam is a competition and workshop for the 72 teams that participate every year.  Attending this experience helps fuel and strengthen our amazing literary community here in Las Vegas by allowing us to attend craft workshops, affinity readings, and network to bring national literary talent to Las Vegas for performances.

As the 2015 BattleBorn Slam Team travels to Oakland this summer August 10-16, we seek your assistance in helping us raise $1500 to pay for the cost of 1 hotel room, as well a rental van for the week.  Any additional money raised will help us pay for incidental expenses needed throughout the week.

WHAT YOU GET

As a contributor, you will have access to unique perks from the Battle Born Slam Team including:

  • Fancy, frame-ready typographic prints of poems from the team.
  • Team compilation chapbooks
  • Individual team member chapbooks
  • Team audio CDs
  • Specially-written, individualized poetry from team members
  • A special, private performance from team members at your venue or event
  • A special poem dedicated to you in our next chapbook. 

For individual chapbooks or personal poem requests, please include the team member you would like this item from: Hongy,  Cactus,  Rachel Dexter,  Jeanetta Rich, AkeemJamal, or Coach AJ Moyer. 

IMPACT

By contributing to this campaign, you help to further the growth of the Las Vegas poetry community and open up more opportunities for us to give the youth of our community a productive outlet for their struggles. By our presence at the National Poetry Slam, you also help us continue to bring in top-level talent to expose our city to the kinds of life-changing experiences that can be created with nothing more than a voice and a microphone.

WHAT IF I CAN'T CONTRIBUTE?

If you can't contribute financially - we dig that. Times are tough. But if you have access to any special deals on travel, merchandise production, or if you just want to send us good vibes and well wishes we'd appreciate it endlessly! While it may only be 5 of us physically going to the National Poetry Slam, we're taking this whole community with us in our hearts!
