story:
///Traducción al español más abajo, si por alguna extraña razón no podeis hacer el pago por pay pal, podeis hacer una transferencia a mi cuenta de evo banco  Ana Requena Martinez ES37 0239 2008 0430 4007 3946 , poniendo BBB en el asunto, Os quiero <3 ////

////Voor Nederlandse vertaling scroll helemaal naar onder - onder de Spaanse text :) /////
direct donations also possible ♡ on NL72TRIO0254463207 on name of A. van den Dool  ALSO, cooking tools, pots, pans, cuttlery are suuuuper welcome: AWESOME!♡

Armed with a camera and cooking gear, two girls will go for a peaceful fight against foodwaste and borders. Bellies beyond borders is a creative foodwaste kitchen-on-wheels to welcome refugees in Europe!

Kilos of ugly carrots, one-day-old bread and other abandoned food are rescued from the container by Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam over the last months. In partnerships with local stores and supermarkets, surplus products are collected to share with the community. Big cooking sessions and free supermarkets fed hundreds of friends and strangers.

This is a story to be continued.. Two girls will leave the headquarters of Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam to continue the mission on a global scale: Fill bellies not bins – beyond borders!


Whilst people in other parts of the planet struggle to fill their bellies, the West fills up bins with foodwaste. Whilst refugees run away from unsave situations, European governments block their route with walls to protect the Western comfort. The world upside down!

Time to reverse this system and create a scenario of sharing and caring. The female guerilla fighters will share their pots and pans their recepies, and creativity with refugees all over Europe.

In collaboration with the refugees, the guerilla girls will produce short videos. They will be broadcasted online at Bellies Beyond Borders TV. Watch a cookingshow with a Syrian lady or a musicvideo for a Ghanese teenage rapper about his hometown.

The camera and cookingtools are packed! All they need now is a van!

Enjoy a delicious healthy meal by Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam this month and make their mission happen! Every euro brings them 1 kilometer closer! Order a breakkie-in-bed, or eternal glory with your name tag on the van. Indulge a lunch-for-love: a healthy meal for you and co-workers cooked with rescued veggies, or a meal at the weekly Foodwaste Feast!


Thanks to your funding they will welcome refugees on behalf of all of us :)

THE BATTLE PLAN:
The Guerilla Kitchen Van will hit the road at the end of October. On every location, the fields will be investigated for Foodwaste. Through local contacts and collaborations with shops and farmers, veggies and fruits will be saved from the bin and ingredients collected for a healthy meal. The guerilla duo will meet refugees thanks to NGO’s on location. With the magic construction build by handyman friends in Amsterdam, the van will have all the needs for a cooking session. The kitchen will be set up around camps or in public places. The camera won’t always be there. First part of the mission is to create a safe and comfortable space and cook a nutricious no-waste meal :)

FUNDRAISER

Cooking gear – 700

Bus – 5000

Video tools – 500

Insurance –1000

Petrol – 1000

----------------------

TOTAL    8300

This budget is based on an ideal situation. The more funding we get, the bigger the capacity of the project could be. So any donation is very welcome. We will make it worthwhile.


////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

Armadas con una cámara y cacharros de cocina, dos chicas comenzarán una lucha pacífica contra el desperdicio de comida; y al mismo tiempo contra las fronteras.

Bellies Beyond borders ( Barrigas sin fronteras) es una cocina creativa de comida reciclada sobre ruedas para dar la bienvenida a los refugiados en Europa.

Kilos de zanahorias con mal aspecto, pan del día anterior y otros alimentos abandonados son rescatados de los contenedores por Guerilla Kitchen

Amsterdam. En colaboración con comercios locales y supermercados, los activistas recogen los excedentes de comida para luego compartirlos con la comunidad más necesitada. Compartiendo con amigos y desconocidos una cocina creativa basada en el aprovechamiento de los alimentos y una práctica de muy satisfactoria de mercado alimentario gratuito.

Esta es una historia que debe continuar por eso dos chicas dejaran la sede de Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam para continuar la misión de una manera global.  ¡Llena barrigas y no contenedores  más allá de las fronteras !

Este proyecto nace al ver como en Europa llenamos los contenedores de comida aprovechable mientras que en el resto del mundo miles de personas sufren para conseguir un planto de comida. Parece imposible, pero esto ocurre al mismo tiempo que una guerra estalla en un país y el resto de países cierran sus carreteras con fronteras para no atender al grito de solidaridad internacional que suplican miles de personas afectadas por esta guerra.

¡ El mundo la reves!

Es momento para invertir el sistema y crear un escenario donde compartir y ayudar al prójimo sea una ley universal.

Estas guerrilleras de la cacerola compartiran sartenes, recetas y creatividad culinaria con los refuiados de toda Europa.

En colaboracion con todos los refugiados, las participantes de Guerilla Kitchen produciran videos cortos  que serán retrasmitidos online en Bellies Beyond Borders TV.  En este canal podreís ver desde una madre siria presentando su programa de cocina hasta a un rapero sirio cantando sobre la situación de su familia o ciudad de origen.

Ya han empaquetado la camara y las herramientas de cocina...

¡ Ahora sólo les falta la furgoneta!

Disfruta de una sana y riquísima comida en Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam este mes y ayuda a que la misión se cumpla, con sólo un euro aportado moverá a las chicas 1km más cerca de su objetivo.

Pide desde un desayuno en la cama o consigue la gloria eterna con tu nombre en la furgo. Disfruta con tus compañeros de trabajo de un lunch-fo-love, un menú sano cocinado con verduras recicladas.

Conoce nuestro gran festín de comida reciclada semanal.

Gracias a tu ayuda las chicas les darán la bienvenida a los refugiados en nombre de todos.

EL PLAN DE BATALLA

La Guerilla Kitchen Van, pisará las carreteras al final de Octubre.

En cada destino las chicas investigarán el terreno para hacer acuerdos y encontrar lugares donde recoger comida; a través de contactos locales  y en colaboración con comercios o agricultores.

Verduras y frutas serán rescatadas de su trayectoria directa al contenedor  y se convertirán en deliciosos y saludables platos que difunden el compañerismo internacional.

¿ Cómo encontraremos a los refugiados?

A través de las ONGs  de cada ciudad; además contamos con la con la mágica ayuda de amigos  en Amsterdam que equiparán la furgo de todo lo necesario para grandes comilonas.

Para terminar explicar que la furgo se estacionará cerca de los campos de refugiados o en lugares públicos dónde la cámara  no estará desde el principio, ya que lo primordial es crear un entorno seguro y confortable para cocinar una comida -no desperdiciada- .


NEDERLANDSE TEKST:

Een creatieve foodwaste keuken op wielen om vluchtelingen te verwelkomen in Europa.

Gewapend met camera en kookgerei zullen twee jongedames de strijd aangaan met voedselverspilling en het vluchtelingenbeleid. Vanuit hun bus zullen ze koken en creëren met vluchtelingen in Oost en Zuid Europa vanaf half oktober.

Voor de crowdfunding duikt Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam komende maand in de keuken om maaltijden te bereiden voor hun sponsors die hun missie mogelijk maken! Bestel een ontbijtje-op-bed, een lunch-for-love of een diner voor twee op een Special Secret Location. Of reis mee in de bus op missie voor een week!

Kilo’s lelijke wortels en dag-oud-brood zijn de afgelopen maanden gered van de containers in Amsterdam door Guerilla Kitchen. In samenwerking met lokale groenteboeren en supermarkten belandde dit voedsel niet in de prullenbak maar op het bord. In de wekelijkse diner feestjes en een gratis supermarkt zijn een heleboel buiken gevuld met gezond eten.

Dit verhaal wordt nu vervolgd op grote schaal: BELLIES BEYOND BORDERS! Twee vrouwelijke strijders verlaten het hoofdkwartier van Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam om de missie voort te zetten in Calais, Budapest en andere plekken. Want terwijl we in Europa prullenbakken vullen met afgedankt voedsel, lopen anderen ver weg rond met knorrende buiken. Terwijl vluchtelingen huis en haard verlaten op zoek naar veiligheid, bouwen Europese regeringen hoge muren om het Westers comfort te bewaken. De wereld op zijn kop!

Het is tijd om het roer om te gooien! De guerilla girls zullen hun potten en pannen, hun recepten en creativiteit delen met vluchtelingen overal in Europa.

Naast koken in de keuken achterin de bus, zullen ze videos maken samen met de vluchtelingen. Deze worden online uitgezonden vanaf eind oktober op Bellies Beyond Borders TV! Bekijk bijvoorbeeld een kookshow met een dame uit Syrie of een muziekvideo van een Ghanese rapper over zijn thuis.

De camera en kookgerei staan paraat! Alles wat ze nu nodig hebben is een bus om buiken te vullen van "vrienden-van-ver". :)
story_txt:
///Traducción al español más abajo, si por alguna extraña razón no podeis hacer el pago por pay pal, podeis hacer una transferencia a mi cuenta de evo banco  Ana Requena Martinez ES37 0239 2008 0430 4007 3946 , poniendo BBB en el asunto, Os quiero <3 ////
////Voor Nederlandse vertaling scroll helemaal naar onder - onder de Spaanse text :) ///// direct donations also possible ♡ on NL72TRIO0254463207 on name of A. van den Dool  ALSO, cooking tools, pots, pans, cuttlery are suuuuper welcome: AWESOME!♡ Armed with a camera and cooking gear, two girls
will go for a peaceful fight against foodwaste and borders. Bellies beyond
borders is a creative foodwaste kitchen-on-wheels to welcome refugees in Europe! 
Kilos of ugly carrots, one-day-old bread and other abandoned food are rescued
from the container by Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam over the last months. In
partnerships with local stores and supermarkets, surplus products are collected
to share with the community. Big cooking sessions and free supermarkets fed
hundreds of friends and strangers. 
This is a story to be continued.. Two
girls will leave the headquarters of Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam to continue the
mission on a global scale: Fill bellies not bins – beyond borders!
 
Whilst people in other parts of the planet struggle to fill their
bellies, the West fills up bins with foodwaste. Whilst refugees run
away from unsave situations, European governments block their route with walls
to protect the Western comfort. The world upside down!

Time to reverse this system and create a
scenario of sharing and caring. The female guerilla fighters will share their
pots and pans their recepies, and creativity with refugees all over Europe. 



In collaboration with the refugees, the guerilla
girls will produce short videos. They will be broadcasted online at Bellies Beyond
Borders TV. Watch a cookingshow with a Syrian lady or a musicvideo for a
Ghanese teenage rapper about his hometown. 
The camera and cookingtools are packed! All they
need now is a van! 
Enjoy a delicious healthy meal by Guerilla
Kitchen Amsterdam this month and make their mission happen! Every euro brings
them 1 kilometer closer! Order a breakkie-in-bed, or eternal glory with your
name tag on the van. Indulge a lunch-for-love: a healthy meal for you and
co-workers cooked with rescued veggies, or a meal at the weekly Foodwaste Feast! 

Thanks to your funding they will welcome
refugees on behalf of all of us :)



THE BATTLE PLAN:The
Guerilla Kitchen Van will hit the road at the end of October. On every
location, the fields will be investigated for Foodwaste. Through local contacts
and collaborations with shops and farmers, veggies and fruits will be saved
from the bin and ingredients collected for a healthy meal. The guerilla duo
will meet refugees thanks to NGO’s on location. With the magic construction
build by handyman friends in Amsterdam, the van will have all the needs for a
cooking session. The kitchen will be set up around camps or in public places. The
camera won’t always be there. First part of the mission is to create a safe and
comfortable space and cook a nutricious no-waste meal :)


FUNDRAISER 
Cooking gear – 700
Bus – 5000
Video tools – 500
Insurance –1000


Petrol – 1000 

----------------------
TOTAL    8300 
This budget is based on an ideal situation.
The more funding we get, the bigger the capacity of the project could be. So
any donation is very welcome. We will make it worthwhile. 

////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
Armadas con una cámara y cacharros de cocina,
dos chicas comenzarán una lucha pacífica contra el desperdicio de comida; y al
mismo tiempo contra las fronteras. 
Bellies
Beyond borders ( Barrigas sin fronteras) es una cocina
creativa de comida reciclada sobre ruedas para dar la bienvenida a los
refugiados en Europa.
Kilos de zanahorias con mal aspecto, pan del día
anterior y otros alimentos abandonados son rescatados de los contenedores por
Guerilla Kitchen 
Amsterdam. En colaboración con comercios locales
y supermercados, los activistas recogen los excedentes de comida para luego
compartirlos con la comunidad más necesitada. Compartiendo con amigos y desconocidos una
cocina creativa basada en el aprovechamiento de los alimentos y una práctica de
muy satisfactoria de mercado alimentario gratuito.
Esta es una historia que debe continuar por
eso dos chicas dejaran la sede de Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam para continuar la
misión de una manera global.  ¡Llena barrigas y no contenedores  más allá de las fronteras !

Este proyecto nace al ver como en Europa
llenamos los contenedores de comida aprovechable mientras que en el resto del
mundo miles de personas sufren para conseguir un planto de comida. Parece
imposible, pero esto ocurre al mismo tiempo que una guerra estalla en un país y
el resto de países cierran sus carreteras con fronteras para no atender al
grito de solidaridad internacional que suplican miles de personas afectadas por
esta guerra.
¡ El mundo la reves!
Es momento para invertir el sistema y crear un
escenario donde compartir y ayudar al prójimo sea una ley universal. 
Estas guerrilleras de la cacerola compartiran
sartenes, recetas y creatividad culinaria con los refuiados de toda Europa.
En colaboracion con todos los refugiados, las
participantes de Guerilla Kitchen produciran videos cortos  que serán retrasmitidos online en Bellies Beyond Borders TV.  En este canal podreís ver desde una madre
siria presentando su programa de cocina hasta a un rapero sirio cantando sobre
la situación de su familia o ciudad de origen. 
Ya han empaquetado la camara y las
herramientas de cocina...
¡ Ahora sólo les falta la furgoneta!
Disfruta de una sana y riquísima comida en
Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam este mes y ayuda a que la misión se cumpla, con sólo
un euro aportado moverá a las chicas 1km más cerca de su objetivo.
Pide desde un desayuno en la cama o consigue
la gloria eterna con tu nombre en la furgo. Disfruta con tus compañeros de
trabajo de un lunch-fo-love, un menú sano
cocinado con verduras recicladas. 
Conoce nuestro gran festín de comida reciclada
semanal.
Gracias a tu ayuda las chicas les darán la
bienvenida a los refugiados en nombre de todos.
EL PLAN DE BATALLA
La Guerilla Kitchen Van, pisará las carreteras
al final de Octubre.
En cada destino las chicas investigarán el
terreno para hacer acuerdos y encontrar lugares donde recoger comida; a través
de contactos locales  y en colaboración
con comercios o agricultores.
Verduras y frutas serán rescatadas de su
trayectoria directa al contenedor  y se
convertirán en deliciosos y saludables platos que difunden el compañerismo
internacional. 
¿ Cómo encontraremos a los refugiados?
A través de las ONGs  de cada ciudad; además contamos con la con la
mágica ayuda de amigos  en Amsterdam que
equiparán la furgo de todo lo necesario para grandes comilonas.
Para terminar explicar que la furgo se
estacionará cerca de los campos de refugiados o en lugares públicos dónde la
cámara  no estará desde el principio, ya
que lo primordial es crear un entorno seguro y confortable para cocinar una
comida -no desperdiciada- .

NEDERLANDSE TEKST:
Een creatieve foodwaste keuken op wielen om
vluchtelingen te verwelkomen in Europa. 
Gewapend met camera en kookgerei zullen
twee jongedames de strijd aangaan met voedselverspilling en het
vluchtelingenbeleid. Vanuit hun bus zullen ze koken en creëren met vluchtelingen
in Oost en Zuid Europa vanaf half oktober. Voor de crowdfunding duikt Guerilla Kitchen Amsterdam komende maand in de keuken om
maaltijden te bereiden voor hun sponsors die hun missie mogelijk maken! Bestel
een ontbijtje-op-bed, een lunch-for-love of een diner voor twee op een Special

dag-oud-brood zijn de afgelopen maanden gered van de containers in Amsterdam
door Guerilla Kitchen. In samenwerking met lokale groenteboeren en
supermarkten belandde dit voedsel niet in de prullenbak maar op het bord. In de
wekelijkse diner feestjes en een gratis supermarkt zijn een heleboel buiken
gevuld met gezond eten. 
Dit verhaal wordt nu vervolgd op grote schaal: BELLIES BEYOND BORDERS!
Twee vrouwelijke strijders verlaten het hoofdkwartier van Guerilla Kitchen
Amsterdam om de missie voort te zetten in Calais, Budapest en andere plekken. Want terwijl we in
Europa prullenbakken vullen met afgedankt voedsel, lopen anderen ver weg rond
met knorrende buiken. Terwijl vluchtelingen huis en haard verlaten op zoek naar
veiligheid, bouwen Europese regeringen hoge muren om het Westers comfort te
bewaken. De wereld op zijn kop!
Het is tijd om het roer om te gooien! De
guerilla girls zullen hun potten en pannen, hun recepten en creativiteit delen
met vluchtelingen overal in Europa. 
Naast koken in de keuken achterin 
de bus, zullen ze videos maken samen met de vluchtelingen. Deze worden 
online uitgezonden vanaf eind oktober op
Bellies Beyond Borders TV! Bekijk bijvoorbeeld een kookshow met een dame
 uit
Syrie of een muziekvideo van een Ghanese rapper over zijn thuis. 
De camera en kookgerei staan paraat! Alles wat
ze nu nodig hebben is een bus om buiken te vullen van "vrienden-van-ver". :)

story:
Short Summary

Contingent academic labor is a feminist issue.  Women comprise a majority of this precarious workforce, and many are women of color and parents/caregivers,  in disciplines in the humanities and social sciences that have historically contributed, and continue to contribute, to women and gender studies departments. Discussions about the future of the field and the future of the profession that take place at annual disciplinary conferences should include the involvement of the *majority* of the faculty teaching, researching, serving, and laboring in the academy.  For the past two years, members of the NWSA's Contingent Faculty Interest Group have run crowd funding campaigns that have helped precariously employed scholars working in the discipline attend this important conference. This year, the interest group has partnered with the Women of Color Caucus to present a roundtable titled: Decolonizing Contingency: Bodies, Borders, and Academic Belonging. 

In order to ensure that all roundtable participants are able to make it to Montreal for this critical conversation, we need your help!

Background

In 2014, over a dozen contingent faculty members working in women’s and gender studies and related disciplines organized and participated in three highly successful sessions on the theme of contingent labor in academia for the 2014 National Women’s Studies Association’s annual conference. Building on this momentum, the newly formed Contingent Faculty Interest Group has organized four sessions and an interest group business meeting at the 2015  NWSA conference on Precarity in Milwaukee. 

In both 2014 and 2015, many precariously-employed participants did not receive enough funding from their respective institutions or the NWSA to attend the conference. However, with the help of generous donors, these participants were able to attend the conference to contribute to scholarly discussions on the topic, as well as advocacy work on behalf of contingent faculty. This work has been successful not only in raising awareness about contingency in higher education, but also with garnering support from NWSA leadership. 

With your help, we can match that support with funding.

What We Need

Contingent faculty have been, and continue to be, largely omitted of professional development opportunities because of lack of support from the colleges, universities, and associations of which they are faculty and members, including the funds to attend conferences.  Although contingent faculty  apply for funding from the NWSA and their institutions where possible,  they most often are  not able to access enough funding to attend the conference given the costs of travel, food and multi-day lodging.


  • Money raised will help contingent faculty members who are participating in the conference sessions attend NWSA in 2016. PArticipants have all already been accepted to the conference, but they must pay for NWSA membership and register for the conference by July 18th.

  • Any additional money generated by this campaign will be donated first to contingent faculty and other precariously employed colleagues who have also been accepted to present at the conference, but did not receive sufficient funding, either from the NWSA or their employers.


The Impact

By supporting contingent faculty members, you will enable our conference participants to contribute to multi-session discussions on the theme of precarity at the 2016 NWSA conference. The participants are eager to collaborate with conference attendees - not only to make contingent faculty’s voices heard, but also to continue to implement actions that NWSA as a professional feminist organization  can take to address these issues in women’s and gender studies departments and programs in the academy.  

The outcomes of this effort (including this fundraising effort!) will help to ensure that conversations about the future of women’s and gender studies include all members of this diverse and ever-expanding discipline for years to come.  


The Nitty Gritty

$700 per person will get our participants to the conference. But we think we can raise even more funds! Every dollar we raise over the coverage of their expenses will be distributed to other contingent faculty members and precarious employed individuals who have not be able to access funding to attend the 2016 NWSA conference. 


Interested in Becoming More Involved?

Join the Contingent Faculty Interest Group (email gbeetham[at]gmail.com for more information). 

Going to be in Montreal? 

Attend one of several panels and business meetings at  NWSA’s 2016 conference that will engage contingency as a feminist issue.

story:
Isan Bamboo Library is a project, whose goal is to build a library made entirely of natural resources (Bamboo) in order to supply books to the local community of Si Sa Ket, Isan, in the northeast of Thailand and thereby provide access to learning and knowledge, otherwise not provided.

Tawan Sintipraksan (FB: Isan Bamboo Library / Kuaythai Chiangmai), a local to the region, yet currently living in Chiang Mai, is full of creative ideas and is fuelled by a desire to give back to his community in which he grew up in. So let’s help him to get started and realize his first project!



Six years ago I fell in love with Thailand and its hearty people. Throughout my travels all over the country I met many wonderful people. One of them is Tawan Sintipraksan, a wonderful soul and by now a very close and good friend. He’s full of energy and great ideas and is as well a very talented artist. Having himself grown up as a local farmer boy from Si Sa Ket, one of the poorest regions in the country, he now wants to give something back to his community he still feels strongly connected to. His plan is to build a hut made of the natural resource bamboo and create the first library in his hometown, the “Isan Bamboo Library”. His goal is to supply books for young and old so they can get information otherwise not accessible to them and read up on topics they’re curious about. He thereby wants to give them an opportunity to discover and expand the wonderful world of phantasy within their minds, as he so often does himself in his art and life.

Grateful to by now be considered a part of his family, them always giving me and my friends a home to stay when anyone of us is over there and simply because of all the good energy I receive from him and his friends, I want to give something back. I therefore provide him with help in writing texts in English, the collecting of books and the search for money required for funding the build of his bamboo hut.



So on behalf of my friends and me, as well as Tawan, I ask for your help. USD 700 are needed for now to build the first “Isan Bamboo Library”. If we can’t reach the target of USD 700, it doesn’t change anything about our plan, the bamboo library will be built anyway. We will just keep collecting until we get the rest together somehow over other channels. There are many people who believe in the project and will help bringing it to an end. But it would be amazing to have the support form you guys. Our vision is to create a community and reach goals collectively, to help out each other and feel happy to have achieved something together. If this applies to you too, then get in and be part of it!

In case we exceed the target of USD 700 there are other ideas to get started with respectively other Isan villages to set up another Isan Bamboo Library.

Of course you can also help by sending over some books to fill that little house with information and life from all around the globe!

Address to send your books to:

Isan Bamboo Library
57 M. 10 Ban Khoen, Nam Kliang
Si sa ket 33130
Thailand

Thank you so much for your time!
Hugs & love
Riana

story:
Update: 2/2/2015:

CCASF believes that Campbell University ROTC is the best program in the country – always has been, always will be.

We believe that reducing financial obstacles to cadets achieving their full academic and leadership potential will make them better leaders for the Army and CU ROTC will remain a national leader.

We provide scholarship money to CU cadets so they can reach their full potential.

You can help by donating.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

***Tax deductions***

Friends of CCASF, unfortunately, CCASF cannot guarantee that your donations through Indiegogo will be considered tax deductible because CCASF is not yet a 501(c)3.

However, after viewing our video, you can donate here directly to CU alumni affairs and those donations will be tax deductible. CCASF will receive the funds either way!

If you've been away from Buies Creek for a few years you may not know that: the Groc is gone, the ROTC department now sits next to the campus laundry and that there is a no-kidding Chick-Fil-A in the campus bookstore. Buies Creek has changed a little...

What hasn't changed is that cadets there need help in meeting their financial obligations...your donation to CCASF enables CU alumni to directly assist cadets in meeting those obligations. To date CCASF has given $3,000 directly to CU cadets. (Click here to see CU's newest president, Dr. J. Bradley Cree, discussing the budget and finance challenges our students and CU faces. )

In order for CCASF to enjoy a lasting, self-sustaining legacy of giving, however, CCASF needs to become a fully-funded endowment - this will allow CCASF to award $1,000 in scholarship money yearly into perpetuity without additional donations.

Please help us reach our goal!


Scholarships awarded in Spring 2015 will be given in memory of 2012 Camel Company Graduate 1LT Robert Kelly. More information on the 1LT Robert Kelly Foundation can be found here.

To learn more about CCASF, visit our Facebook page here. Or e-mail us at camelcompanyasf@gmail.com. 

The music for our video was scored by friend of CCASF John Schucker, find out more about John and his work here.

Thanks, Spread the word! Get involved!

Thanks,

CCASF Team

story:
Hello,

My name is Mathew and i am a twelfth grade student at Jefferson County Open School. My school is all about hands on work and doing community service. We go on many trips all around the country and do community service and learn life skills. This is my fourth year at Jefferson County Open School. I have been to Washington D.C., Tallahassee Florida and all around Colorado with my school. When i went to Florida i got to stay at the Tallahassee zoo and do community service there. We created enclosures, fixed and restored habitats at the zoo while also going out and experiencing florida. Each trip i take with the school is an amazing experience and i always learn so much. This year i could not pass up the opportunity to go out of the country for my first time.We will be leaving on the trip in January. While in Nicaragua i will be doing an assortment of things:
  • Staying on omatempa which is an island in the middle of lake Nicaragua, (Fun fact- Omatempa is two volcanos that came up out of the ocean)
  • On the island we will be staying will the local people in their homes.
  • My class and i will be doing community service on the island, mainly building a playground for the local kids.
  • We will also be doing other community service work like building new houses, new bathrooms, building rafts and anything else we can help with.
  • While there i will be working on my communication skills also because i am not fluent in spanish and they are.
  • We will also be doing some really amazing diving further down south. That will be great because i'v never been scuba diving before.
  • While there i will be learning all about the nicaraguan culture also.

I am very excited to go on this trip because it will be an experience of a life time. I will learn many things and will not get another opportunity like this when i am out of high school.

$1,500 Goal

The plane flight alone to Nicaragua is $780 dollars and the rest of the money goes toward the resources for the playground, getting scuba certified and donations to the people of omatempa for letting us stay in there homes with them.

The Impact

In Nicaragua there is more poverty than here in the U.S. and going there and helping build and fix things really means a lot to them and means a lot to me because i know i am helping them. Just building a playground is a really great thing for them because i remember playing on a playground as a kid and i loved it, its great to let those kids have that experience. I love to do these community service projects and have no problem getting dirty and helping out because it feels good to help others.

Risks & Challenges

I have never been out of the country so it is a bit scary for me to leave home. I am not fluent in spanish and hardly know a lot of spanish so going to a place where it is predominately spanish speaking is scary but i will pick up quickly and will use other ways to communicate.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some other ways that you can help is to spread the word and help me raise the money to go help and learn all about Nicaragua. Please do share with others and help me make this reality.

story:
The Story

We're going to help John continue his education.

When John was 12 years (now 14 years), he lost his dad, the breadwinner of the family. His mother was the only one taking care of him and his siblings. Due to the financial hardships that his family was battling he came to the city (Accra)  to sell sachet water at a lorry station in Accra called 'Circle' to enable him send some money to his mom and use the remaining to further his education.  John sleeps in the lorry station when he closes from selling the water and at dawn at about 3 am he wakes up to help travelers carry their luggage so they can give him some money. 

Humans of Ghana is raising funds to get John off the street, reunite him with his family and enable him go back to school and for his dream of becoming  a medical doctor a reality. 

It will cost us a total of GHc 15,000 to continue his Junior high school, Senior High School and put him and his family in a comfortable position. As the eldest child of five,  his access to education would go a long way to help his younger siblings to be inspired. LET'S HELP JOHN GO BACK TO SCHOOL!

story:
Off the Tepic Highway leaving Puerto Vallarta Mexico, there is a narrow sideroad that takes you to a place you may otherwise have missed that is the home to 43 of the sweetest kids you have ever met. Casa Hogar is appreciative of community donations and support. The children  love visits, hugs, and and can always use gifts like food, medicines and clothing.


My story: My name is Jan Erik Williams and I am a single dad of 2 young boys. I stumbled on Casa Hogar several years ago and found myself needing to visit. Puerto Vallarta is a beautiful town on the pacific coast of Mexico. When I first heard of Casa Hogar, I could not comprehend how this orphanage could be possible in this beautiful tourist town. But true to fact, it is there- my boys and I have now been to visit several times, each time bringing what we could to help.


For the last several years I have collected donated money, diapers, medical supplies, clothing and basic necessities like toothpaste and toothbrushes and brought it for the kids on my visits to PV. Its all I can do, and a drop in the bucket. Being a single dad myself it can be tough, but just imagine not having a mom or dad to stand behind you to make your day more special and provide you with some well deserved and needed necessities.


Casa Hogar is a lovely place, surroundings simple, clean and the people who come to volunteer full of love and care for these kids. The thing that will catch your attention the most is the sweetness of the kids wanting to just have you sit and play with them, spend time with them and perhaps give them a hug.


I think any financial donation you would make to help these kids would be absolutely wonderful, and most appreciated. I can tell you from personal experience that it is received gratefully and humbly.

Thank you for considering this possibility.

story:
Haute Africa

Since 2007, Haute Africa has been in the business of helping people help themselves.  To date, we have provided business education and consulting services to 195 small business owners in Guinea, West Africa.  These clients have used their new knowledge and skills to grow their businesses and create over 300 new jobs - jobs that provide families with income to pay for food, housing, education and contribute to the growth of the local economy.

Our Transition

In line with our mission of empowerment, this year Haute Africa will transition control of our organization to our current Program Manager, Ansoumane Camara.  Ansoumane is well prepared to tackle this challenge, as he served as a contract consultant for Haute Africa from 2006-2010 and was then named Program Manager in 2010.  After this final fundraising campaign, Haute Africa will suspend US fundraising operations indefinitely and rely on Ansoumane to locate funding for Haute Africa operations moving forward.  The relationships Ansoumane has built with key government agencies and nonprofit foundations should serve him well in this capacity. 

Yet the current Ebola outbreak stands to ruin our transition plan and our very organization...

Ebola Crisis

In March 2014, an Ebola outbreak started in the Forest Region of Guinea, near the town of N'Zerekore (which happens to be home to 40 of Haute Africa's clients).  Since March, there have been more than 21,000 reported cases of Ebola worldwide, and over 8,300 reported resulting deaths.  About 1,800 of these deaths have occurred in Guinea. 

In addition to the tragic toll in terms of human life, Ebola has brought Guinea and the surrounding region to a complete standstill in terms of business and economic development.  Large corporations and nonprofit foundations alike have suspended operations and pulled out their people.  Funding for anything other than Ebola (including education, infrastructure, agriculture, etc.) has all but dried up.  This has made Haute Africa's transition an especially difficult one, as the very government agencies and nonprofit foundations that Haute Africa will depend on moving forward have suspended their relevant funding.

What We Need

In order to be fair to Ansoumane and his family (including his wife Madina and daughter Fatoumata shown in the picture above) during our transition, we are raising funds for a "transition package" for Ansoumane to weather the Ebola outbreak and fund Haute Africa's operations from now until July 2015.  This amount comes to $4,100.  This campaign will also cover remaining fees and debts of $1,650, which will allow Haute Africa to close out US fundraising operations.

story:
Help this teacher achieve her lifetime educational goal.

  • I have been putting myself back through school from a bachelors to doctorate since being widowed at the young age of 31 (9 years ago) while working full time as a teacher and raising my son.
  • When my husband passed I changed careers from EMS Medic and Army Reserves to become a Middle School Math and Science teacher so I could best care for my son (then 7 yrs old), be home at night with him, and still give back to my community.
  • My life goal is to build and operate an all girls boarding school for unadopted pre-teens and teens to provide them a home, a family, and an education. To achieve that dream, I need to complete my doctorate in Teacher Leadership before that.

I need the kind help of strangers to make it to graduation! 

Currently I am writing my disseration and am scheduled to graduate by the end of December 2014. BUT I can't graduate if my tuition is not paid off! 

  • I currently have a tuition balance is $8,850 and if not paid by Dec 30th, I won't be able to graduate despite completing my dissertation. 
  • Any amount of funds received will go to pay down my tuition balance owing.

    My Track Record 

    • All of my life I have volunteered, participated in scouts, coached soccer, and many other community services events. I help friends, family, and strangers whenever I can.  
    • I have always put my family and my son's needs first which is why I am struggling to pay the balance of my doctoral tuition. 
    • I started this journey with an associates degree and EMT license. I completed my bachelors in 2007 and then my masters in 2010. Now I am done with all my doctoral classes and halfway completed my dissertation.  

    My Challenge

    • My only challenge is coming up with the tuition balance... my dissertation is on track, my chair and committee members are taking great care of my and supporting me at every turn... 
    • With YOUR help I will be able to achieve my goal and over come my challenge of paying off my tuition.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    As an educator, I also have created many great and unique activities for students to use in the classroom. I have 124 products in my e-store on Teachers Pay Teachers. I earn 80% on every sale and have been using those sales too also help pay down my tuition. 

    • If you are a teacher or know other teachers, please share news of my e-store at www.actvitiestoteach.com... Every sale counts... 

    • Please share news of my campaign, I appreciate the help searching out kindness from strangers to help my complete my education. 

    • Please remember you can use Indiegogo share tools to help me share news!

    Thank you for your time considering my campaign and your generous contribution... every $5 and $10 donation (or sale at my e-store) adds up....

story:
I am Avani, an Earth Protector, ambassador of Forum Terra and I love to plant trees! 

I wrote a illustrated  book that teaches the steps to plant trees, make seed balls and create tree nurseries with recycled materials.

I have 30 days to raise 800 euros and make this dream come true.  

This money is to pay the book production costs.

I work with children so I care a lot about the future of humankind on this planet.

My dream is to publish my book very soon.

I am blessed and grateful to meet beautiful souls on the Earth that help me to create some wonderful things for a better world.  

One of them is Maria João Lopes, a great illustrator, that made beautiful illustrations for this book. 

To every person who can kindly contribute I will acknowledge and thank you in the book. 

One of the prefaces of my book is from a beautiful friend with a celestial divine voice:

“I love trees. The fact that we humans have the ability to help a young tree grow in its most favorable conditions is such a great gift. Planting new native trees in a natural and loving way is one of the most important things we can contribute to the health of this wonderful planet as well as to our health. Witnessing Avani planting a tree in Costa Rica showed me this passion. Thank you, Avani, for encouraging us and helping to make our home greener. “                           Deva Premal

story:
Tell me and I will forget... 

Show me and I will remember... 

Involve me and I will understand.

This september I'm running 10 Miles (Dam tot Damloop in Amsterdam) to raise money for Source Connenction. An organization who assist farmers in Zambia in establishing food security by training them to become more self-supplying and less dependent on aid institutions. I believe this is the only way to really help the people in Zambia. 

Please help me raise enough money to make a difference!


All about Source Connection

Since 2001 the Source Connection Foundation supports local communities in rural Zambia. We're fighting poverty by transferring knowledge. We have empowered the people in Simonga by the development of a 'Community-based Sustainable Tourism' project, we started drinking water projects in Mandia and Katombora and we developed a minor agriculture project in both areas. 

Since 2012 we advanced our efforts to support agriculture in the region by the provision of skills and knowledge through our local partner Farming God´s Way. On behalf of and together with local communities we work to improve agriculture skills, gain food security and economic development by access to the (local) food market for a better future with lasting results.


So why should you support this initiative?

In order to answer that we would like to quote from a recent article regarding Conservation Agriculture in IPS News , wherein the Chef of the World Food Program Mr. Cousin states: “we have the solution in our hands". The article discusses the current drought and food scarcity in Zambia and proposes Conservation Agriculture as being THE solution. It explains how the method embraces minimal soil disruption and more variation in crop growing. When growing more different types of crops, a farmer is less dependent on the success of one harvest alone. Also, while disrupting the soil less, the soil is better equipped to handle heavy rainfall and thus able to prevent flooding that could destroy crops.

This recent Global News article thus builds upon what SourceConnection has been a firm believer in for years. Conservation Agriculture is THE future for farmers. Not only for Zambian farmers, but also for farmers in other African countries which are facing the same climate issues.


Curious?

Get more info or just enjoy more pictures and stories at:

https://www.facebook.com/SourceConnection 

http://sourceconnection.nl

http://www.ipsnews.be/artikel/klimaatslimme-landbouw-zal-voedselramp-zambia-voorkomen


Ready to support?

Please help me raise enough money to make a difference! And tell your friends about it, all support is welcome:

IBAN: NL69 INGB 0009 279932  Stichting SourceConnection in Amsterdam (please note Dam tot Damloop)

story:
_______________________________________________

$2,018 for #DiversityInTech in 2018 

_______________________________________________

Let's #PressForProgress together. 

There are a number of inspiring non-profits bringing more underrepresented folks into tech, and they need our support.  Let's make this year a little easier for them. Donate through this campaign, and 100% of proceeds go to the non-profit you select.

If you donate more than $50 you get a Find My Flock hoodie! 

_______________________________________________

Why is this an issue?  

_______________________________________________

Tech is changing our world at an ever-increasing pace and we have an ethical imperative to make sure everybody is involved. At the moment, they are not. 

  • Black people, Latinos, and Native Americans are underrepresented in tech by 16 to 18 percentage points compared with their presence in the US labor force overall (WIRED).
  • Women hold only 26% of computing occupations, down from 36% in 1991 (NCWIT).

  • The numbers are even more dismal for folks at the intersection of many forms of underrepresentation. Black women hold only 3% of tech positions and Latinas hold only 1%.

If you're curious as to why this may be happening, we made you this infographic:

  


(CREDIT: WIRED)

And of course, these are only a few of the many groups seeking inclusion in our industry. We stand for inclusion of people of all sexualities, classes, physical abilities and religions. 

_______________________________________________

What You Get.

_______________________________________________

One of the comfiest hoodies in all of startup land. We asked around. We conducted a poll. We tried some on. You're going to like it. 

The hoodie is a grey BELLA + CANVAS Triblend Sponge Fleece Full-Zip Hoodie. 

Sizes are unisex and range from S - 2XL. You will select your size and your preferred recipient non-profit in the check-out form. All hoodies have the Find My Flock logo on the left chest and a sweet break-the-glass-ceiling image on the back. Here's a picture: 

Here's a close-up of the design on the back: 

BONUS: 100% of proceeds are going to the non-profit you choose, so you also get to sleep better tonight for having done a good thing. 

You can also choose to donate without a hoodie (see options to the right) and conserve even more cash for the non-profit. 

_______________________________________________

Who are the non-profits I can choose to donate to? 

_______________________________________________

We could not be more excited to educate you about these groups. The best part is YOU get to choose which one calls most to your heart for us to send YOUR money to!

  • Blind Institute of Technology:  Addressing an attitude shift for blind professionals and educating companies on how to hire and cultivate success for the visually impaired.
  • Code 2040: A community of Black and Latinx technologists and their allies who are diversifying tech to create a more equitable, inclusive, and prosperous economy.
  • Girl Develop It: Provides affordable and judgment-free opportunities for women interested in learning web and software development.
  • Women Who Startup: A learning platform for a global community of female entrepreneurs and innovators.

If you can't make up your mind at checkout, just click  'undecided' and we'll split it up between them. 

_______________________________________________

Who is Find My Flock?

_______________________________________________

Seriously today is not about us. Not a single dime from this campaign will go to Flock. But if you're curious... 

Find My Flock is a tech recruiting agency that only partners with inclusive companies. Everyone placed through our network receives 6-months of follow-up career coaching. 

We do that because while 74% of technical women report "loving their work", 56% are leaving the industry mid-career (NCWIT).

Why? The most commonly cited reason is unsupportive work environments. Only 20% actually drop out of the workforce, and even those 20% indicate they would stay if they had another option. 

Our mission is to boost retention rates for underrepresented folks in tech by channeling developers to companies that deserve them. If you're interested, you can read more here.
story_txt:
_______________________________________________
$2,018 for #DiversityInTech in 2018 
_______________________________________________
Let's #PressForProgress together. 
There are a number of inspiring non-profits bringing more underrepresented folks into tech, and they need our support.  Let's make this year a little easier for them. Donate through this campaign, and 100% of proceeds go to the non-profit you select.
If you donate more than $50 you get a Find My Flock hoodie! 
_______________________________________________
Why is this an issue?  
_______________________________________________Tech is changing our world at an ever-increasing pace and we have an ethical imperative to make sure everybody is involved. At the moment, they are not. 

Black people, Latinos, and Native Americans are underrepresented in tech by 16 to 18 percentage points compared with their presence in the US labor force overall (WIRED).


Women hold only 26% of computing occupations, down from 36% in 1991 (NCWIT).

The numbers are even more dismal for folks at the intersection of many forms of underrepresentation. Black women hold only 3% of tech positions and Latinas hold only 1%.
If you're curious as to why this may be happening, we made you this infographic:  (CREDIT: WIRED)And of course, these are only a few of the many groups seeking inclusion in our industry. We stand for inclusion of people of all sexualities, classes, physical abilities and religions. _______________________________________________
What You Get.
_______________________________________________
One of the comfiest hoodies in all of startup land. We asked around. We conducted a poll. We tried some on. You're going to like it. 
The hoodie is a grey BELLA + CANVAS Triblend Sponge Fleece Full-Zip Hoodie. 
Sizes are unisex and range from S - 2XL. You will select your size and your preferred recipient non-profit in the check-out form. All hoodies have the Find My Flock logo on the left chest and a sweet break-the-glass-ceiling image on the back. Here's a picture: 

Here's a close-up of the design on the back: 

BONUS: 100% of proceeds are going to the non-profit you choose, so you also get to sleep better tonight for having done a good thing. 
You can also choose to donate without a hoodie (see options to the right) and conserve even more cash for the non-profit. 
_______________________________________________
Who are the non-profits I can choose to donate to? 
_______________________________________________
We could not be more excited to educate you about these groups. The best part is YOU get to choose which one calls most to your heart for us to send YOUR money to!


Blind Institute of Technology:  Addressing an attitude shift for blind professionals and educating companies on how to hire and cultivate success for the visually impaired.

Code 2040: A community of Black and Latinx technologists and their allies who are diversifying tech to create a more equitable, inclusive, and prosperous economy.

Girl Develop It: Provides affordable and judgment-free opportunities for women interested in learning web and software development.

Women Who Startup: A learning platform for a global community of female entrepreneurs and innovators.

If you can't make up your mind at checkout, just click  'undecided' and we'll split it up between them. 
_______________________________________________
Who is Find My Flock?_______________________________________________Seriously today is not about us. Not a single dime from this campaign will go to Flock. But if you're curious... Find My Flock is a tech recruiting agency that only partners with inclusive companies. Everyone placed through our network receives 6-months of follow-up career coaching. We do that because while 74% of technical women report "loving their work", 56% are leaving the industry mid-career (NCWIT). Why? The most commonly cited reason is unsupportive work environments. Only 20% actually drop out of the workforce, and even those 20% indicate they would stay if they had another option. Our mission is to boost retention rates for underrepresented folks in tech by channeling developers to companies that deserve them. If you're interested, you can read more here.

story: In January, the Harvard Philippine Forum sends around 15 undergraduates to the Philippines on a community service trip in collaboration with two non-profit organizations: The Stairway Foundation (a rehabilitation center for physically and sexually abused street children) and Childhope Asia (which develops education programs for street children). In the past Harvard students have taught workshops to a group of around 30 street children on anything from dance to singing to nutrition to hygiene. Since then, the number of children we work with has nearly doubled and our involvement with the local community has increased. With the support of and space provided by Emilio Aguinaldo College in Manila we have also organized and executed a final performance showcasing the children’s talents to the local community to build their self esteem and confidence.

story:
Hello everybody. It’s me AJ you know from the block.

4 years ago I started to critalize my dream, which was my carreer i was so exited cause it took me a long time to get to there, it was so hard. 4 years ago i finished high school with the highest score which allowed to get a scholarship in one of the best college in Mexico. 

It was september 2013 when i got my admissión for Marketing and Advertising in TecMilenio University, I was freacked out and excited at the same time. I was like i was like, fasten your seat belt it’s gonna be a bumpy ride. I knew i was gonna have work it, well, you know what i mean…

I moved to Puerto Vallarta a couple of months later and I started to work so hard to pay part of the tuition cuz the scholarship was just 90% out of it. 

2 years later, it was 2015 the college ask me to do a project for a business and unfortunately i couln’t finish, i fail it and I lost 40% of my scholarship, The University and I were paying 50/50, that set me in a tough position, cuz the tuition of TecMilenio is not that cheap at all. But i couldn’t stop i knew had to finish my career, I was focused on my goal.

My career helped to improve my persona, since the very first begining my career changed my perception of life. It has helped me to be a real profesional, well i have always been, and this has given me the real change in my life.

I'm pretty close to finish it, just 1 more month and that’s it, however, i need to pay some expenses such as 

  • last quarter tuition ($11 000 MXN)
  • graduation ($3 500 MXN)
  • degree licence and certificate ( $7 000 MXN)
  • documentation for degree ($2 000 MXN)

All these expenses amounted to $23 500 thousand pesos or $1400 US. and i wanna ask you  the biggets favor ever, please support me to get it, I don’t wanna go back to the streets (hahaha)

In order to make this happen, look, i have great rewards for you guys. 

  • Porn postcards, (obviously me on it)
  • Lunch dates, maybe more than that
  • Tequila
  • Live impersonations of Cher and Bette Middle, I mean just for fun.
  • I can cook some of my famous Hindu meals you know they’re very famous.
  • And little cactus plants

Now imagine me guys with a degree, everybody would be like: "who’s that cutie?", "- oh it’s AJ the smartypants-",  "oh look at that, It’s AJ, the marketing guy, Mister Know it all". 

Seriously, I can’t do it without you guys, i really need your support, please please help me, and if you can’t afford even a dollar please send me all your good energy and help to to share this video with all your friends, so I can get my goal!

Thank you!

story:
Chi sono io: 

Mi chiamo Sara Lando, e da più di 10 anni lavoro come fotografa e giro il mondo insegnando fotografia.
Quando l'estate scorsa la mia pagina di Facebook è stata invasa di bufale sugli immigrati ho pensato che mi sarebbe piaciuto approfondire l'argomento e ho contattato Casa a Colori, un'associazione di Bassano del Grappa che da 25 anni lavora sul territorio fornendo supporto ai migranti e ai cittadini su tematiche che riguardano  l'integrazione, la formazione e l'intercultura. Non sono una fotogiornalista e non avrebbe avuto senso per me portare avanti un progetto documentario, ma nel corso dei mesi mi sono accorta di quanto manchi in questo momento una rappresentazione fotografica dei richiedenti asilo che li veda come individui, fotografati non come testimonianza ma in quanto soggetti, persone che non vogliono essere necessariamente mostrate per educare gli altri o come esempio dei problemi del mondo, ma che vogliono -come chiunque- una foto in cui si riconoscono e si vedono belli. 

Chi è Casa a Colori

Casa a Colori nasce nel 1992 su iniziativa di un gruppo di volontari che operavano all’Istituto Scalabrini di Bassano del Grappa per dare un aiuto concreto ai migranti che in quegli anni iniziavano ad arrivare numerosi principalmente dal nord Africa e dai paesi dell’est.

Inizialmente sorta per tentare di risolvere il problema alloggiativo con la creazione di centri di prima e di seconda accoglienza, successivamente si è impegnata sul fronte della formazione e dell’intercultura realizzando corsi di alfabetizzazione e per l’inserimento lavorativo e sul fronte della tutela degli immigrati aprendo uno sportello informazioni.

Attualmente l’associazione opera su più fronti e non solo in favore degli immigrati, nonostante nei loro confronti sia ancora maggiormente rivolta la loro attenzione.

Cosa ci serve e Cosa ti arriva

Dal 17 Marzo al 2 Aprile, per celebrare i 25 anni di Casa a Colori, allestiremo una mostra fotografica a ingresso libero. Abbiamo chiesto di poter avere un piccolo spazio per esporre qualche foto, ci hanno messo a disposizione Palazzo Bonaguro nella sua interezza. 

I soldi raccolti serviranno a stampare una quarantina di stampe su stoffa 100x140 con i ritratti in bianco e nero, una serie di immagini a colori che illustrano le attività dell'associazione, i materiali di supporto alla mostra (inviti, cartelloni, locandine...), ad acquistare le cornici e a coprire le spese dell'inaugurazione, per evitare di chiedere alla gente di portarsi le patatine e l'aranciata amara da casa. 


Il mio lavoro e quello delle persone che stanno lavorando a questa mostra non verrà riconosciuto in termini economici, e le birre che devo alle persone che mi hanno dato una mano nel corso di questo progetto escono tutte dalle mie tasche.

Perché il crowdfunding

La cosa più ovvia per coprire i costi di questa operazione sarebbe stata cercare una o più aziende che facessero da sponsor. Abbiamo però pensato che potesse essere più importante e significativo coinvolgere i cittadini di Bassano (e perché no, anche quelli che non vivono qui) e mostrare in modo tangibile che esistono persone che riconoscono il valore della diversità e dell'accoglienza e che non siamo circondati solo di intolleranza e rifiuto del diverso. 
Vogliamo dare alle persone la possibilità di partecipare a un'iniziativa in cui si possa celebrare qualcosa di bello e non soltanto intervenire per far fronte a un'emergenza. 
Vogliamo festeggiare e vogliamo farlo insieme a voi: voi che conoscete Casa a Colori e voi che non ne avete mai sentito parlare, ma magari avete in mente una gita a Bassano a metà marzo. Voi che siete informati sulle problematiche legate all'immigrazione e voi che vorreste saperne di più.
E anche voi a cui non frega niente della mostra ma volete farvi fare un ritratto da me o mangiare una cena etnica: la nostra gratitudine non diminuisce di un millimetro. 

Cosa succede se superiamo l'obiettivo?

Per l'allestimento di questa mostra abbiamo cercato di "stringere un pochino la cinghia" e scelto  soluzioni il più possibile economiche, senza dover rinunciare completamente alla qualità: questo perché ci piacerebbe poter superare l'obiettivo e usare i fondi raccolti in questo modo per creare dei laboratori fotografici. 
La fotografia è uno strumento potentissimo di comunicazione e nel corso dell'ultimo decennio ho potuto vedere sul campo come una macchina fotografica sappia creare ponti e raccontare storie anche per persone che credono di non avere una voce. 
L'idea è quella di non creare delle iniziative esclusive per i richiedenti asilo, ma degli spazi aperti anche ai cittadini italiani, in cui si possa collaborare a progetti comuni, pensati nell'ottica di integrazione e confronto.
A seconda di quanti soldi verranno raccolti saranno iniziative piccole o un po' più importanti, ma mi piacerebbe che fosse comunque l'inizio di qualcosa da fare crescere nel tempo. 

Come puoi aiutarci

Ovviamente il modo più diretto di aiutarci è quello di dare un contributo economico, selezionando una delle reward che trovi qui a fianco. Se non ti è possibile puoi sempre aiutarci passando parola il più possibile: condividi il link usando gli strumenti di condivisione che Indiegogo ti mette e disposizione, parlane con gli sconosciuti mentre fai la fila in posta, e vieni a festeggiare con noi il 17 marzo!
