Amber is a proud Hufflepuff who enjoys using her love of numbers to help make the world a better place. With ten years of experience in nonprofit accounting, Amber oversees the HPA's Finance and Human Resources Departments. She holds a B.A. in Mathematics and an M.S. in Accounting.Janae Phillips, Director of Leadership & Education. In her ten years as a program designer and community organizer Janae has been a passionate advocate for creating more playful, engaging leadership training. She manages the HPA’s chapters program, which spans six continents, is the architect behind their immersive story-based leadership retreat, and is their lead curriculum writer. Janae holds a B.S. in Family Studies and Human Development, concentration in Leadership Studies and Practice, and an M.S. in Educational Technology.Katie Bowers, Campaigns Director. As the Campaigns Director for the Harry Potter Alliance, Katie has organized thousands of fans across the globe to make a difference on gender equity, LGBTQ+ rights, literacy, access to education, and more. Her favorite part of working for the HPA is seeing our creative, enthusiastic members shaping their communities! A Ravenclaw hoping to do some good, Katie has been integrating her love of pop culture and social justice through organizing initiatives and experiential education since 2005.  Matt Maggiacomo, Executive Director. In 2005, Matt accidentally fell down the rabbit hole of Harry Potter fandom and hasn’t emerged since. After spending five years touring the United States, Canada, and Europe with his wizard rock band, The Whomping Willows, Matt landed his first job at the Harry Potter Alliance in 2013. As the HPA’s first Chapters Director, Matt fostered the creation of Granger Leadership Academy and led the expansion of HPA Chapters across six continents. Matt has served as the HPA's Executive Director since January 2015. He earned a B.A. in English from UMASS-Amherst in 2001.

story:
WHAT CAN I DO WITH INTELLISAURUS?

Intellisaurus is intended for many skill levels. The easy to follow instructions allow someone with a modest skill level to assemble the robot and have it walking in a matter of hours. There is no soldering or programming required to build and play with it. With a little more in-depth involvement you can connect the AI hardware and enable Google Assistant or Alexa. Impress your friends with a smart speaker that also walks. If you consider yourself a true maker or hacker then get into the Source code and modify it. Or, customize the shell in your favorite 3D modeling software and print new parts. You decide!

Intellisaurus is an Open Source quadruped walking robot kit.

This fun loving guy reaches 8 inches tall. He sports an Arduino Nano to control the motors and a Raspberry Pi Zero W to connect to the internet and run Google Assistant, or other various AI algorithms. He walks he talks he struts his stuff! Its all within the reach of your imagination! This versatile frame can wear different shells such as Triceratops, Stegosaurus, or Dragon, each sold, or created on your 3D printer, separately. All open source software, so you are in control, modify, and improve your Intellisaurus to satisfy your Inner Maker.

  • Good in Schools - Classroom friendly projects
  • Good in Maker Spaces - All open Source means various levels of build and modify
  • Good for individual maker looking to increase their mechanical knowledge and understanding
  • Good for a 3D printer exploration or learning how to make parts for a finished use
  • Good for a programmer looking to expand their Artificial Intelligence skills
  • Good for a robotics enthusiast wanting to learn mechanics, and or software development
  • Good as just cooler version of Smart Speaker.
  • Good for YOU or YOUR GEEK LOVED ONE! 

FLEXIBLE BUILD OPTIONS

The Intellisaurus comes in three separate kits. So you can choose to purchase only what you need.

Base Kit

The base kit includes all you need to build the robot. All the electronics, sensors, servos, screws and other items are included (except the two 18650 batteries). All the plastic parts with necessary screws and bolts. The only tools you need is one small Philips screw driver.

This kit includes an IR remote controller, to allow you to control the robots movements directly, without any of the Artificial Intelligence features

Animal Shell – Package

Buy a shell pre-printed or download files and print your own. The shell adds weight to the head and tail which is necessary to balance well while walking.

These shells are provided as a downloadable STL files. So you can print or even modify them. Print in you favorite color. Use your favorite 3D software to customize the shell.

There are three shells to choose from, Triceratops, Dragon, or Stegosaurus.

Artificial Intelligence – Package

Get this bundle of Raspberry Pi, audio hat, speaker, and camera to create an intelligent robot that sees, speaks and understands. You do not need this Package to have the robot walk. The Base Kit includes an Arduino and IR controller which can control the basic walking motions. The Raspberry Pi in this Package sends high level commands tell the Arduino which way to turn and where to go.

This kit does not include an SD card reader for your computer. To make the most out of this kit you will need to connect the Raspberry Pi to your own monitor, keyboard, and mouse. There is a SD card reader on the Raspberry Pi.

 

Learn Electronics of a walking robot

The electronics of Intellisaurus intentionally uses standard parts used in many types of robots. Using things like standard I2C bus you can add more sensors. When you learn how this one goes together you will be that much closer to building your own designs.  The basic block diagram of this robot could be used with many different robot designs.

Learn to Program a Walking Robot

Get in and modify the quadruped walking code. All the software is Open Source. You’ve been watching those videos of Boston Dynamics robots. This is your chance to learn some of that! The code included in the Intellisaurus kit is fully functional, so you don’t have to know how to program a walking robot. But, if you want to, the world would love to see you make improvements and share them.

To modify your Intellisaurus programming does require that you are comfortable with the Arduino development environment. The code base is not simple, it required months of development. Modification of the walking code is not intended for the beginner. We provide a base of code that actually works as a walking quadruped. We intend for you, the experienced programmer, to get in and modify it.

Learn Artificial Intelligence

When you include the Artificial Intelligence Package you can build an intelligent robot that sees, speaks and understands. Then you can reprogram it, and reach new intellisaurus heights!
With the Raspberry Pi, audio hat, speaker, and camera, you can experiment with Google’s neural network APIs and create intelligence.
Use the camera and Google’s Vision API to see faces, detect emotions and recognize common objects. Then the robot can react to that knowledge, like turning and walking towards a face, or avoiding vegetables.
Use the microphone and speaker to allow your robot to respond to voice commands. Or use the Google Assistant API to build an intelligent robot that can understand you, and respond when you ask it a question, or tell it to do something.

COMPLETE AND CLEAR INSTRUCTIONS

Each instruction package will be delivered as a Video, online instructions and a downloadable PDF. These instructions will be easy to follow and thorough enough to allow a deep understanding. These instructions are for every experience level. this can be your first robot build or your 100th, these instructions aim to get you a satisfactory build experience. Our goal is to inspire you to stretch yourself to modify and build different things based on these ideas. You are in control, modify, and improve your Intellisaurus to satisfy your Inner Maker.

Assembling the Base Kit Frame
This is a walkthrough of assembling the acrylic frame. How to mount the electronics are included in this video, while the innards of the robot are still open.


Assembling the Base Kit Electronics
With the frame already assembled, this walkthrough  shows you how to connect the electronics together. There is no soldering required. Everything is connected with standard jumper wires. However it is wise to follow this closely so none of the wires get crossed.  Connecting full power to the wrong place can damage the electronics.


Assembling the Leg Mechanisms and Servo Calibration
Once the frame and  base kit electronics are installed it is time to add the legs. The final stage of adding the legs includes calibrating the servos. A helpful stand for the robot doubles as a guide to make calibrating the servos easy.


Adding Artificial Intelligence Package electronics to Base Kit
So you want to make your Intellisaurus smart. This walkthrough shows you how to connect the AI Package parts.


3D printing your own shell
If you didn’t buy the shell parts then you will need to print your own. This means you have access to a 3D printer. This walkthrough gives you guidance and helpful hints on how to best print the shell parts on your own printer.


Adding the shell parts to the basic kit
Now that your Intellisaurus is structurally sound and likely intelligent, let's make it look cool too. This walk through shows you how to add the shell parts to the robot. 


Understanding quadruped walking algorithms of Intellisaurus
This is a walkthrough of specifically the Arduino code. We talk about the outline of the code and how it all fits together. We also point out some areas that you might want to improve.


Getting started with Voice Recognition Commands
This walkthrough requires the AI Package. We will get your Intellisaurus connected to the internet. Using a Google Voice API to recognize voice commands, we will have your robot react to those commands. 
This walkthrough requires that you connect the Raspberry Pi to your own monitor and keyboard.  


Adding Google Assistant to Intellisaurus
This walkthrough requires the AI Package. We will get your Intellisaurus connected to the internet and using a Google Assistant API. Now you can ask your robot questions and it will answer you. 
This walkthrough requires that you connect the Raspberry Pi to your own monitor and keyboard.  

Adding Amazon Alexa to Intellisaurus
This walkthrough requires the AI Package. We will get your Intellisaurus connected to the internet and using a Amazon Alexa API. I am betting all your friends will envy your Intellisaurus robot Alexa speaker, as it is a way cooler smart speaker than whatever they have. 
This walkthrough requires that you connect the Raspberry Pi to your own monitor and keyboard.  

Getting started with Face and Object Recognition to Intellisaurus
This walkthrough requires the AI Package. We will get your Intellisaurus connected to the internet and using a Google Object Recognition API. We will then use object or face recognition to implement a “Follow Me” behavior
This walkthrough requires that you connect the Raspberry Pi to your own monitor and keyboard.

Jacquin Buchanan

Jacquin has 30 years experience in product development. He has been the director of Software Development for multiple startup companies. He has been involved in the full product development life cycle including manufacturing, electronics and software development.

Jacquin Buchanan is a fountain of ideas and projects, which often ensnare and inspire those around him. Way back in College he was an aspiring sculptor who instead choose to pursue his other passion of computer science. Intellisaurus is a way for him to reignite some of his passion for sculpture and design and mix it with his extensive engineering experience.  

In 1991, Jacquin was a founder of in-sync, the digital video editing software company which made Speed Razor one of the original nonlinear digital video editors.

He has enjoyed directing software development with Voxtec International Inc. We built the first handheld, speech to speech, natural language translator, the Phraselator. Then went on to improve it. The SQ.410 is as close to a handheld universal translator as anyone has gotten.

He relocated recently to Fort Collins, Colorado, where he lives, loves, and chants with his artist wife and his talkative son.

Delivery Schedule

I am very confident in the design of this robot. All the prototypes function well. All the electronics are relatively standard, and don't require any new boards to be manufactured. I am not sure how timely certain suppliers will be with a couple of the parts, so I have given a little extra time for this in expected delivery dates. 

Most of the effort from now to delivery will be completing the dozen instructional videos. This is relatively low risk work, and should not impact delivery schedules. I have many ideas for more instructional videos of projects that can be done with this kit. So, expect a continuous flow of potential projects.

story:
Our Child, Not Yours is a non-profit civil liberties law firm protecting the Constitutional rights of all parents - married and unmarried, mothers and fathers, by relying only upon the U. S. Constitution.  A non-partisan unaffilated entity, Our Child, Not Yours does not use a standard or doctrine other than the Constitution's fundamental right of parents to raise their own children without government interference.

Our Child, Not Yours will fight against the erroneous claim of government that it has the authority to intrude upon and interfere with the right of parents to raise their own children. How? By standing side by side with parents and their children through carefully selected litigation that will protect the right of the parent or parents with whom we join AND, as a result, also for other parents and their families by the precedential impact and the deterrent impact!

 Illustrations of government’s overreaching:

 1.  A child is hurt and an insurance company offers to settle the claim.  The parents must get court approval, that is, permission, by first paying a filing fee.  The court may appoint a “guardian ad litem” who is paid by the parents and, depending on the amount, the parents must post a bond, open a separate bank account and cannot use the money even for the child without seeking and getting court permission.

 2.  Two parents who are divorcing agree on a parenting plan including all of the custody terms for their children, but the court can reject the plan of the parents and, instead, substitute the judge’s own parenting plan that the judge thinks is better for the child than the plan of the child’s own parents.

 3.  In 2007, Texas mandated by executive order from the governor that all females entering the sixth grade receive the HPV vaccine, with some exceptions.  Later overridden by the Texas legislature, concerns were raised about the drug's cost, safety, and parents' rights to refuse for any reason including moral objections related to a vaccine mandate for a sexually transmitted disease.

 4.  In 2012, in North Carolina, a school confiscated the turkey on whole-wheat sandwich and the other items of a home-packed lunch and gave the student the cafeteria lunch because the home-packed lunch did not meet the school’s nutritional requirements.  The child did not eat the chicken nuggets she was given.  The child was not in medical need, was not nutritionally deficient, and neither obese nor underweight. 

Through carefully selected legal actions to start or to join, through the education of the public and public servants, and through research and analysis, Our Child, Not Yours will protect the constitutional rights of parents – all parents, married or unmarried, mothers and fathers, to raise their children free from the mandates and prohibitions of government except as is constitutionally permitted to keep children from harm, which is a legitimate and constitutionally permitted purpose of government. To further this mission, Our Child, Not Yours also will advise and guide parents who are battling government and will educate and train law students, attorneys and those advancing the cause of freedom to parent one’s own children in the methods of such public interest activism.

After determining that no other entity seeks to protect the rights of all parents by using only the Untied States Constitution as its guide, Our Child, Not Yours was founded to be the civil liberties law firm that will do so.  Though a “law firm,” it is a non-profit law firm where the attorneys advising parents and litigating for them will do so without being paid exorbitantly, but reasonably as set by an unpaid Board of Directors, comprised of parents, Moms and Dads.  Our Child, Not Yours will undertake innovative litigation in the state and federal courts and will influence public attitudes on behalf of parents whose Constitutional rights are to be protected from infringement by the government.

Of course, if a child is being harmed, it is constitutionally permissible for the government to intervene. In all other circumstances, Our Child, Not Yours will sue the government and individuals acting on behalf of the government when either unconstitutionally takes away or attempts to take away the rights of a parent to raise her or his child or children as the parent wishes.

The funding being raised will permit Our Child, Not Yours to take on cases and walk the walk, not just talk the talk.  The funds will pay for the website, costs of raising public awareness, and a period of modest overhead permitting Our Child, Not Yours to move from idea to action.

The impact will be most realized for the parents and their children represented by Our Child, Not Yours.  But the trickle-down impact will be dramatic for all parents and all children.  Taxpayers will benefit by the restrictions put in place to stop the expansion of government into micromanaging parents in their efforts to raise their own children.  Personal liberties will be restored for parents doing a fine job with their children.  Resources wasted in overseeing good parents can be reallocated to help children in need, children being hurt, abused or neglected where government rightfully should intercede.  You can make a difference – today and in the years and decades to come.

If you donate or if you don't, please follow our efforts by joining our email list and "Like" us on Facebook.

As a new non-profit, an application for 501(c)(3) status is being filed with the IRS. If approved, the IRS exemption is retroactive to the date of organization. Because our mission statement is “To Protect the Constitutional Rights of Parents,” after review of the 501 (c) (3) guidelines and consultation with independent sources (including a prominent 501 (c) (3) that is our model), we are confident of IRS approval.

story:
As part of the 'Face of Newcastle' modelling competition it is the job of the contestants to try and raise as much money as possible for the chosen charity, the Rainbow Child Foundation. The Rainbow Child Foundation (registered charity No. 42369857) is a non-profit organisation that helps underprivileged children all over the world in a variety of ways.The charity was founded by singer Chico Slimani, his wife Daniyela Rakic and his brother, actor JC Mac, and concentrates on providing water, food and shelter in countries which are less fortunate than ours.

I'm asking for YOUR help to raise as much money as possible to contribute towards this, and even something as little as donating 50p would all help. As well as creating this page, I am also planning on running various charity auctions, doing some car boot sales and hopefully organising a selections of events to contribute towards the cause. Thankyou all for your time :)
story_txt:
As part of the 'Face of Newcastle' modelling competition it is the job of the contestants to try and raise as much money as possible for the chosen charity, the Rainbow Child Foundation. The Rainbow Child Foundation (registered charity No. 42369857) is a non-profit organisation that helps underprivileged children all over the world in a variety of ways.The charity was founded by singer Chico Slimani, his wife Daniyela Rakic and his brother, actor JC Mac, and concentrates on providing water, food and shelter in countries which are less fortunate than ours. 
I'm asking for YOUR help to raise as much money as possible to contribute towards this, and even something as little as donating 50p would all help. As well as creating this page, I am also planning on running various charity auctions, doing some car boot sales and hopefully organising a selections of events to contribute towards the cause. Thankyou all for your time :)

story:
Short Summary

On 9/11 I was at the top of my field as an IT manager at a Fortune 500 company. My company saw the tragedy as a reason to cut back on personell. Needless to say - I as middle management took a fall.

I moved 1200 miles to take an office manager job shortly there after. After two years working in a financial institution - once again, this time because of the economy - I took a fall.

I then moved 900 miles for work. In 2010 - that business collapsed.

Two years ago, my mom became ill, so I have been caring for her the last two years, up to her death two weeks ago. I have now decided that at 55 years old, I need to have a CAREER that doesn't depend on anyone but myself, and I have chosen photo journalism, since photography has always been a passionate hobby for me. It's time my passion became my life work!

story:
The Orpheum Children’s Science Museum is excited to announce an opportunity to help us bring the next great exhibit to the children of our community! We can’t wait to introduce our newest bright idea, one that we think will really add some sparkle to the experiences our 25,000 visitors have each year.

The Orpheum wants to bring a new exhibit - Light Bright Create - to the Museum, but we need your help to do it!

Covering over 300 square-feet, our exhibit will feature a 6 foot by 4 foot Giant Light Bright Create! With room for nearly 1000 colored pegs, the exhibit will empower children to create vibrant designs, investigate color combinations, and play with patterns on a grand scale. This low-pressure environment will encourage children to experiment, boosting confidence in the ability to take something from their imagination and create it.

Constructed from colored acrylic rods, wood, and LEDs the Light Bright Create will have a simple but effective design. The exhibit will be located on the mezzanine level of the museum in an area where visitors’ creations will truly shine. 

We won't stop there though! We have big plans that would expand the Light Bright Create into a whole set of Giant Games!

For more information about the campaign, be sure to watch this interview with Associate Director Caitlin Lill on the WCIA Morning Show: http://illinoishomepage.net/fulltext/?nxd_id=410532

 
 

The Benefits of Playing Games

Games help children develop critical math and logic skills. Games teach children about patterns, combinations, strategy, and thinking ahead. They also teach general life skills like turn-taking, patience, communication, and collaboration.

Light Bright Create in particular will provide a unique pathway to learning. It will stimulate the imaginations of visitors, arouse curiosity, and encourage creativity. It will contribute to the development of visual perception and color recognition, as well as important motor skills in younger children like eye-hand coordination and manual dexterity. Making the game GIANT adds to the impact by increasing the levels of fun and engagement; this also allows more than one child to play at a time, which is necessary in an informal learning environment.

 

Benefits to the Community

Children’s museums help children develop essential foundational skills that are no longer addressed in many schools and provide opportunities for quality interactions between children and their families or peers. Research from the University of Illinois finds that children feel bored as much as 50 percent of the time while at school or doing their homework. At children’s museums, kids become excited about what they are learning while they are playing. As multidisciplinary institutions, children’s museums are defining how to teach the arts, humanities, sciences, mathematics and human relations across generations. The Light Bright Create in particular will use art and excitement to provide a gateway to learning, inspiring kids across East Central Illinois to gain confidence in their ability to enjoy science and math.  

Contributing to our IndieGoGo campaign will also benefit not just yourself but the entire community! Funders aren’t just donors but active participants in bringing quality science education to children and families throughout Champaign County. Contributing also directly benefits your family, as anyone giving $25 or more will receive tickets to the museum and access to the new installation. We’ll also be hosting a full-day exhibit opening in September, which is the perfect benefit for museum members! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute financially to bringing Light Bright Create to the Orpheum? That's ok! We encourage you to share this via social media sites like facebook and twitter, tell you friends about it, and put up posters in places you frequent. This is a community effort and we can't do it without your support. Plus, once the exhibit is installed everyone will be welcome to visit and enjoy! 

 

Stretch Goals: Giant Games Series

This campaign doesn’t have to stop at just Light Bright Create. The original $3500 goal will get us there, but we believe we can do even better than that! To that end, we’ve developed a series of stretch goals to provide incentive to raise more funds and bring more Giant Games to the Orpheum. With additional funding we'll expand our efforts to refurbish and construct four different games exhibits this fall! Check them out below!

If we get $4000…the first step will be to fix the Giant Kaleidoscope! This links perfectly to the light experiments that visitors will conduct with the Light Bright Create, and gives us the chance to educate children about light waves and reflections.

If we get $4500…we’ll bring back Giant Chess! Particularly effective at teaching strategy and the importance of thinking ahead, Giant Chess is a great way for kids and families to interact!

If we get $6000…we’ll round out the “Giant Games” at the Orpheum with a HUGE version of the game Operations! With lessons about biology, medicine, and the importance of hand-eye coordination, Giant Operations is sure to bring educational fun to thousands of visitors!

If we get over $6000...it won't be hard to imagine new, exciting exhibits and programs! We'll update this section with new goals as we raise funds.

 

 

About the OCSM

The Orpheum Children’s Science Museum in Champaign, IL is dedicated to providing fun learning opportunities for children and families throughout the East Central Illinois region. As a privately-funded nonprofit, our mission is to inspire, engage, and educate children through exploration of science and the arts. Through 20 years of providing interactive exhibits and programs to our community we feel confident that our newest initiative is going to be one of our best yet: bringing the magic of Light Bright Create to children of all ages. With your help, we can make this project come alive for our community! 

 

Our Commitment

The Orpheum Children’s Science Museum is dedicated to providing high quality experiences for the community. We promise that 100% of funds raised through IndieGoGo will go towards exhibit construction and program development. All exhibits and programs will be designed with educational goals in mind.

 

Why IndieGoGo?

Something you may be wondering is why we’re using IndieGoGo to raise the funds for these exhibits. Three reasons:

 

-       With IndieGoGo, we can reach a lot of people quickly through a familiar medium. Since the Orpheum is 100% privately funded, we rely on our community to help us bring inspiring new exhibits and programs to the museum each year. IndieGoGo makes this process easy – and fun – for everyone involved!

-       We’re hoping to expand our methods of raising funds and going directly to the community for support at any level. Even $1 helps us, and IndieGoGo enables people to contribute at whatever level is comfortable for them and still receive recognition for it. Furthermore, IndieGoGo isn’t like other donation sites - you’ll be directly receiving goods and services for what you contribute, essentially letting us know that you support our efforts before we start them. 

-       Third, with IndieGoGo you can donate directly through PayPal.  Unlike Kickstarter, IndieGoGo allows us to receive charitable contributions. Because the Orpheum is a non-profit organization your donations to the Orpheum through PayPal may be tax deductible!

 

Contact Us

Do you have a question or a comment about our campaign? Have an idea for a "perk" that you think would be a great addition? Feel free to get in touch with us! Please send an e-mail to our Associate Director, Caitlin Lill, at caitlin@orpheumkids.com or call at (217)352-5895.

story:
Hi everyone,

We are trying our best to go back to year 2 of the American Youth Foundation's National Leadership Conference.  We were so fortunate to have had so many people help us last year, many became our good friends.

Well, we are at it again.  We are making sure that all of our forms are in and funds are being raised.  We appreciate any donation, large or small, to help us achieve our goal.

The NLC is August 3-10, outside of Grand Rapids, Michigan.  

Click the link below for more information.

http://www.ayf.com/youth-development-leadership-conference.asp

What We Need

We have applied for financial aid and hope to receive it like we did last year.  Unfortunately, our families do not have the money for plane tickets and other travel expenses.  We are trying to raise $500 for each of our plane tickets and we will each need $100 for the bus ride to and from the airport.  Between the two of us, we are thinking about $400 for the registration fees and any other incidentals.
 

The Impact

We had the time of our lives at the NLC 2011 and cannot wait to continue to grow as leaders.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us to spread the word, again.  We can't wait to pay-it-forward one day.

Thanks you!

story:
What is Turn Up the BASE?

Turn Up the BASE (Building Advocates through Social Justice Education) is a program born out of the minds and experiences of Mira Salas and Karen Cortez.  Many of you who know us, know our passion and unwavering commitment to youth and social justice.  While we both work with youth on a daily basis and undoubtably inject social justice into our work, we wanted to create a program where we could combine our two passions in the form of social justice education. 

Turn Up the BASE is 3 day, 2 night social justice education mini conference for gender marginalized (young womyn, transgender, and gender queer) youth of color ages 14-18.  We hope to create a space where youth examine gender through personal and shared experiences of discrimination and begin to think critically about gender roles and stereotypes.  We will then challenge youth to think about how they can make a difference and enact social change in their community.  Youth will walk away with a sense of empowerment, community, and skills to become effective agents of change.  **And the best part is- it is free, free, FREE for all participants!! ** 

Turn Up the BASE will be facilitated through interactive activities, exercises, workshops, and discussion.  Youth participants will also have an opportunity to earn a scholarship as well as raffle prizes and giveaways. 

The conference will take place at Point Reyes Hostel on Friday, August 3-Sunday, August 5, 2012.

Karen and Mira have a combined 8 years of experience working with youth.  In addition, Mira has organized similar retreats for young womyn. 

We, our supporters, and youth in the community are super excited about this project!  With your help, we can see it through! 

We Need YOU!

We need your love, your support, and, of course, your money!  Our budget is $4000 exactly which covers accomodations, food, supplies, transportation for the youth, and incentives such as our scholarship.  You can check out our budget in the gallery.

In exchange, we are offering our lovely Thank You gifts described in detail to the right.  Beyond that, you get to take part in our FIRST, of what we hope will be many, Turn Up the BASE conference.  Support our youth, create a vital counter space, and take part in history!

What Else Can You Do?

A lot!  We understand that not everyone can support financially and even if you can there are other ways to get involved! 

First, we are looking for in-kind donations in the form of food and supplies.  You can contact us at turnupthebaseconference@gmail.com for more information on what you could provide. 

Second, if you work with youth please refer your youth! You can go to our facebook page for more information about the conference and to access the application: facebook.com/turnupthebase    

Lastly, please share this with friends and family who may be interested in contributing!  Post it on your Facebook, twitter, or forward our email.

story:
Who we are:

Sport Against Poverty was created with a dream of developing sustainable soccer programs in Kenya for the underprivileged youth. This can be accomplished through the formation of partnerships with local Kenyan schools that will make our projects self-sufficient long before we ever leave the area. Our mission is to partner athletics with education to provide children with opportunities for advancement, both on and off the field. 

We believe, whole-heartedly, in the power of sports to motivate youth and transform lives. Personally, we have been fortunate enough to participate in sports from a very young age, and through this, we have witnessed the ability that sports possess to encourage focus and growth in all aspects of life. Our simple goal is to provide these children with that same opportunity—the opportunity to use their talents to achieve success.  By providing these children with access to coaches, equipment, and academic incentives, we hope to facilitate a program wherein the youth can rise up and reach their full potential. 

We have made two previous trips to Kenya (2005, 2007) and one to South Africa (2010) to build these relationships. We have also partnered with Sporting KC (Formerly the Kansas City Wizards) and SoccerPro.com and have been featured on their websites several times.

What We Need:

We are looking to raise enough funds to travel to Kenya and break ground on some of our programs. We aren’t looking to ship over a few supplies and move on because shoes will wear out, fields will need repair, and balls will lose air. We are striving to create sustainable programs that will run long after we have left, and the only way to do that is through forming individual and personal relationships with schools on the ground in Kenya. All of the money will be spent locally and none of our supplies will be outsourced. At the core of our mission is a focus on sustainability, and we believe the only way to achieve that is through introducing currency paired with opportunity into local economies. 

Funding will be used for:

  • Travel Costs (Roughly $3,500): Flight, Vaccines, Food. 
  • Field refurbishments: Goals, Nets, Turf Management. 
  • Equipment: Shoes, Shin-Guards, Balls, Gloves, Numbered Jerseys, Cones.
  • Local Labor: Identifying and training coaches, mentors, etc. 
  • Scholarships Programs: Identify and support youth with outstanding potential who wish to better themselves and make an impact on their local community.  

The Impact

By contributing to our cause, you are helping to introduce opportunity into the lives of youth that might never have known it. With your help, we can create sustainable programs that will empower and push children towards success and the betterment of their community in the years to come.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute, and we appreciate you taking the time to check this out. If you are not able to contribute financially, there are still some other ways that you can get involved.

  • Spread the word. Do you know someone that can help us out? Do you have a friend of a friend that wants to get involved? Every little bit helps—seriously. 
  • Do you have new or slightly used equipment? Some kids are out there using rocks as soccer balls. Got a ball in your garage or a numbered jersey in the attic? Send it our way. We take over as much equipment as we can fit in our bags. 

Thank you for your time and consideration.

story:
ABOUT MY TRIP
 
This fall, I have the opportunity to participate in two international service projects in conjunction with my graduate program in Occupational Therapy at Pacific University. 

In October, my classmates and great friends, Nicole and Liz, will be joining me as we travel to Dhaka, Bangladesh to provide services at the Centre for the Rehabilitation of the Paralyzed.  For the past year we have helped pioneer this adventure to Bangladesh through a brand new partnership with the Centre for the Rehabilitation of the Paralyzed (CRP) and Pacific University.  Over the course of 10 weeks, we will work to integrate children with disabilities into their families and communities by providing rehabilitation therapy, caregiver training and disability education.  CRP is one of the only facilities in Bangladesh to provide services to people with disabilities (though the disabled make up 10% of this country’s 140 million population).  The lack of service is due to a history of violence, negative perceptions and superstitious fears about disability within the region.  

After working in Bangladesh, Nicole and I will then travel to Nicaragua for 10 days to provide health care to elders living in nursing homes, called “hogars”.  This partnership is an interdisciplinary service project involving 13 hogars and Pacific University’s health professions students, of which we are proud to have been selected to provide Occupational Therapy services. This trip is sponsered by the Jesse F. Richardson Foundation, a nonprofit specializing in projects to improve conditions for adults in poverty. 

Both locations will provide me with different opportunities to develop cultural competency, empathy, and open-mindedness while helping provide services for people who experience discrimination due to their disabilities and often lack resources for appropriate care.

WHAT I NEED

I could use your support in many ways.  The first and most important thing, please pray for me as I prepare for this challenging educational mission (and for Brian who will be staying in Portland). 

I also will need some financial support to make this trip possible. I expect the trips to cost about $6,000 for room, board and airfare expenses. I am working to supply some of the cost through scholarships and financial aid, and every bit of support helps.

If you donate through this website, I have created some incentives, which are listed as "Perks" below.

If you would rather not donate through this website, here are other ways you can help!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

1. Share my page with others! Spread the word to others that you think are interested in my journey.

2. Gift cards, airfare miles or monetary donations can be contributed towards my personal travel expenses. (Unfortunately not tax deductible)
Sent to:
Megan Kelly
1717 NE 27th Ave
Portland, OR 97212

3. Mail a tax deductable donation to the Nicaragua project:  Please be sure to specify funds in my name on the memo. Include your name and address so the foundation can send you a tax letter.
Sent to:
The Jessie F. Richardson Foundation  
15900 SE 82nd Dr. 
Clackamas, OR 97015

4. Join the facebook page: Our Big Adventure to Bangladesh and then Nicaragua! There, you can stay up to date on all of the challenges, preparations and happenings of myself and my two fantastic travelling companions.

Again, thank you for your consideration and contribution to these upcoming educational experiences. Any assistance you are able to provide will be greatly appreciated.

Sincerely,
Megan Brown Kelly
story_txt:
ABOUT MY TRIP
 
This fall, I have the opportunity to participate in two international service projects in conjunction with my graduate program in Occupational Therapy at Pacific University. 
In October, my classmates and great friends, Nicole and Liz, will be joining me as we travel to Dhaka, Bangladesh to provide services at the Centre for the Rehabilitation of the Paralyzed.  For the past year we have helped pioneer this adventure to Bangladesh through a brand new partnership with the Centre for the Rehabilitation of the Paralyzed (CRP) and Pacific University.  Over the course of 10 weeks, we will work to integrate children with disabilities into their families and communities by providing rehabilitation therapy, caregiver training and disability education.  CRP is one of the only facilities in Bangladesh to provide services to people with disabilities (though the disabled make up 10% of this country’s 140 million population).  The lack of service is due to a history of violence, negative perceptions and superstitious fears about disability within the region.  
After working in Bangladesh, Nicole and I will then travel to Nicaragua for 10 days to provide health care to elders living in nursing homes, called “hogars”.  This partnership is an interdisciplinary service project involving 13 hogars and Pacific University’s health professions students, of which we are proud to have been selected to provide Occupational Therapy services. This trip is sponsered by the Jesse F. Richardson Foundation, a nonprofit specializing in projects to improve conditions for adults in poverty. 
Both locations will provide me with different opportunities to develop cultural competency, empathy, and open-mindedness while helping provide services for people who experience discrimination due to their disabilities and often lack resources for appropriate care.


WHAT I NEED
I could use your support in many ways.  The first and most important thing, please pray for me as I prepare for this challenging educational mission (and for Brian who will be staying in Portland). 
I also will need some financial support to make this trip possible. I expect the trips to cost about $6,000 for room, board and airfare expenses. I am working to supply some of the cost through scholarships and financial aid, and every bit of support helps.
If you donate through this website, I have created some incentives, which are listed as "Perks" below.
If you would rather not donate through this website, here are other ways you can help!
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
1. Share my page with others! Spread the word to others that you think are interested in my journey.
2. Gift cards, airfare miles or monetary donations can be contributed towards my personal travel expenses. (Unfortunately not tax deductible)Sent to:Megan Kelly1717 NE 27th AvePortland, OR 97212

3. Mail a tax deductable donation to the Nicaragua project:  Please be sure to specify funds in my name on the memo. Include your name and address so the foundation can send you a tax letter.Sent to:The Jessie F. Richardson Foundation  15900 SE 82nd Dr. Clackamas, OR 97015
4. Join the facebook page: Our Big Adventure to Bangladesh and then Nicaragua! There, you can stay up to date on all of the challenges, preparations and happenings of myself and my two fantastic travelling companions.
Again, thank you for your consideration and contribution to these upcoming educational experiences. Any assistance you are able to provide will be greatly appreciated.
Sincerely,Megan Brown Kelly

story:
Short Summary

A close family friend graduated from college and selflessly found her true calling shortly thereafter in Botswana where she and a friend started an orphanage. Together, they have worked with local women to grow this wonderful seed into a very special place for sick and abandoned children in the village.

However, the orphanage is still very young, and they continue to struggling with money. My grandmother has taken it upon herself to crochet hats and blankets for each of the children who are staying at the orphanage as a way of helping out from halfway across the world.

This is my grandmother's passion. She loves to crochet and has created and given away hundreds of handmade items for free, all made from materials that she purchased herself. 

What We Need & What You Get

My grandmother has purchased all of the yarn with her own money, and has spent weeks on this project. She has enjoyed every stitch of it.

Unfortunately, we simply cannot afford to ship them to the village. As a result, we are asking for your help. Our goal of $500.00 will cover shipping, yarn reimbursement, and allow her to buy more yarn to continue making hats and blankets for the children. Any and all extra money will be donated directly to the Lobatse Orphanage.

It is important to note that if we do not reach our funding goal, all contributions will be refunded. 

The Impact

Helping us fund this project would be so amazing. Not only would you be helping the orphanage in Lobaste, Botswana, but you'll also help my grandmother fully realize her dream of helping people across the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you simply cannot afford to help monetarily, there are other ways that you can help!

  • Spread the word on Facebook and Twitter!
  • Tell your friends!
  • Read more about the orphanage in Lobaste, Botswana.

- - - - - - - -

For more information about the orphanage, please visit HERE. Credit for portions of the video go to Mississippi College for use of their footage from Botswana, and Candyrat Records for use of Andy McKee's song "Rylynn".

story:
1 in 4 women in Canada have been abused by their partner. Children are present during 80% of these assaults.

Can you imagine how scared those kids must be?

Children who witness abuse have unique challenges to overcome. Growing up in an abusive home, they may have a radically different idea of "normal" relationship behaviour and the ways in which people express anger or frustration. Abuse in the home prevents them from receiving the consistent affection and nurturing that kids need. They may be scared, confused and isolated. The message they often receive is that 'Love' equals hurt and fear.

Being part of an abusive home is traumatic and as a result children can display many of the responses to trauma in their behaviour - depression, aggression, social withdrawal, physical symptoms like stomach aches or headaches are all common ways these children may respond. These "behavioural issues" are often labeled and "diagnosed" and at times may even lead to prescribed medications. They are labeled as bad kids, seen as bullies or may be marginalized from social groups.

Without intervention and support, children who witness abuse are at high risk of repeating the abusive behaviour they are growing up with, both as victims and as abusers. Boys who witness abuse have a 10x greater risk of repeating abusive behaviour in adult relationships.

Doesn't every child deserve better odds?

In addition to emergency support and shelter for women escaping domestic abuse, Victoria Women’s Transition House has been offering counselling, support and summer camps for children who witness abuse for more than 20 years. We have seen the amazing transformations that can happen when our counsellors give these children the supports and tools they need to learn about healthy boundaries, personal safety and positive ways to express emotions. We know from years of experience, the odds for these kids can be shifted and with support, they can build themselves a better future without abuse or violence. Working together, we can break the cycle of abuse for these children and prevent domestic abuse before it starts.

The key is working together. While the professional help of our counsellors is critical for their best chance of success, children need support and positive reinforcement from other adult mentors in their lives. Our counsellors are skilled and capable, however they are only one of the many adults these children interact with every day. Most important of all of the adults they encounter, of course, are their parents.

Our goal is to make a DVD that we can use to educate parents, as well as other adult mentors (such as teachers, aunts and uncles, school nurses) in the children’s lives, about the challenges these children face and that the behaviour issues they are seeing may be linked to witnessing abuse at home. The DVD will demonstrate, in an effective visual manner, some of the behaviours kids may exhibit, and the tools and resources that are available to help the child cope and overcome their trauma.

Transition House has effectively used DVD's as a learning tool in the past. We strongly believe that this DVD, with a focus on building a circle of support around kids who witness abuse, will make a huge impact on the ability of kids to break free from the abuse and violence they witnessed. This can allow them to build more hopeful and healthy lives as they grow.

Will you help us raise $5000 to create this DVD and so that we can let children who witness abuse know that love doesn't have to equal hurt? Please work with us to give these kids a chance at a more hopeful future.

Make a donation now!

Your contribution, big or small, will help us make and distribute this DVD. Please forward this to your email lists, post on your social media and ask your friends to do the same.

Together, we can show these kids Love ≠ Hurt.

We can break the cycle of violence and create hopeful futures for kids.

We are happy to provide Canadian charitable tax receipts for gifts over $10 if you provide us with your complete contact information (name, address, email or phone number).

** some folks have had problems making a donation through the windows explorer web browser. Please email us directly if you run into any trouble: theresan@vwth.bc.ca.**

For any questions regarding our indiegogo campaign or how you might be able to support us, please feel free to email theresan@vwth.bc.ca or call 250-592-2927 ext 214.

For more information about our organization and the services we provide please visit http://www.transitionhouse.net

Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

We earned around 1/3 of our goal in the first round of funding and are so happy to have the project jump-started.  Now it's time to make this project last!

This project stems from a desire to give back to my community. 

After winning a Rotary Scholarship to study music in South Africa, I wanted to find a way to give back to my community that gave me the opportunity to have this amazing experience, and I feel the best way is through youth & education.

So while I am here studying what I love, I am trying build a pen-pal program between a highschool here in South Africa with my home highschool in the USA, to give students here and from my home a chance to explore a world outside themselves by connecting with each other.  I hope to open their eyes to the same wonderful opportunities that I've been fortunate enough to have & to hopefully inspire them to engage.

What We Need & What You Get

We need money to pay for:

-shipping of care packages exchanged between classrooms (this figure is based on 10kg and is roughly $300 per package, so one from each class is $600, depending on the weight)

- supplies to put the care package together: (cds for music, paper for letters, tape, a box, materials for kids to make jewelry if they wish, drawings, a book if they wish etc.)

-disposable cameras to give the kids so they can take photos and share them

-processing of photos taken by the kids

-the processing of photographic portraits of students that I am taking 

The Impact

The impact of this project is to connect youth with each other.  The most important aspect of this project is that more than letters, each classroom is putting together a package with letters, photos, and other goodies to share their culture and for each classroom to teach each other.

Long-term benefits range from potential life-long friendships between students and potentially international high-school exchanges or at least visits if the program is able to become sustainable and to connect more kids with each other.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please just share this link with others and helps us reach our initial fundraising goal so we can try to further this project!

story:
Short Summary

In 2006, three school teachers from Melbourne, Australia decided that they wanted to get their students to realize that they have the capacity to make a positive difference in the world. They wanted their students to understand that they could be catalysts; dynamic forces for change. So, the teachers founded The Simunye Project which has inspired hundreds of people and raised over $100, 000 making a massive impact on the lives of local Australians and severely underprivileged communities in South Africa.

The Simunye Project guarantees that all sponsorships and fundraised money goes to those people who need it most. Focusing in on 4 organisations, the Project builds and renovates facilities, delivers food programs, trains teachers, improves health and sanitation and runs holiday programs all in a sustainable and impactful way.

‘Simunye’ is a Zulu word meaning ‘We are one’ and calls on people to acknowledge that we are all part of the one humanity and that in order to live full and meaningful lives, we must help others to do the same.

Sponsorships from the smallest amount to the larger sums all make a real difference in the lives of these underprivileged communities. $100 will help feed a family for three months; $500 helps to sponsor a teacher; $1500 helps to build toilets and get rid of the threat of cholera; $10 000 builds a well and provides fresh water to an entire community; $15 000 is sufficient funds for a classroom.

It’s that easy.

One company decided not to have corporate planner for the year and sponsored that amount to the Simunye Project enabling us to build a well and improve the lives of an entire community forever.

So, what’s in it for you? Depending on the amount you sponsor you will have access to photographs, video footage and outstanding speakers. This allows you to leverage your sponsorship ensuring that employees and clients are fully aware of your commitment to social responsibility. There is even a 7 day experience in South Africa specifically designed for those busy people who would like to provide hands-on assistance.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This year our aim is to build another well (borehole) for Educare Daycare Centre. They are in desperate need of access to clean water to drink, to wash and to enable them to water their vegetable garden. A borehole will result in massively improved health and sanitation conditions, and in some cases will save lives. 

This is a unique organization as young people are given the opportunity to work alongside local people to improve local conditions. The impact is real, sustainable and measurable. There are countless reports of improved health, work, social, academic and financial situations amongst individuals and communities. Furthermore, young people in Australia are changed forever as they see the power they have to change the world for the better.

We need as much or as little as you can give! 100% of the funds raised go directly to projects which help these communities. Through Indigogo, we are hoping to raise the $10 000.

No matter what we raise, we will be able to put it all towards one of the projects we will complete in 2013. There is no dollar that can't be put to good use!  

 

The Impact

There are countless stories from our work in South Africa that indicate the viability of the projects. In 2009, we were able to get rid of a hole in the ground that served as a toilet at a day care centre and build a toilet. The access to clean sanitation dramatically lowered the levels of cholera to virtually zero.

The local communities trust us deeply as year after year we return to make sustainable changes and improve their lives.

Video footage and letters attest to the impact the Simunye Project is making.

 The current organisations that we work with are: 

Urban Organisations

  • Tshepang Programme for Orphaned and Vulnerable Children An after-school care program for orphaned and vulnerable primary school children. This serves over 200 children and families. We also support local baking and clothing industries that the Simunye Project has helped to build on site.
  • Princess Alice Adoption Home Cares for babies abandoned or awaiting adoption

Rural Organisations

  • Manyeleti Primary School Disadvantaged rural school
  • New Life Day Care Centre A centre caring for small children during the daytime whilst their parents work
  • Educare Day Care Centre built entirely by The Simunye Project looks after over 60 young children.

 

Other ways you can help

Maybe you would like to be part of the Project for your school, work, sports club or group of mates. We can tailor-make a trip for you. And, rest assured, it will be a life- changing experience as you do something real for your global community. Africa will get under your skin and you will be booking your next trip back very soon!

Even if you can't contribute, please spread the word of Simunye to any people or organizations that you think would like to be a part of this amazing project. Share through the indigogo share tools or go to www.thesimunyeproject.com to check out what we do, and keep up with our latest trip. 

There are also YouTube videos that beautifully capture the Project in action.

Thank you for your consideration and interest in providing life-changing experiences for young people, both locally and abroad.

story:
Our Story

The Strong Camps:  Growing Strong Girls with Big Dreams
In June 2011, Full Circles Foundation, a project of Grand Aspirations, launched the Strong Camps, a six-week series of community-powered summer day camps that worked to illuminate the connections between personal, community, and environmental health for girls ages 5 through 17.  The camps were hosted in Raleigh, North Carolina, by area faith communities, and in partnership with a host of North Carolina partners.  

At Strong Home Camp, we canoed, explored North Carolina's forests and learned that "everything [really] is hitched to everything else."  We examined the connections between math and nature, and cooked delicious meals with local, whole food.  We planted our own herbs and made "flower bombs," ideal for turning dusty cityscapes into fragrant oases for bumblebees!

At Strong Self Camp, we discovered the joy of upcycling, screen-printing by hand, and making our own all-natural body products.  The older girls had thought-provoking discussions about human rights, gender, and women in history.  We did yoga in the morning, made our own hula-hoops, wrote the official Full Circles Foundation anthem, and capped the camp off with an eclectic talent show!

At Strong Neighbor Camp, we learned about the importance of participatory governance and drafted, via consensus, our own camp guidelines.  We talked about "the marketplace" and visited local businesses and the farmer's market to learn first-hand what it is like being a local entrepreneur.  We explored the orienting power of shared stories (and the role we play in writing them) at the North Carolina history museum and on an afternoon rickshaw tour of Raleigh.  The older girls visited local colleges and universities, while the younger ones finally got the much-desired trip to the pool. 

It was a transformative summer, not only because the camps were amazing, but also because a central ethic of social entrepreneurship created real ownership and real community.  Each camp featured a microventure project that built financial and community resources.  Campers, families, and instructors would all come out to the monthly downtown Raleigh "First Friday" markets to talk to Raleigh neighbors about the connections between personal, community, and environmental health, and to offer our awesome goods - artisinal all-natural bath salts, screen-printed t-shirts, flower bombs, and hand-made hula hoops.      

Back to the Future
In summer 2012, Full Circles Foundation is preparing to expand the Strong Camps in Raleigh to include more girls, a veggie-diesel bus, an overnight Strong Home camp, and the integration of an apprentice program! 

Full Circles Foundation is also THRILLED to announce that a team of amazing women from Lexington, Kentucky, have decided to host a Strong Camps pilot program in their hometown!  Sharing lessons, dreams, and schemes, Raleigh and Lexington will co-develop complimentary programming that is founded on the same core principles, yet also unique to our own places.   

Want to read the full history of Full Circles Foundation?  Scroll on down!

The Impact of the Strong Camps

Campers

The Strong Camps are an opportunity for campers gain environmental literacy, health literacy, civic efficacy, and extra practice in many of their school subjects.  But most critically, they gain confidence.  And a girl with confidence in the power of her dreams generates all kinds of additional (and statistically shown) positive impacts, from her neighborhood to Washington.


Instructors 

The Strong Camps provide a unique opportunity for instructors as well.  A position with Full Circles Foundation requires the a rare responsibility of both fine-tuning abstract ideas, and turning them into reality.  The challenges to executing the Strong Camps are not insignificant and require rigorous personal reflection as well.  This makes it all the more incredible to reflect upon success.  Campers are not the only ones who left the summer with a new-found sense of empowerment and purpose.


Community

The planning and execution of the Strong Camps also provide an opportunity for community partners to come together for substantive, joyful conversations about the localized, integrated solutions that, together, we can build to meet modern crises.        


What We Need & What You Get

The goal for our holiday fundraising campaign is $2500.  While this may seem like a fair chunk of change, it's only the beginning of our 2012 resource-generation efforts.  Running a full 2012 Strong Camps series will cost about $30,000*, and we are going to be running two!  To put it a different way, a "full scholarship" for a camper would sum in the neighborhood of $500 (a bargain for a six week camp!) 


The funds that we raise allow us to offer free attendance to all qualifying campers.  The funds cover living-wage based stipends for instructors, camp materials, transportation, space, and camp meals.    


While we gratefully accept any amount of funding, check out the perks we have listed on the right side for our generous donors!  Every penny counts! 


* This number reflects the total value of the Strong Camps.  A significant percentage thereof is constituted by in-kind donations.


Other Ways You Can Help

Follow us on Twitter.  http://twitter.com/#!/FullCirclesNC & http://twitter.cm/#!/FullCirlcesKY

Become our Facebook friend.  http://www.facebook.com/fullcirclesfoundation

Recommend our blog to your friends.  http://www.strongcamps2011.blogspot.com/ & http://fullcirclesfoundation.tumblr.com/

Volunteer!  http://www.fullcirclesfoundation.org/volunteerapp.html

Contact us about replicating FCF in your Southeastern or Appalachian community! 


The Full Dish

In January 2011, a team of three determined women - young folks with audacious optimism, a pinch of experience, a desire to create empowering and sustainable models of living, and fairly threadbare pockets - launched a bold project in Raleigh, North Carolina, dedicated to growing strong girls, a fair economy, and a healthy planet.  It was called Full Circles Foundation.  

Their vision was to co-create a safe, empowering community that was rooted in an understanding of 
  • the indivisibility of personal, community, and environmental health (it's all connected!); 
  • the need for lateral power (networks!); 
  • the strength found in nurturing diverse perspectives, identities, skills, forms of intelligence, etc.; 
  • the importance of feedback mechanisms (often referred to as "listening"); 
  • and the necessity of "relational" solutions to modern crises.  

This community would then do the impossible:  translate pretty words into praxis.   

It would provide a long-term continuum of think-outside-the-box adventures (also called "programs") for girls who have high potential but are facing big challenges.  These programs would weave together social entrepreneurship, democracy training, and interdisciplinary instruction in personal health & wellness, environmental literacy/natural sciences, creative communication, and mathematics.  And when we say "long term," we mean that - best case scenario - a girl would be matriculated as a rising Kindergartner and Full Circles Foundation would hang out with her until she graduated from high school.  And the model would be self-sustaining!  And we were fairly convinced that this just might be a good enough idea that other communities might eventually want to replicate it!  

Pretty huge, right?  But it wasn't exactly clear how we were going to get from brainstorming around the kitchen table to the immense vision described above.

And then our fairy godmother showed up.  Her name was Grand Aspirations (www.grandaspirations.org).  She specializes in turning the dreams of "young folks with audacious optimism, a desire to create empowering and sustainable models of living, and fairly threadbare pockets" (pinch of experience not necessary) into reality.

Grand Aspirations took us under her wing, equipped us with seed funding, organizational tools, and seats at a capacity building conference.  None of this would have been possible without the amazing support and partnership of Grand Aspirations.  We love you Grand Aspirations!
story_txt:
Our Story
The Strong Camps:  Growing Strong Girls with Big Dreams
In June 2011, Full Circles Foundation, a project of Grand Aspirations, launched the Strong Camps, a six-week series of community-powered summer day camps that worked to illuminate the connections between personal, community, and environmental health for girls ages 5 through 17.  The camps were hosted in Raleigh, North Carolina, by area faith communities, and in partnership with a host of North Carolina partners.  

At Strong Home Camp, we canoed, explored North Carolina's forests and learned that "everything [really] is hitched to everything else."  We examined the connections between math and nature, and cooked delicious meals with local, whole food.  We planted our own herbs and made "flower bombs," ideal for turning dusty cityscapes into fragrant oases for bumblebees!


At Strong Self Camp, we discovered the joy of upcycling, screen-printing by hand, and making our own all-natural body products.  The older girls had thought-provoking discussions about human rights, gender, and women in history.  We did yoga in the morning, made our own hula-hoops, wrote the official Full Circles Foundation anthem, and capped the camp off with an eclectic talent show!


At Strong Neighbor Camp, we learned about the importance of participatory governance and drafted, via consensus, our own camp guidelines.  We talked about "the marketplace" and visited local businesses and the farmer's market to learn first-hand what it is like being a local entrepreneur.  We explored the orienting power of shared stories (and the role we play in writing them) at the North Carolina history museum and on an afternoon rickshaw tour of Raleigh.  The older girls visited local colleges and universities, while the younger ones finally got the much-desired trip to the pool. 

It was a transformative summer, not only because the camps were amazing, but also because a central ethic of social entrepreneurship created real ownership and real community.  Each camp featured a microventure project that built financial and community resources.  Campers, families, and instructors would all come out to the monthly downtown Raleigh "First Friday" markets to talk to Raleigh neighbors about the connections between personal, community, and environmental health, and to offer our awesome goods - artisinal all-natural bath salts, screen-printed t-shirts, flower bombs, and hand-made hula hoops.

story:
THE 18TH ANNUAL THAI CULTURAL DAY

Witness and celebrate the art forms of Thailand in Hollywood, at the Barnsdall Art Park. Enjoy a day filled with Thai dancing, costumes, fashion shows, music, and art. Learn the folk dances taught to Thai children and see men and women demonstrating their skills at Thai kick boxing.

This is a fantastic family day atop Barnsdall Art Part which is home to the historic Frank Lloyd Wright Hollyhock House. It's Free to the public and brought to you by a generous grant from the Los Angeles Department of Cultural Affairs and hundreds of volunteers and contributors from the Thai community and friends.

The festival takes place on:
Sunday, September 19, 2010
from 11:00am-5:00pm
At:
Barnsdall Art Park
4800 Hollywood Boulevard
Los Angeles, CA 90027

Convenient parking is available across the street at Kaiser.
(*please park only in legal or clearly designated spaces to avoid tickets and/or towing)

Whether you can join us or not, a contribution from you will go a long way towards keeping this cultural treasure of Los Angeles alive. Please give and be a part of the day. Your contributions will be tax deductible as Thai Community Arts and Cultural Committee which puts on the event is a 501c3 organization.

story:
My Story!

Hello! My name is Jennie Willingham. I'm a 27 year old studying to become a minister with the Unity church, a metaphysical Christian religious organization. I received a scholarship to take ministerial classes at Unity Village in Missouri, where the Unity Institute is located. The scholarship covers four classes and room and board--all I need is to do is get there!


This AMAZING scholarship expires in April, so the last opportunity I have to take classes is in March. Things have been rough recently--my father's been in the hospital, a friend recently passed away, I have a part time job (which I love) where I don't get enough hours to sustain myself, among several other stressful situations accumulating over the past few months. Taking these classes is a symbolic affirmation that things will get better and that I'm exactly where I'm supposed to be.


The Impact!

Taking these classes means the world to me. I want to help people, and to live in service. I haven't been able to afford to take classes over the past few years, and recently I've been having a bit of a crisis in faith. I feel very drawn to take these classes, to use this scholarship before it expires.


As these courses lead to self-discovery, there's no doubt in my mind that I will return refreshed and inspired, and bring that new energy to every aspect of my life; to my volunteer positions working with high schoolers, middle schoolers, and young adults, as well as volunteering with domestic violence survivors, and among my friends and coworkers.


What I Need!

I need money for airfare and random travel expenses, as well as for a new (very inexpensive) camera to document and chronologize my trip. Pictures are very important to me, both for personal enjoyment and in sharing my memories with other people. I particularly want pictures to look back on once I'm a minister, to share my path with other people who think they may not be able to achieve their dreams.


Any contribution over $15 will receive a "Thank You!" postcard from Unity Village while I'm there.


WHATEVER you can contribute would be SOOOOOO appreciated!! Five dollars, ten dollars, even a fistful of change!!


Other Ways You Can Help!!

Keep this vision in your mind! Tell other people! Send me good vibes!


THANK YOU for checking out my page!! I'd love your support!

story:
Our Story

Service to the World was created for the Kentucky YMCA alumi to practice global citizenship through service learning, cultural exchange, and exposure to global YMCA movements. It is a capacity-building program that gives young adults the opportunity to promote youth development, healthy living, and social responsibility throuh work with YMCAs around the globe. This year, our inaugural STTW team will travel to Israel and the Palestinian Territories for two weeks of service and cultural immersion with the Jerusalem International YMCA, the East Jersusalem YMCA, and several other community organizations and NGO's.

The Impact

We are proud to announce that this is the Kentucky YMCA Youth Association's first international service endeavor. Our plan is to create a sustainable model for our Service to the World program, along the lines of our Y-Corps Service program, so that we may continue to provide opportunities for young Kentuckians to serve and to learn.


During these two weeks, our ultimate goal is to put the idea of global citizenship into practice.  We hope to accomplish this goal by building meaningful relationships with the Israeli and Palestinian people through service learning and cultural immersion. We want to know their stories and their lifestyles, their hopes and musings as individuals, and in turn, we want to share the same with them. 


The mission of this program is not for us to "fix" problems or impart our own ideas for solutions, but rather to engage in a powerful learning process that might help us understand the history and nuances of a deeply complex issue from both sides.  We hope to humble ourselves in service with the goal of taking away a lesson or two in history, diplomacy, and the joy that is service learning.


Another goal of this trip is to gain exposure to the incredible momentum that is the Global YMCA movement. We will learn what the YMCA's in Jerusalem, Tiberius, Ramallah, Beit Sahour, and Jericho are up to. We will work with a peace preschool, a women's job training center, a refugee camp, a guest retreat house, and other small NGO's. We will cross through the major cities of Tel Aviv, Jerusalem, and Haifa, up through the green mountains of the Golan Region and down through the Negev Desert in the south of Israel. We will journey into the West Bank and visit several major historical sites in a handful of cities. We will ask questions though the answers may evade us and we will meditate though we will find ourselves wrestling with the confrontation between loss and the endurance of the human spirit.


With a globalized world in mind, with dreams of peace for our grandchildren, and with the hope of making a small impact in a major conflict in a mighty big world, we are honored to be the inaugural team and we are excited that you are interested in helping us see this vision through.


Our Illustrious Team

Sadie Aschbacher, Louisville
Allison Carter, Mount Vernon
Josh Hardesty, Louisville
Christopher Head, Simpsonville
Ashton Hupman, Lexington
Tracy Jo Ingram, Louisville
Emily Miles, Louisville
Neha Parthasarathy, Greenville, SC
Clayton Ray, Louisville
Randall Richardson, Elizabethtown
Nicole Ashley Smith, Walton 
Taylor Willett, Louisville 


What We Need & What You Get

Each team member will be responsible for raising $3,650. With twelve team members that calls for a total of $43,200 to pull this thing off! Right now we are setting our goal lower to see if we can capture an initial interest in our campaign (not to mention the site penalizes us if we don't reach our goal). If we can generate enough income to reach our $6,000 goal, that's $500 off the top for each team member!

So, here it goes-- the break down of the $3,650/member...

  • $1,600: The plane ticket to-and-fro, but of course.
  • $800: On-the-ground transportation. This is a HUGE cost for us-- renting a bus + having a guide/driver/living GPS for two whole weeks.
  • $400: Grub to fill our bellies for two weeks (roughly $7/meal x 3/day, plus snacks to sustain, and airport meals just in case).
  • $400: Staff overhead (at 1 staff member's $3650 cost) and a little extra to fund back into the sustainability of the program.
  • $200: Our favorite part! $200 USD from each team member will be donated towards an NGO in Israel/Palestinian territories. That's nearly $2,500 proud bucks!
  • $150: Most days we will have lodging at local YMCA's. On the days we don't (roughly around 4), we will have to stay at inexpensive hostels/hotels. 
  • $100: Entrance into museums, parks, and other cultural learning activities including Masada National Park, the Golan Heights Winery, Ein Gedi Botanical Gardens, etc.


Check out our sweet incentives just to the right of this text. For every dollar you donate at the $25 level or above, you'll reap the benefits!

Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise about our campaign, please! You can share this page on Facebook, by e-mail, on Twitter. Send word to other Y-alums, your boss, your Great Auntie Shirley, your monkey's uncle. Whatever works, all helps. Our appreciation is profound.

story:
After 16 years out of school, I decided to go back and get my degree in Business Management.  I am the mom of twin boys that are 9, I am employed full time and I have been attending school full time since last winter.  I have maintained a 3.98 GPA and most recently became a member of National Honor Society, Phi Theta Kappa.  I am president-elect of the local Bangor Kiwanis and participate in many community events. 

I was nominated to be part of the International Scholar Laureate Program which is being hosted in New Zealand and Australia for 7 days in May.  The total trip including flight and tuition is about $6,095 and I am looking for tuition assistance.  I will be in the Medical and Science field learning about transformation of the healthcare system and patient access in these countries.  This is a huge learning opportunity for me for my education and my career, as I currently work for a hospital system in Organizational Effectiveness.

I am honored and truly appreciate any assistance on can provide, as I will not be able to experience this once in a lifetime event without the help of you!  I am reaching out to local are clubs and have established sponsorship levels.  I will hold a press release and the donors will receive full credit for their support.  (Bronze -$50, Silver - $100, Gold $250, and Platinum - $500.)

Thank you again for support!
